s.w: Five
Joan rode home, her heart heavy as lead.
She was beset by the realization that she desired nothing more than to go to the Hall as Anne Mowbray's companion.
At the same time, she felt a sense of guilt, of disloyalty, that she could even for an instant contemplate the idea of deserting her mother and turning her back on the place she called home.
She took no pleasure from the countryside as on the outward journey.

Then she had shown an avid interest in everything she saw: the horses themselves, the rabbits frolicking in the fields or running to escape the horses' hooves, in a landscape full of promise — cool, mellow and green.
Now the sun had disappeared behind a cloud and the countryside was shadowed and brooding — an unfriendly place filled with menace.
Her heart was still at Framlingham Hall, the house that stood in the shadow of the great castle with thirteen towers, built by Roger Bigod in the year 1177.
Briar Cottage looked of a sudden smaller, Joan thought as it came into sight.

It appeared deserted, a trifle sinister even amid the overhanging trees — and, though she had not before registered the fact, it lacked the sound of happy voices which had in times past always greeted her return.
Briar Cottage no longer seemed like home; like the cottage where eleven years earlier she had been born.
The groom helped her dismount and she thanked him politely and waited, unwilling to break the link with her new-found friend before she must, until groom and horses were out of sight.

She was surprised that her mother had not hurried out
to greet her.
She had pictured Bess Halidon, restless and anxious, looking eagerly for her return…
She lifted the latch and went indoors.

s.c: &bquo;Mama?&equo; she called from the threshold.
&bquo;Mama?

s.w: I am back — home again safe and sound.
Where are you?
Upstairs?
I'm coming up.
There's no need to worry — I'd not live there for all the gold in Christendom and I told the lady Anne as much!
Nay, I said — at Briar Cottage I live and there I mean to stay!&equo;
She had reached the top of the narrow wooden stairs that led into the single upper-storey chamber she shared with her mother.
Little more than a boarded-over loft in a single storey cottage, the room was neat and clean as a newly-laundered pinny.

s.c: &bquo;Mama —&equo; she said — and giving a little cry, ran towards the low wooden bed.
&bquo;Mama, are you poorly?&equo;

s.w: She put out a hand and touched the prostrate woman — and drew it away in distress.
Bess Halidon was dead— though not yet cold.
It must have been just after I left, thought Joan.
Mama must have felt poorly, dragged herself upstairs and…
Bess Halidon's eyes were half open, and Joan, to whom death was no new experience, gently closed them.
She straightened out the dead woman, folded her hands and tidied the bed.

s.c: &bquo;I must go for the priest —&equo; she said to the empty room.
&bquo;— and for Mother Neville who does the laying-out.

s.w: I must go right away.&equo;
She shed no tears as she left the cottage and made her way along the lane to the priest's house.
Tears were for later— was not she Bess Halidon's daughter?
There were things to be done, important things.
She must keep busy— see to things.
It was not until night-time that Joan had time to think properly, to let the fact that her mother was dead, sink in.
Lying on a pallet in the downstairs chamber, the deceased woman laid out upstairs, the only sounds came from the cat cleaning itself by the hearth and an owl hooting raucously outside.
She was beset of a sudden by a great fear…
She was utterly alone now.
The realization came as a shock and she pressed her clenched fist to her heart as if to pacify it.
Alone, she thought…
First papa, then Alice, Margaret, Ann and Rose — and now poor mama.
I have none in the whole world to call my own.

s.c: &bquo;But I am in my twelfth summer,&equo; she said aloud then, stifling a sob.
&bquo;I could manage — of course I could!

s.w: The cottage is mine now, for mama told me — only a few days ago, it was — that it would be mine one day.
And I too could take in washing…&equo;
Framlingham Hall sprang to mind at that point.
She thought of thedowager-duchess and the lady Anne…
It was then that the thought struck her.
It was then that the tears fell.

s.c: &bquo;Alas, lady Anne!&equo; she said through her tears — the words echoing eerily around the darkened chamber.
&bquo;So you've got your own way after all.

s.w: You prayed, just as you said you would— and, this time, God has answered your prayer!&equo;
Six
Once Bess Halidon had been laid to rest in the small village churchyard, and the initial shock of her mother's death had abated, Joan decided to pay a second visit to Framlingham Hall.
Should the dowager-duchess not be in residence, she told herself, she would leave a message with the housekeeper.
Elizabeth Mowbray having been informed by a servant of Bess Halidon's demise, had sent Joan a formal but kindly letter of condolence.
She had made no reference to Joan's first visit to the Hall, considering it unsuitable to combine such a letter with practicalities.
Presenting herself at the servant's entrance, Joan asked nervously if she might speak to the housekeeper.
After a few minutes, she was shown into that estimable if forbidding woman's presence.

s.c: &bquo;You wished to see me, I believe,&equo; Mistress Bubwith said coldly.

s.w: She was uncertain as to the position of this girl whom she knew to be daughter to a washerwoman but whom the dowager-duchess, a lady of formal demeanour and rigid etiquette, none the less treated as one of higher status.
There is more in this than meets the eye! thought the housekeeper.
The girl is polite enough, though somewhat raw in speech — yet her likeness to the lady Anne is quite uncanny.
It is plain that someone, sometime, bore an infant on the wrong side of the blanket!
The lady Anne is a Mowbray all right, so 'tis plain from which side of the family this lass comes.
That being so, I must watch my step and keep my ears pinned back.

s.c:
&bquo;I'm here to see Her Grace,&equo; explained Joan, having
rehearsed what she would say during the two-mile walk from Briar Cottage.
&bquo;If now's not convenient, I can come back another day.&equo;
&bquo;What is the nature of your business with Her Grace?&equo; enquired the housekeeper coldly.
&bquo;It has to do with what was said last time I was here.&equo;
&bquo;Her Grace is at home.

s.w: Wait here and I will enquire as to an appointment.&equo;
Mistress Bubwith returned very quickly, seeming a mite breathless.

s.c: &bquo;Her Grace will see you now, Joan Halidon.

s.w: She can spare you but a few minutes, she says —&equo; the dowager-duchess had in fact said no such thing &bquo;— but will see you at once.&equo;
On entering the solar, Joan was reminded of that other visit and what had come after — and was all but overwhelmed by distress.

s.c: &bquo;A good day to you, Joan,&equo; was Elizabeth Mowbray's greeting.
&bquo;I rather hoped you would call on us.&equo;

s.w: Joan hid her surprise.

s.c: &bquo;Thank you for the letter, Your Grace — 'twas kind of you to write.

s.w: I can't read, but I took it to the priest and he read it to me.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;And how are you managing without your mother?&equo; enquired Elizabeth Mowbray.
&bquo;You are, I believe, on your own — and you not twelve years of age!&equo;

s.w: Perhaps it was something in the dowager-duchess's voice that caused it, but Joan to her own dismay burst into tears.
She fumbled for a handkerchief without success — and Elizabeth Mowbray handed her the capaciouslace-edged one she wore for decoration at her girdle.

s.c: &bquo;You must miss your mother greatly,&equo; observed Elizabeth Mowbray.
&bquo;Life can be very cruel at times.

s.w: I know what it is to lose one dearly loved.&equo;

s.c: &equo; 'Twas that day, you see,&equo; explained Joan, trying to stem her tears.
&bquo;I left here, telling myself I couldn't be lady Anne's companion 'cos I couldn't leave mama on her own.

s.w: And when I got home, poor ma was dead and I was the one on me own!
I'm sorry, Your Grace…&equo;
Elizabeth Mowbray poured a little wine into a silver cup and gave it to her.

s.c: &bquo;Sip this,&equo; she said.
&bquo;It will make you feel better.
&bquo;I'm sorry for making such a fuss,&equo; Joan said apologetically, drying her eyes — before taking a few sips of the wine which she did not much like.
&bquo;I also am sorry, Joan — for you and your loss.

s.w: But the offer of your coming here to us still stands.
The lady Anne has talked of little else since she met you and would be overjoyed, I know, were you able in due course to come and live with us.
What do you say?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I'd like nothing better,&equo; Joan replied with feeling.
&bquo;I'd be a good servant to the lady Anne.&equo;
&bquo;The lady Anne needs you.

s.w: She needs someone of her own age to talk with — maybe even to quarrel with at times,&equo; said Elizabeth Mowbray with a smile.

s.c: &bquo;As her companion, you would receive many privileges — though only those not pertaining to rank, as you will understand.

s.w: Such is to a great extent your due.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;My due, you say?&equo;

s.w: Joan was puzzled.

s.c: &bquo;You speak as if such privileges were mine by right, Your Grace.&equo;
&bquo;One day, Joan, we shall speak of that again,&equo; came the intriguing reply.
&bquo;I shall tell you a little more of your background — acquaint you perchance with certain knowledge to which I am privy.

s.w: Here and now is not the time.
All that needs to be said here and now is — how soon may we expect you?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;There's Briar Cottage,&equo; Joan said uneasily after a moment's consideration.
&bquo;That'll have to be sold and the inside scrubbed and made ready for them as buys it.

s.w: Once that's done…&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I have a suggestion to make, Joan.

s.w: Why not stay here tonight and on the morrow I will have someone take you over to Briar Cottage with a wagon?

Then you can collect up your belongings, all those things you would wish to have with you at the Hall — you will have your own bedchamber remember — and then, when you are ready, you can bolt the door and the windows and return here in the wagon.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;But the cottage itself,&equo; demurred Joan.
&bquo;I know naught about selling things and…&equo;

&bquo;My steward shall take charge of the matter for you — if
you so wish,&equo; Elizabeth Mowbray interposed, as if she had already given thought to it.
&bquo;Alternatively, you could retain Briar Cottage.

s.w: We could refurbish it and it would remain your property, a place of your own to go to whenever you so desired.
I doubt not it holds many happy memories for you.

s.c: &bquo;It does indeed, Your Grace.&equo;

s.w: Tears again filled Joan's eyes but she brushed them away.

s.c: &bquo;Yea, I'd like to keep it — if it's possible.&equo;
&bquo;It is indeed, Joan — and keep it you shall,&equo; smiled Elizabeth Mowbray.
&bquo;Whilst you remain here with us — and let me say here and now that there will be a place here for you for as long as you wish — you will share in the life of the household and have all provided.

s.w: Furthermore, it would please me to give you an allowance for your personal use.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Your Grace, I don't understand — why are you doing all this for me?

s.w: Has it to do with what you said as you'd tell me one day?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;In some measure — but only in some measure,&equo; replied Elizabeth Mowbray.

s.w: She looked down at a letter on the table in front of her, collecting her thoughts.
Is not this lass sister, half-sister to my daughter? she asked herself.
What else, since she is of my lord's begetting?

s.c: &bquo;I see you as a sister for my daughter — the sister she never had.

s.w: Might one then ask a favour of you?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;You can, Your Grace — ask anything.&equo;
&bquo;I ask that henceforth, whatsoever the provocation and difficulties, you will remain loyal and true to the lady Anne — as to a sister.&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Mowbray sighed.

s.c: &bquo;Anne can at times be wilful, self-centred, headstrong — she is a true Mowbray!

s.w: But she has fine qualities also — as I trust you will discover for yourself.
Pray tell me, Joan Halidon, that I may depend on your loyalty to my daughter.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I swear it,&equo; Joan said earnestly, her eyes bright with tears.
&bquo;By the Holy Rood, I swear it!&equo;

s.w: Her emotion this time was not prompted by grief for her mother — but by the seriousness of the moment.
Her heart was touched by what the duchess had offered her and by what had been asked of herself in return.

So many
benefits would she receive, not least the companionship of the vivacious and warm-hearted Anne Mowbray; and so little was being asked of herself.
The promise was readily given and gratefully received: so small a thing it seemed to the giver and so great to the receiver.
But the journey of life has many twists and turns.
Dark passageways and blind alleys obscure the light at the end of the tunnel.
Danger, intrigue and tragedy lurk unseen, unrecognized by the traveller — whilst evil, unimagined and terrible, lies in wait around the next bend.

Just as the end of the tunnel comes into view, giving promise of freedom and happiness, of radiance long awaited — the darkness and That-which-dwells-in-darkness bear down, overtaking those quickening footsteps…
Seven
Joan accordingly took up the post of companion to the lady Anne and thereafter had no great difficulty in adjusting to a new and privileged life-style.
At Elizabeth Mowbray's suggestion, she took the name de Warenne after one of her real father's earldoms — though she herself was still unaware of the connection.
Joan liked the name and, since it pleased the duchess, had no qualms about severing this last link with her former life.
She occupied a well-furnished chamber close to the lady Anne's apartments, and was given a wardrobe of new clothes which was an especial delight.
Prior to sharing her young mistress's lessons, she received instruction in deportment and etiquette.
She learned quickly and eagerly and soon acquired sufficient know-how to join Anne Mowbray in the small schoolroom.
Elizabeth Mowbray was delighted by the marked change in her daughter that followed Joan's arrival.
Moody and high-strung though Anne was by nature, the girls' brief quarrels were no more than might be expected between any siblings.
The duchess, recalling her own upbringing amidst a lively brood of brothers and sisters, recognized this, and was gratified by the devotion and closeness that had grown up between the girls.
The following year passed uneventfully at Framlingham Hall.
It was a year during which Joan came near to forgetting her humble origins — the fact that she was the orphaned daughter of a washerwoman.

All but adopted by Elizabeth Mowbray — though having no idea why — she was Joan de Warenne, friend and companion to Anne Duchess
of York.
The fact that she addressed the latter formally, as lady Anne, was the one concession to rank and status — and even that was frequently disregarded when the girls were alone…
Then came the day in the year 1482 when Elizabeth Mowbray received a letter from the king requiring her presence with her daughter at court.
Anne was approaching her thirteenth birthday and King Edward considered it time that she and his son Prince Richard, then ten years of age, became better acquainted.
The idea of being received at court for the first time since the childhood marriage, at first caused Anne much excitement.
Seamstresses were put to work to increase her already adequate wardrobe but, as the days passed and the day of departure from Framlingham loomed close, she became increasingly petulant.

s.c: &bquo;Why, methought you were overjoyed at the prospect of going to court!&equo; remarked Joan, to whom the idea was akin to going as a mere mortal to fairyland.
&bquo;For myself, I can scarce believe it is true — that I am to accompany you on so grand a venture.&equo;
&bquo;I was pleased — at first,&equo; admitted Anne gloomily.
&bquo;If only one were going to court freely and looking to a bright future — 't is different for you!&equo;
&bquo;But you are free — free as a bird!&equo; laughed Joan.
&bquo;To hear you talk, anyone would think you were being sent to prison!&equo;
&bquo;And that is exactly it!&equo; complained Anne.
&bquo;Shall not I be chained like a prisoner to a child for the rest of my life?

s.w: I may not so much as glance at all those handsome courtiers!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Prince Richard is but three years your junior,&equo; said Joan cheerfully, refusing to take her complaints seriously.
&bquo;The time will soon pass and then he will be of a suitable age to marry.&equo;
&bquo;But we are married,&equo; pointed out Anne.
&bquo;And I have no wish for time to soon pass, as you express it — were time to pass that quickly, I should very soon be an old old woman.

s.w: Why, by the time Prince Richard is fifteen and considered of an age to really marry, I shall be eighteen.
Have you thought of that, Joan de Warenne?&equo;
Joan had thought of it and could understand Anne's feelings.
But there was no point in admitting as much.

s.c: &bquo;'Tis said the prince is a handsome boy,&equo; she said instead.
&bquo;A handsome boy , as you say,&equo; pouted Anne.
&bquo;But who wishes to find themselves married to a boy?

s.w: I am in my thirteenth summer and dream of a romantic match, of a handsome suitor — not a boy!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Alas that you did not marry Prince Edward!&equo; sighed Joan.
&bquo;He is but a little younger than you and is tall for his age, it is said.&equo;

s.w: Anne looked pensive.

s.c: &bquo;I know — and that is the trouble.

s.w: I was nine at the time of the wedding and you just could not imagine how foolish I felt, dressed as a bride in all her finery, standing beside a six-year-old and with hundreds of people looking on.
said the guests.

hi.w: A fairytale match it is — makes one wish one were young again!

s.w: For all their fine words, I'd wager that not a damsel there would have changed places with me — who would willingly wed a pretty six-year-old!
I should have wed Edward, you say?
That would have been a very different matter.
Edward seemed quite grown up, quiet and interesting — and very good-looking instead of pretty like his baby brother!
I felt a rapport with Edward.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Prince Edward is destined for greater things,&equo; Joan said with a tactlessness rare in her and which she was to regret.
&bquo;He must marry a foreign princess — a French princess, I daresay, to bring greater amity between our peoples.

s.w: Master Peachey has told me of the succession and how important it is to unite nations through contracts of marriage.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Important to whom — to Master Peachey?&equo; demanded Anne, thereby suggesting that she held the opinions of their tutor in contempt. &bquo;'Tis certainly of no importance to myself — and I'd wager 'tis of no importance to Prince Edward either.

s.w: Now —&equo;

s.c: &bquo;You should not say &bquo;I'd wager&equo;!' put in Joan.
&bquo;Master Peachey reprimanded you only this morning for speaking thus — it is unladylike, he said!&equo;
&bquo;— if I were affianced to him,&equo; continued Anne without batting an eyelid, &bquo;instead of —&equo;
&bquo;To him, you say?&equo; enquired Joan mischievously.
&bquo;To Master Peachey, do you mean?&equo;
&bquo;— that cherubic infant,&equo; continued Anne, &bquo; I should dance for joy from here to Westminster!&equo;
&bquo;We cannot have all that we desire in this life,&equo; pointed out Joan in a tone remarkably like that of their confessor, Father Powicke.

s.w: Such might endanger our immortal souls!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Besides —&equo; said Anne who had not been listening, but pursuing her own line of thought &bquo;— if I were affianced to Prince Edward, the marriage could be completed in a year or so — instead of delayed for Heaven knows how long!&equo;
&bquo;Why are you in such a hurry to be really and truly wed?&equo; asked Joan curiously.
&bquo;I confess I am not — most definitely not!&equo;
&bquo;I suppose 't is because I am the elder and have a better knowledge of such things,&equo; Anne replied in a superior tone.
&bquo;Because I am married, you see, mama had my governess explain to me about marriage — of what is expected of one in the marriage bed.&equo;
&bquo;Oh that!&equo; said Joan dismissively.
&bquo;I asked if you also were to be told but mama said nay — you are younger than myself, she said, and are unlikely to wed for some time.

s.w: As I said to mama then, by the time I am bedded, I shall likely be too old — or have forgotten what it is I am supposed to do!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Forgotten?&equo; asked Joan, her tinkling laughter deepening the frown on the other girl's face.
&bquo;You are so droll, Anne.

s.w: Besides, what if you did forget — you would have someone at hand to remind you!&equo;
Anne gave a good imitation of a shudder.

s.c: &bquo;Pray do not remind me — if you only knew!

s.w: But of course you do not know — how could you — and I doubt you could imagine, however hard you tried!&equo;
Having led a far less narrow life than Anne, Joan could imagine only too well.
Little more than a year earlier there had been that never-to-be-forgotten encounter at the inn.
Such encounters, be they lawful or unlawful, in wedlock or out of it, were — in common with the plague — to be avoided at all costs.
Imagine indeed! she thought to herself.
Why, all I want is to forget…

s.c: &bquo;Anyway, Anne, the important thing is to go to court and accustom yourself to its ways,&equo; she said practically.
&bquo;The princes have six sisters, I am told, of ages ranging from sixteen to two years.&equo;
&bquo;They had six sisters,&equo; corrected Anne.
&bquo;Mary, the second from eldest, died only last month.

s.w: I expect they wished to marry her off to an infant — so she simply succumbed!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Well, that leaves five sisters, and I feel sure you will enjoy their company and make many new friends.&equo;

s.w: Anne gave thought to it.

s.c: &bquo;Friends, you say?

s.w: But the princesses will be my sisters-in-law — and I can feel it in my bones that we shall just not take to each other at all!
You are my friend, Joan — my only friend.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;And you are being a bessie-brains today,&equo; laughed Joan, flattered but refusing to take her seriously.
&bquo;Anyway, I am looking forward to going to court — so there!&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Mowbray, accompanied by her daughter and a large entourage, set forth from Framlingham a few weeks later.
Bound for Westminster Palace where she would remain as her daughter's chaperon , the dowager-duchess, though well accustomed in her youth to court life, viewed the summons without enthusiasm.
Since her marriage, she had become accustomed to a less competitive and more rural way of life and therefore regarded her return to court as a duty, an onerous duty.
Her chief adviser since the death of her husband was Sir Thomas Vaughan, now appointed surveyor and demiser of the revenues of the Norfolk inheritance.

Formerly esquire of the body to Henry the Sixth, Vaughan had become treasurer of the chamber to Edward the Fourth, by whom he was so highly regarded that in 1471 he had been appointed chamberlain to the then one-year-old Prince Edward.
Thus Vaughan had a close connection with both the family of the deceased fourth Duke of Norfolk and with Anne Mowbray's young brother-in-law Edward.

He was a strong link between the royal family and the Mowbrays
and, highly regarded by both, was a man of influence and judgement.

Formerly a Yorkist soldier, Vaughan had recently acquired a house for Prince Edward at Stepney; and was joint lessee with the prince of another house he had built within the precincts of Westminster Abbey &bquo;for the pleasure of the king and his consort Elizabeth and their son.&equo;

That he had a thumb in many pies was undeniable: he served as sheriff in both Surrey and Sussex and had been appointed to head a commission examining the revenues of the confiscated estates of George Duke of Clarence, the king's brother.
Clarence, by some curious quirk of fate that again linked the Mowbrays with the royal family, had been arrested on the day following Anne's wedding and subsequently judicially executed.
Vaughan accompanied Elizabeth Mowbray and her daughter to London and, on arrival, smoothed their path ably and tactfully.
Graciously received, first by the king and then the queen — the beautiful and vivacious Elizabeth Woodville — Anne was next presented to her young husband.
Richard Duke of York was not as Anne had recalled him.
Four years had elapsed since that splendid wedding but somehow although she herself had passed from childhood to early womanhood, Anne had still pictured Richard as he had been then.
Richard was tall for his age and personable, with impeccable manners and a strong sense of occasion.
Yet still there was a hint of mischievousness in his eyes as he met Anne's gaze, which gave the lie to his otherwise angelic appearance.
He kissed her hand with practised elegance as she made her curtsy and exchanged pleasantries with her, displaying a savoir-faire rare in one of his years.
Prince Edward too kissed Anne's hand, greeting her courteously as his much-esteemed sister-in-law — but his manner was detached, his expression carefully veiled.
This was one of the few occasions when Joan was unable to accompany her half-sister.

Officially described as the lady Anne's companion, Joan had no place in the royal
reunion and must remain behind in their apartments.

Whilst this was of some concern to Anne, who relied greatly on Joan, it was of no concern to Joan herself: enthralled by everything she saw, by fairytale glimpses of the capital, the palace and the royal family, she viewed everything and everyone with avid interest.
The fact that Anne now relied on her to the extent of being somewhat lost without her, gave Joan a curious but none the less pleasurable sense of power.

How, she asked herself in those early days, has it come about that I, daughter to a humble carpenter and a washerwoman, have become the companion and confidante of her who is close to the throne, who issister-in-law to him who will one day be King of England?
Although she accompanied Anne to most of her subsequent meetings with the royal family, Joan did so as an adjunct, a chaperon , to the elder girl.
She must remain discreetly in the background — in the wings as it were — being ever attentive to Anne's requirements and reputation, and acting with prudence and discretion whensoever the need arose.
Again this troubled Joan less than it did Anne, who wished her friend, as she insisted she was, to share everything.
Joan, though Anne's junior by a year and not yet fully accustomed to the ways of the nobility, was by far the more worldly-wise of the two.
She watched, listened, learned and assessed, speaking only when spoken to in general — whilst all the while making her plans and looking to the future…
Enchanted at first by her good fortune in becoming Anne Mowbray's companion, grateful for the benefits showered upon her, Joan rapidly became accustomed to her new role.
She had a curious feeling that greater good fortune would yet be hers, that she was destined for high places.
She could not have explained it but she no longer even thought of herself as Joan Halidon — but as Joan de Warenne, protégée of the dowager-duchess of Norfolk.

As the months passed and the court moved — and Anne and Joan with it — from Westminster to Greenwich, from Greenwich to Sheen and then back again to Westminster,
and as Joan practised and adopted the ways of the nobility, the close resemblance between herself and Anne became more pronounced.
Each had long hair which flowed in a golden mane down her back; and despite the difference in age, they were of similar height.
Joan perhaps was of a rather sturdier build, her earlier maturity revealed by shapely breasts that rounded the bodice of her gowns to the open envy of Anne.

s.c: &bquo;Anyone would think you were the elder,&equo; Anne complained one day.
&bquo;Why, for pity's sake, am I still flat as a board!&equo;
&bquo;There is plenty of time,&equo; laughed Joan.

s.w: Anne made a face.

s.c: &bquo;Till I am properly married, you mean?

s.w: If I have not achieved a shapely figure by then, I shall become a nun!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;But nuns have shapely figures, I am sure.&equo;
&bquo;How do you know that?&equo; demanded Anne.
&bquo;You cannot see them, after all.&equo;
&bquo;You are right there,&equo; admitted Joan.
&bquo;With those voluminous robes…&equo;
&bquo;You cannot tell,&equo; put in Anne triumphantly.
&bquo;I expect some take the veil simply to hide a flat chest!&equo;
&bquo;What nonsense you do talk!&equo;
&bquo;Oh, 't is all right for you to be superior…&equo;
&bquo;Besides, what does it matter?&equo;

s.w: Joan asked sombrely.
She was reminded of her ravishment and how her lack then of a shapely figure had in no way inhibited the brutal hands of her assailant.

s.c: &bquo;Time will take care of that.&equo;
&bquo;Time!&equo; exclaimed Anne scathingly.

&bquo;Here am I, in my thirteenth summer and wedded to a boy of ten who will be unable to complete the marriage for at least five years — and with no sign of a bosom to show I am truly a damsel full grown!&equo;
&bquo;You must practise patience, my lady!&equo;
&bquo;If only I were married to Prince Edward!&equo; sighed Anne, by no means for the first time.
&bquo;He already seems grown up.&equo;
&bquo;I suppose he does,&equo; said Joan vaguely, herself nurturing a secret fondness for that prince.
&bquo;You do not sound over enthusiastic, I must say,&equo; remarked Anne.
&bquo;Oh well, there is no accounting for tastes!

s.w: Edward is quiet and aloof — one can not tell what he is thinking.
When he looks at me and kisses my hand, I go all shivery — would you believe that!&equo;
Yea, Joan thought, I would believe it — and he has not even kissed my hand!

s.c: &bquo;I believe Edward likes me,&equo; continued Anne.
&bquo;Though needless to say he keeps his thoughts to himself.&equo;
&bquo;Prince Richard likes you.&equo;
&bquo;Naturally he does,&equo; Anne said complacently.
&bquo;Is not he my husband?&equo;
&bquo;Sort of.&equo;

s.w: Joan, have you any idea what is meant by completing a marriage?&equo;
Joan was already in bed and Anne, who had herself ostensibly retired, had come to her chamber to talk to her.
Frequently the girls talked thus into the early hours — and usually in the comparatively small but cosy bedchamber allotted to Joan.
The question was sudden, unexpected, and Joan was not at all sure she wished to reply.

s.c: &bquo;I suppose I have,&equo; she said on a note of reluctance not lost on the elder girl.
&bquo;There is a bedding ceremony and once the bride and bridegroom have been put to bed and everything — but everything — sprinkled with holy water, then the marriage is completed.&equo;

s.w: Anne looked relieved.

s.c: &bquo;Oh, is that all!

s.w: From what my governess told me and the way our elders talk and exchange glances when speaking of completion or bedding , I imagined there must be a sort of initiation ceremony, something absolutely frightful!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Methought you knew all about it,&equo; pointed out Joan.
&bquo;Your governess, you said…&equo;

s.w: Anne sighed.

s.c: &bquo;Well, she did tell me in a way.

s.w: She told me, just as did you a moment ago, about being put to bed and the sprinkling of holy water — but I could still not see what all the fuss was about!
Is there something more, Joan?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;How should I know!&equo;
&bquo;But you do know, do you not?

s.w: You are simply afraid to tell me.&equo;
There was a catch in Anne's voice and she seemed close to tears.

s.c: &bquo;Is it something quite dreadful?&equo;

s.w: Joan was recalling the day, not much more than a year ago, when she had found herself alone in a locked room with the innkeeper.
She remembered the moment when he had locked the door and she had known herself trapped — she could still hear the sound of Rose Trivet crying her heart out in another part of the house.

s.c: &bquo;Dreadful,&equo; she nodded — but her reply had nothing to do with Anne's question.
&bquo;Dreadful.&equo;
&bquo;Like being branded?&equo; persisted Anne.
&bquo;So that ever afterwards you have a mark and can prove you are truly married?&equo;
&bquo;Something like that,&equo; Joan agreed absently.
&bquo;But where do they do it?&equo; enquired Anne nervously.

s.w: But Joan was harking back to that awful day.
Still she could hear her own cries, as she had begged to be released — but nay, he had flung her down on the stone floor and leaned over her.
She had twisted and turned, struggling to free herself to no avail, until a well-aimed kick had won her a temporary respite.
With an obscene oath he had released her.

s.c: &bquo;You little slut!&equo; he had said through clenched teeth, his face ugly with fury — and some other emotion she had not then recognized.
&bquo;You'll pay for that, you trollop!&equo;

s.w: He had turned her over then, his hands brutal, and removing his leather belt, had lashed her unmercifully across buttocks and thighs.
Then, as faint with pain and fear, she had whimpered, begging him to release her, he had turned her on to her back again and leapt on top of her…
When eventually she had arrived back at Briar Cottage, there had been no concealing her distress from Bess Halidon.
Violently used, she could scarcely walk — and without a word, had placed the shilling on the kitchen table.
No explanation had been necessary.
Her mother had bathed her in the tin bath in front of the kitchen fire, had dried her and sat her down before the fire with a bowl of steaming hot broth.

Then had come
the only question Bess Halidon was ever to ask about the incident.

s.c: &bquo;Who was it?&equo;
&bquo;Innkeeper,&equo; had come the almost inaudible reply.
&bquo;You are looking all secretive,&equo; complained Anne at that point, seeing her companion's far-away expression.
&bquo;I believe you know something I do not.&equo;
&bquo;I am sorry, Anne.

s.w: What were you saying?&equo;
Joan looked puzzled.

s.c: &bquo;Something about being branded?&equo;
&bquo;I wondered where they did it.&equo;
&bquo;Where they did it?&equo;

s.w: Joan asked vaguely, still haunted by the dreadful memory.

s.c: &bquo;Why, in the forest — where else than the forest!&equo;
&bquo;Then my bridegroom and I must go to the forest to become really and truly wed?

s.w: Like the babes in the wood, I suppose — though in our case there will be only one babe, since I by then will be an old lady!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Now you are being foolish, lady Anne,&equo; complained Joan, the formal mode of address seeming to better convey her displeasure.
&bquo;You treat the matter lightly — whereas I myself was never more serious.&equo;
&bquo;I too was serious,&equo; insisted Anne in a hurt tone.
&bquo;I wished to discover how it was done — and where.

s.w: And you said it was done in the forest.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;It must have been in the forest —&equo; Joan said dreamily &bquo;— because that is where they found him next day.

s.w: He was not dead, but not far off dead — and 't was said he'd never be the same again.
He grew morose after that and growled at the customers, it seems — so most took themselves to the next village for their ale.
He died a while back, not long before I left Briar Cottage.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I know not what you are talking about, Joan Halidon!&equo; complained Anne, having decided that she was making it all up.
&bquo;De Warenne — if you do not mind, my lady.&equo;
&bquo;Methinks I prefer Halidon ,&equo; observed Anne slowly, seeming to give thought to it.
&bquo;I must admit though that there is sometimes a temptation to call you Joan Harridan!&equo;
&bquo;Horrid child!&equo; said Joan mildly.
&bquo;Call me not so!

s.w:
Just because I have not as yet acquired a
figure…&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Horrid child!&equo;

s.w: Joan said again.
My father was Lord de Warenne, you know — Warenne was one of his earldoms,&equo; Anne said haughtily.

s.c: &bquo;Now it is mine.

s.w: Is not it curious that you have taken the name?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I did so at the duchess your mother's suggestion.&equo;

s.w: Anne gave thought to that.

s.c: &bquo;Joan — dear Joan!&equo; she said then.

s.w: Her mood had changed, it seemed, and she was all lightness and joy.

s.c: &bquo;Would not it be wonderful if we were in truth sisters!&equo;
&bquo;Wonderful indeed!&equo;

s.w: Joan's tone was a little mocking.

s.c: &bquo;A tale from the land of marvels!&equo;
&bquo;Tease all you will but we are alike — everyone says so!

s.w: Mama named you de Warenne — is not it possible that you are in some way connected with the duke my father's family?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Perchance I am a princess in disguise.&equo;
&bquo;Yea, that is it!&equo; exclaimed Anne delightedly.
&bquo;That is the answer.

s.w: Why did not I think of it before?
You are a princess and must therefore marry a prince — you can marry Prince Richard and then I shall marry his brother!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Are not you forgetting something?&equo;
&bquo;How so?&equo;
&bquo;You are married,&equo; Joan pointed out.
&bquo;You are already married — to Prince Richard.

s.w: If I were truly a princess — it would be Prince Edward for me!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;And then I should hate you for ever,&equo; complained Anne.
&bquo;Seriously though, would you, Joan de Warenne, if you could — only if remember — take Prince Edward from me?&equo;
&bquo;What a foolish question!&equo;
&bquo;Answer me, Joan de Warenne — answer me!&equo;
&bquo;Would I take Prince Edward from you, you ask?&equo;

s.w: Joan gave thought to it — gazing pensively and tantalisingly into space.
She was well aware of Anne's tenseness — that this was no casual question and that her reply, at least to Anne, was all-important.

s.c: &bquo;Yea, lady Anne, I rather think I would.&equo;

s.w: Anne watched her for a few moments in stunned silence, trying to decide if she meant what she had said.
Then she burst into tears and rushed from the chamber.

s.c: &bquo;But you did ask, my lady,&equo; Joan said quietly, wonderingly, to the empty room.
&bquo;You did ask.&equo;

s.w: The alarming thing was that what had started as a lively discussion, had somehow gone sour on the two girls.
For Joan, though she had not recognized the fact until that instant when the words crossed her lips, had meant what she said.
And Anne had known she meant it.
Eight
Just prior to Twelfth Night in the January of 1483, Anne went down with a not too serious attack of the prevalent sweating sickness.

Low-spirited, disappointed that she must forgo the festivities which always marked the twelfth day of Christmas, she wept copiously and bewailed her ill-fortune to such an extent that it was feared she would increase the severity of the illness.

s.c: &bquo;You must go in my stead, Joan,&equo; she said, placing a feverish hand on that of her companion.
&bquo;You must go and then you can tell me of it afterwards.

s.w: You shall wear my gown.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;But your gown would not fit me,&equo; said Joan — a mite tactlessly in view of their recent conversation.
&equo; 'Twould be too tight in the bodice.&equo;
&bquo;You are just making excuses,&equo; complained Anne, recognizing Joan's reluctance to gate-crash on royal celebrations.
&bquo;We are of the same height exactly and, if necessary, the bodice could be let out a trifle.&equo;
&bquo;How would I explain the presence of one who is known to the court as Joan de Warenne, the Duchess of York's companion — in other words her servant!&equo;
&bquo;You know quite well you are not a servant,&equo; Anne told her.
&bquo;There is some mystery surrounding your birth — I just know there is! — and one of these days I mean to discover the truth.&equo;
&bquo;You are being fanciful,&equo; Joan said in the manner of one humouring an invalid.
&bquo;Think you I know not who my parents and grandparents were?&equo;
&bquo;You imagine you do.

s.w: Either way, we are so alike, we could be taken for sisters — everyone says so.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Everyone?

s.w: You mean the Archbishop of Canterbury, the Dauphin, the Pope, the Pied Piper of Hamelin…&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Prince Edward says so,&equo; interposed Anne in a cross voice.

s.w: Now Joan, having a fondness for the prince, was both flattered and heartened by this disclosure.
She had assumed that, relegated by protocol to the background at court functions, she was unnoticed by the nobility.
However, she had no intention of revealing her gratification to Anne.

s.c: &bquo;Polite conversation, no more,&equo; she said airily, hoping thus to goad Anne into revealing a little more.
&bquo;I doubt the prince has really noticed me.&equo;
&bquo;You are mistaken there, Joan.
&bquo;Is that your cousin?&equo; the prince asked me.
&bquo;She is so like you that she could be your twin!&equo;&equo;
&bquo;Is that all!&equo; exclaimed Joan ungraciously.
&bquo;Nay, there is more besides,&equo; Anne told her, warming to her theme.

s.w: She recalled that she had at the time been a little put out by the prince's interest in Joan — but now the important thing was to persuade Joan to join in the festivities and bring her a first-hand report.

s.c: &bquo;I explained to the prince that you were my companion and he said — all the while gazing at you across the hall — &bquo;But a relative none the less, I'll warrant!

s.w: Joan de Warenne is a beauty — a real beauty.&equo;
I was a trifle vexed at that and said, &bquo;She is not yet thirteen years of age!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Indeed?&equo; he said.
&bquo;Then we are of like age — how interesting!

s.w: I too am frequently taken to be older than my years.
I would meet the beauteous child — pray contrive to present her to me, lady Anne.&equo;&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Did he truly say that?&equo; asked Joan, unable to conceal her delight.
&bquo;Really and truly?&equo;
&bquo;He did indeed.&equo;
&bquo;How did you answer about the last — about presenting me to him?&equo;
&bquo;Now, let me see…&equo; said Anne tantalisingly.
&bquo;&bquo;Next time I am taking the air in the palace gardens, I shall send word to you,brother-in-law,&equo; I said.
&bquo;Joan de Warenne always accompanies me.&equo;&equo;

s.w: Joan flushed with pleasure but her words were guarded.

s.c: &bquo;I am honoured by the prince's interest — but I doubt not it stems from mere curiosity as to my connection with her for whom he has a brotherly fondness.&equo;
&bquo;Brotherly?&equo;

s.w: Anne looked vexed.

s.c: &bquo;That is as maybe — but my feelings for him are not sisterly, I promise you.

s.w: Far from it.
Alas that today of all days, when there will be opportunity for further converse with him, I am laid low with this horrid malady!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Alas indeed!&equo;
&bquo;I really do feel quite poorly, Joan.&equo;
&bquo;Naturally you do.

s.w: You must lie quiet and stop overtaxing your strength — then you will be better in no time.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I trust you will not take the contagion,&equo; Anne said wearily, lying back pale and wan upon the pillows.
&bquo;Otherwise you too will have to forgo the festivities — and I shall know naught of what goes on!&equo;
&bquo;There is no fear of my taking it,&equo; Joan assured her.
&bquo;I suffered an attack two years before I came here — I shall not take it again, that is certain.

s.w: 'Twas that, mama reckoned, which preserved me from the pestilence!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;And you will go?&equo;
&bquo;Go — go where?&equo; asked Joan, well aware of Anne's meaning.
&bquo;Why, to the Twelfth Night festivities— where else?&equo;
&bquo;Since my lady commands it,&equo; replied Joan with a small mocking curtsy.
&bquo;Could I refuse her bidding?&equo;
&bquo;Yea, if it suited you,&equo; Anne said with truth.
&bquo;Only mama shall know our secret — she has already expressed the intention of concealing the nature of my illness, for fear of arousing alarm.

s.w: Mama will agree, I am sure — you cannot put a foot wrong, it seems, where she is concerned!
I shall have someone alter the dress to fit you.
It is too tight for myself, I shall say — and since I am indisposed, my companion shall fit it on for me!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;There is little time,&equo; said Joan nervously.
&bquo;There is plenty of time — hours and hours in fact in which to change your identity.

s.w: So go now, Joan, and start to make ready.

Dress your hair in the way I intended, put
on my pearl necklace and —&equo; Anne drew off her gold ring and carelessly dropped it on to the coverlet &bquo;— my wedding-ring.
Then, with you wearing my dress and your best smile, none will entertain the notion that you are other than Anne Duchess of York.&equo;
Elizabeth Mowbray, though having reservations about the deception, could in truth see no harm in it.

Masques, revelry and outlandish costumes were part and parcel of Twelfth Night, when the more sombre festivities of Christmas were past and the new year could be celebrated with whole-hearted enthusiasm.
One young lady, disguised as another, would be unlikely therefore to provoke censure even if recognized.
What harm could there be on this night of all nights, thedowager-duchess asked herself, in Joan de Warenne representing her who is in fact her half-sister?
I myself shall be there, since it is clearly expected of me, and thus there will be no need of a chaperon.
And since Joan's taking her place would greatly please Anne…
Joan looked wholly enchanting as she entered the great hall that evening beside the duchess.
She was wearing a pale pink velvet gown trimmed with grey fur, over a cloth-of-silver undergown.
Her hair had been braided and was concealed under a heart-shaped silverhead-dress with a transparent white veil.
Anne's pearl necklace adorned her throat, and her gold ring the third finger of Joan's left hand.
It seemed to Joan that the wedding-ring was burning her finger; it caught the light, glistering brightly as if wishing to draw attention to the fact that it was embellishing an alien hand.
But Joan's smile was all her own — and in no way feigned.
Indeed its brilliance suggested that Anne Duchess of York possessed some new-found and enviable secret.
Court etiquette was now familiar to Joan, since she had watched avidly all that went on during her chaperonage of her young mistress.

But she had qualms about
encountering the royal family, wondering if they would see her, not as Anne Mowbray, but as a stranger.
That, she thought, will be the moment of truth…
Received by the king and queen as she made her entrance, she curtsied deeply, and waited with bated breath for what would happen next.

s.c: &bquo;Ah, our beauteous daughter-in-law!&equo; said the king with his usual bonhomie and turning to the queen.
&bquo;Is not our little bride a sight for sore eyes!&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Woodville, well accustomed to her husband's appreciative eye for a pretty woman, smiled.

s.c: &bquo;You look truly charming, my lady,&equo; she said generously.
&bquo;The prince your husband methinks will be a proud fellow!&equo;

s.w: Next she was greeted by Prince Richard himself.
Wearing tunic and hose of pale blue satin lavishly ornamented with silver, he looked more angelic than ever.
With his blond curls and vivid blue eyes, he was the prototype of a youthful Plantagenet.
He, as well as Anne and Joan herself, was of Plantagenet stock, being a descendant of Edward the Third's son Lionel, through the female line.
Prince Richard smiled and greeted her courteously.

s.c: &bquo;How beautiful you are, my lady,&equo; he said ingenuously before turning mischievously to his brother.
&bquo;The prince my brother can scarce take his eyes off you!&equo;
&bquo;You do me much honour, my lord,&equo; Joan said, overwhelmed by relief that her identity had not been challenged.

s.w: Indeed, she thought, I am beginning to see myself as Anne— beginning to believe I am Anne!
Next it was Prince Edward's turn to greet her.
For just an instant, glancing up from her curtsy, Joan registered a look of puzzlement in the prince's gaze.
But then, as if in that same instant he had solved the puzzle, he spoke.

s.c: &bquo;Greetings, my lady, on this surely most blessed of all Twelfth Nights!&equo; he said quietly.
&bquo;And to you also, my lord,&equo; Joan responded.

s.w:
Richard came forward then to formally ask for her hand in a pavan but, observing that his brother was conversing
with his elected bride and catching the latter's meaningful glance, he cheerfully turned away and asked his sister Cecily instead.

s.c: &bquo;And where is your companion this evening, my lady?&equo; enquired Prince Edward of Joan.
&bquo;My companion?&equo;

s.w: Joan frowned ever so slightly.

s.c: &bquo;Why, she has a slight malady, alas!&equo;
&bquo;The lady Anne, I am told, is given to tantrums.&equo;

s.w: The words were enigmatic and the expression cool — perfectly composed.
It was a test remark, as they were both aware.
Joan's expression was a study.

s.c: &bquo;The lady Anne is —&equo; She paused, floundered and then looked at him uneasily &bquo;— myself.

s.w: You speak of myself, my lord.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I am not deceived, my lady,&equo; came the confident reply.
&bquo;Look not so dismayed, I pray you — or it will be construed that I have made some unwelcome proposal.&equo;
&bquo;But…&equo;
&bquo;Be at peace, my lady.

s.w: I warrant none but myself will have seen through the deception.
I am, after all, something of an expert on the subject!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;What mean you, my lord?&equo;
&bquo;As the lady Anne is aware — and to her chagrin — I have more than once expressed admiration of her companion.

s.w: That she has so kindly obliged me this evening, and on Twelfth Night of all nights causes me no small surprise.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Then since you have seen through the deception, my lord —&equo; Joan saw Elizabeth Mowbray's gaze upon her and lowered her voice still further &bquo;— methinks I should leave forthwith.&equo;
&bquo;Leave?&equo;

s.w: The aggrieved note in the prince's voice prompted several heads to turn in their direction — to Joan's discomfiture.

s.c: &bquo;Nay, that is the last thing I desire.&equo;
&bquo;And the first thing, my lord?&equo; enquired Joan innocently — having lowered her voice now almost to a whisper.

s.w: The first thing?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Ah!&equo;

s.w: Prince Edward's gaze met hers and she flushed delicately.

s.c: &bquo;There is a time and a place for everything, my lady, and this is neither, alas!

s.w: And yet…&equo;

He paused and seemed to be considering his next words
with especial care.

s.c: &bquo;And yet, my lord?&equo; prompted Joan.

s.w: A court equerry appeared at that point at the prince's elbow.

s.c: &bquo;My lord prince,&equo; he said, &bquo;the king your father desires speech with you.&equo;
&bquo;I shall be with His Grace anon,&equo; the prince replied on a small note of displeasure, before again turning to Joan.

s.w: He spoke in a low voice.

s.c: &bquo;Pray present abrother-in-law's felicitations to the lady Anne.

s.w: I trust we shall meet again, you and I — I shall contrive a meeting, a rather more private meeting, as soon as may be.
I trust you would find that agreeable.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;If it be agreeable also to my lady Anne in whose service I am,&equo; Joan replied dutifully.
&bquo;I thank you, my lord, for your courtesy.&equo;
&bquo;My courtesy?&equo;

s.w: The prince looked rueful.

s.c: &bquo;Tell me, my lady — is it mere courtesy that makes the bells ring, that makes moonlight of a sudden more desirable than sunlight and makes one yearn for this Twelfth Night to be of the past?

s.w: Methinks not.
Even at this moment, I see that in your gaze which finds an echo in my own heart!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Your heart?&equo;

s.w: Joan spoke breathlessly, tremulously — like one who sees a childhood tale given substance, a fairytale come of a sudden to life.

s.c: &bquo;My lord, I…&equo;
&bquo;I must away,&equo; Prince Edward put in gently.
&bquo;The king awaits me and will soon be out of patience.

s.w: We shall meet again, Joan de Warenne — and very soon, if I have my way.&equo;
Her cheeks flushed, her heart fluttering, Joan watched as he moved away.
Prince Richard approached then and invited her to dance with him, and she smilingly accepted, feeling like one in a dream.
Prince Richard was struck by her beauty — why, he asked himself, have not I noticed it before?
The lady Anne looks different tonight but 't is a difference I cannot fathom.
Her face seems to glow with happiness as if a vision has of a sudden become reality.
Until then he had thought of her as sulky, even wilful, and had in truth been no more anxious for the match than she.

To him the childhood wedding had been something
of a charade during which each character had played a part, knowing that the coming together at the end — the whole story — was not to be taken seriously.
It had been a game to him, to her — to everybody.

He had played his part, had enjoyed the pomp and the dressing-up, and being with his bride the centre of attention, confident all the while that Fate, his father or the future — the three f's as he called them to himself — would eventually rearrange the matter to everyone's satisfaction.
Richard Duke of York meanwhile was an excellent dancer — as might be expected of a youthful extrovert with severalfun-loving sisters.
In fact, he was a better dancer than his brother — and a worthy partner for a damsel with stars in her eyes.
Joan was aware that her life would never be quite the same again.
She had caught a glimpse of Heaven; had seen adoration and more in the gaze of a handsome prince who would one day be king of England.
Nay, she would never be the same again.
Once before, following another encounter, a brutal and terrifying encounter, she had recognized that.
But that had been a piercing of her body, a searing of her mind — but this encounter had been the captivation of her soul.

Anne made a good recovery from her illness and three weeks later was back in circulation.
Joan had regaled her with details of the Twelfth Night festivities— whilst remaining noticeably reticent on the subject of Prince Edward.
Thus when the prince outlined to Anne his plan for a secret rendezvous with Joan, she had been more than a little piqued.
to play the part this time of chaperon to her own servant?
Such was unthinkable.
But when the prince reminded her — oh, so gently — of the deception practised upon his royal parents on Twelfth Night, Anne realized she had little choice.
She acquiesced, agreeing to his plan for a meeting with Joan in the palace rose-garden.
She had no real objection to the change of roles or to chaperoning her own servant— to her it would be another adventure.
Her disgruntlement arose from the now obvious fact that the prince was enamoured of Joan.

s.c: &bquo;What pains me is that you took the opportunity when I was sick unto death to steal Prince Edward's heart from me,&equo; she said to Joan, having informed her of the plan.
&bquo;That was despicable.&equo;
&bquo;You were not sick unto death,&equo; retorted Joan.
&bquo;And since at no time have you possessed the prince's heart, how could I have stolen it from you?&equo;
&bquo;But you knew how I felt about him,&equo; pouted Anne.
&bquo;How could you act so deceitfully, Joan?&equo;
&bquo;You are a married lady, remember — the prince is your brother-in-law&equo;.

s.w:
Would you expect him, the prince of Wales, to so far flout convention as to seek a liaison with
his brother's lady?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Then you think that whilst he is in truth enamoured of myself, he sees you as second best.&equo;
&bquo;It may be so,&equo; said Joan lightly, more wounded by the suggestion than she would have admitted.
&bquo;Would you have me ask him if that is indeed the case?&equo;
&bquo;You will do no such thing, Joan de Warenne!&equo;

s.w: Anne said hastily.

s.c: &bquo;If you do, I shall never ever speak to you again.&equo;
&bquo;Then you will carry out the prince's design?&equo;
&bquo;Since he himself asked me,&equo; Anne said sullenly, &bquo;how could I refuse?&equo;
&bquo;Easily,&equo; came the uncompromising answer.
&bquo;Had you wished to refuse, you would have done so without a second thought!&equo;

s.w: And so the meeting took place.
It was February and the weather was unseasonably mild.
The morning sky was blue as yet but storm clouds were gathering and the wind seemed on the change.
All three of the participants in that clandestine meeting, looking back a few months later, were to recall the weather on that day as an omen — a mirror of the tempestuous events which followed.
Edward was already there when Joan arrived.
She had left Anne, fur-clad and ostensibly reading a book of hours that Prince Richard had given her, on a stone seat near the entrance to the rose-garden.
He came to meet her, his hands extended in greeting.
His gaze, as it met hers, clearly expressed his pleasure.

s.c: &bquo;Joan,&equo; he said, &bquo; this meeting is at once a joy and a sorrow.&equo;
&bquo;How so, my lord?&equo; she asked.
&bquo;On the morrow I am to leave Westminster — I learned of the fact only this morning.&equo;

s.w: Joan's smile disappeared and her face clouded.

s.c: &bquo;Why so, my lord?&equo; she asked softly, and he heard the catch in her voice.
&bquo;I am bound for Ludlow.&equo;
&bquo;For Ludlow!&equo; repeated Joan who had not before heard of that place.
&bquo;I am Prince of Wales, after all.&equo;
&bquo;Ludlow is in Wales?&equo;

s.w: It is on the Welsh border — and I am to reside there in my principality, pursuing my studies under the tutelage of my uncle Earl Rivers and the guardianship of him who has long been my chamberlain, Sir Thomas Vaughan.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Sir Thomas Vaughan is known to me, being the administrator of the Norfolk estates,&equo; Joan told him.
&equo; 'Twas he escorted the dowager-duchess and my lady Anne to court.&equo;
&bquo;Then he may be useful to us,&equo; Edward said thoughtfully.
&bquo;I dare say he could be persuaded to convey letters from Ludlow to a certain damsel of my acquaintance.&equo;
&bquo;Then this is not farewell, my lord?&equo;
&bquo;A temporary farewell only — I doubt not I shall return to court in the summer, whether it be at Westminster, Eltham or Richmond.

s.w: But enough talk of farewells and reunions — let us speak of the present.&equo;
Joan smiled.

s.c: &bquo;If that be your desire, my lord.&equo;
&bquo;Joan de Warenne, I am deeply enamoured of you.&equo;
&bquo;But you scarcely know me,&equo; she said demurely.
&bquo;I am but companion to the lady Anne.&equo;
&bquo;I have ofttimes wondered about you since you accompanied the lady Anne to court.&equo;
&bquo;Wondered about me, my lord — pray what did you wonder?&equo;
&bquo;I was drawn by the likeness between you.

s.w: I assumed you to be related to the lady Anne.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Alas, my lord, I have no claim to such distinction!&equo;

s.w: Yet the likeness is quite riveting.
Others too have remarked on it — the queen my mother made reference to it only yesternight…&equo;
He paused, not wishing to repeat his mother's words.

s.c: &bquo;Indeed, my lord?&equo; prompted Joan.
&bquo;Joan, time is fleeting and I would tell you what is in my mind,&equo; he said gravely.

&bquo;I am shortly to wed the daughter of the dauphin of France — thus to promote amity between
our two countries.

s.w: Should this be announced during my absence, as is not unlikely, I would you should know it as a marriage of convenience, no more.
I have a deep affection for you, a yearning that will be with me till the day I die.&equo;
Joan shivered.

s.c: &bquo;You, like myself, my lord, are in but your thirteenth year — pray let us not give thought to death!&equo;

s.w: But death comes to us all,&equo; said the prince in surprise.

s.c: &bquo;Why then should one ignore it?&equo;
&bquo;I lost my father and mother and four sisters prior to becoming the lady Anne's companion.

s.w: Thus death has been ever close to me — so close that it seemed to me at times that I could reach out and touch it.
I try therefore to think only of life and youth — I could not speak lightly of death as do you, my lord.&equo;
The prince watched her, held by her expression.
She and Anne were dressed alike in the manner of twins.

Each wore a dark green velvet mantle, close-fastened against the weather with gold cords and tassels, while her unbound hair, entwined at the crown with ropes of pearls, was covered with a transparent white veil.
As they approached, the prince had found it almost impossible to tell the one from the other.

But now, talking to Joan, seeing her changing expressions, he asked himself how it had been so — apart from their dress, it seemed to him then that there was after all no strong likeness between them.
Joan's face at that moment was full of radiance.
A trick of the light perhaps — or the face of love looking upon that of the beloved?

s.c: &bquo;You try , you say, to think only of life and youth,&equo; he said at length, watching her closely.
&bquo;What then of love?&equo;
&bquo;Ah, but I have not tried to think of love,&equo; came the answer.
&bquo;Love is something that just happens, I dare say.&equo;
&bquo;And has it happened?&equo;

s.w: She nodded.

s.c: &bquo;Then your feelings for me are as mine for you?&equo; he asked softly.
&bquo;I fear so.&equo;
&bquo;Fear and love do not mix, it seems to me — one should be happy in one's love,&equo; he said soberly.

s.w:
Joan, hearken to me — I know not what the future holds and I shall, if I may,
elude the bonds of the French marriage — but remember always, I pray you, that you have an especial place in my heart.

I shall contrive to write to you during my absence, to tell you what is in my mind and heart — and when in the summer we meet again, there will be further clandestine meetings, many joyful hours and reunions, I promise you.
Say only that this of which I speak is pleasing to you.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;It is indeed, my lord — with all my heart I say it is.&equo;
&bquo;As a token of my regard for you, I have here a gift…&equo;

s.w: He took from his jerkin a small velvet-wrapped package.

s.c: &bquo;I would have you wear it on a ribbon inside your bodice.&equo;

s.w: Joan undid the package and looked at its contents without speaking for a moment.
The gold ring was exquisitely ornamented with tiny pearls.

s.c: &bquo;Thank you, my lord,&equo; she said, her eyes shining with tears.
&bquo;It is the most beautiful thing I have had in my whole life.&equo;
&bquo;It was given to me by my grandmother, the lady Jacquetta, and has a curious history.

s.w: One day perchance I shall tell you of it.
But wear it, Joan, to remind you of me.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I will,&equo; she said through her tears.
&bquo;Always and for ever.&equo;
&bquo;Now it is time for us to part, alas, alas!

s.w: Nay, be not sorrowful — summer is not many moons away!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;But…&equo;

s.w: He took her hand but this time, instead of the formal kiss, he turned her hand over and kissed the palm, sending little ripples of pleasure coursing through her body.

s.c: &bquo;Farewell, Joan de Warenne,&equo; he said.
&bquo;We shall meet again, never fear.&equo;
&bquo;Farewell, my lord,&equo; she said softly.
&bquo;Go with God.&equo;

s.w: Anne was stamping her feet to keep warm and showing every sign of impatience when Joan joined her.

s.c: &bquo;I am stiff with cold,&equo; she complained.
&bquo;You have been simply ages!&equo;

s.w: Joan had turned round to take a last look at the prince.
But the garden was deserted and already he had disappeared from view.

s.c: &bquo;I expect I shall die of exposure,&equo; went on Anne, piqued by Joan's lack of concern.
&bquo;I am warm as toast,&equo; Joan said unsympathetically.
&bquo;I am sorry I kept you waiting, lady Anne — the prince is going away, you see.&equo;
&bquo;So that is the end of that!&equo;
&bquo;Nay, on the contrary — it is but the beginning methinks.&equo;

s.w: Joan spoke more from defiance than conviction.

s.c: &bquo;Out of sight, out of mind, is the practice with youths of his age,&equo; said the voice of experience.
&bquo;I know not why he troubled — keeping us both standing about catching our death of cold!&equo;
&bquo;He gave me this,&equo; Joan told her, holding out the ring for inspection.
&bquo;Holy Mary!

s.w: I expect he robbed the crown jewels!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;He said it belonged to his grandmother — his maternal grandmother.&equo;
&bquo;Not Jacquetta?&equo; asked Anne, stopping in her tracks in apparent shock.
&bquo;Surely not Jacquetta?&equo;
&bquo;So he said.&equo;
&bquo;Better have a care then!

s.w: Jacquetta, the queen's mother, is said to be a witch.
They say she procured her daughter's marriage to the king by sorcery and has committed all manner of other crimes.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Must you tease so?&equo; asked Joan, not believing a word of it.
&bquo;Must you spoil everything?&equo;
&bquo;Oh, come on, Joan — let us make haste,&equo; said Anne crossly.
&bquo;I am frozen half to death — and all for a servant, if you please!

s.w: Mama would have a fit if she knew.&equo;
The prince and I have a close affection one for the other.
Now he must go away and I dare say I shall never see him again,&equo; Joan said woefully, lagging behind despite Anne's grumbles and gazing down at the ring.

s.c: &bquo;This is all I shall have to remember him by — you are cruel to treat it with such levity.&equo;

s.w: Anne, who was heart-free despite her sometimes extravagant claims, was surprised to see tears coursing down Joan's face.
Her heart touched on the instant by her friend's distress, she put an arm through hers and led her back to the palace.

s.c: &equo; 'Twill be all right, Joan,&equo; she assured her.
&bquo;I was but teasing — I meant no harm.

s.w: Take heart!
The prince will not forget you — I just know he will not.
You will be together again before very long — and then who knows!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Oh, Anne, do you really think so?&equo; asked Joan wistfully.
&bquo;If only I could be certain of that.&equo;

s.w: Anne looked at her, surprised at her depth of feeling.
She loved her dearly — as a sister, the best of sisters.
Her teasing was harmless for the most part, light-hearted and without malice.

s.c: &bquo;Then simply take my word for it,&equo; she said consolingly.
&bquo;You will see your prince again and be very close — I feel it in my bones!&equo;

s.w: Despite outward appearances and her protected upbringing, it seemed after all as if Anne were the more worldly-wise of the two — or even the three of them.
She believed what she had said and yet those last words had a curious prophetic ring — as if somewhere in those uncharted seas which man calls Time, they were echoing and re-echoing into the future.
But this is not real, she thought.
The reality was long ago — oh so long ago!
Still there is that curious ringing in my ears, a noise as of metal spades on lead — unhappy sounds which seem to shake my very bones…

The sounds were plaintive, resonant, doom-laden as those of a passing-bell, and she recognized even then — though she could not have found words to express it — that it would turn out thus, just as she had said.
Joan would indeed see her prince again and be very close — and she herself had, as she said, felt it in her bones, God help them all!
Surreptitiously, her hand hidden within the furry confines of her muff, Anne made the sign of the cross.

Joan received in all three letters from Prince Edward over the next weeks, cheerful letters telling her of his new abode and his favourable impressions of the Welsh Marches and its people.
He told her he missed her and his family, and that the prince his brother would shortly be paying him a visit.
He signed each letter simply as &bquo; Your own Edward.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;There are times,&equo; he said in the first letter,&bquo;that I wish myself not a prince, but a simple fellow.

s.w: As a prince, you understand, one does not enjoy freedom in the sense that one of more humble origin may enjoy freedom.
Sir Thomas Vaughan has consented, albeit reluctantly, to convey my letters under cover of official letters to the dowager-duchess regarding the Norfolk estate.
I know not how long he will do so.

s.c: &bquo;Felicitations from him who must worship you from afar and longs to have you for his own.&equo;

s.w: One week after the third letter arrived, Elizabeth Mowbray summoned Joan to her library.
Her expression was stern, a mite displeased.

Joan,&equo; she said without preamble, &bquo;I have today received a letter from Sir Thomas Vaughan which pertains, not to his Norfolk administrative undertakings, but to his duty in respect of Edward Prince of Wales.&equo;
Joan said nothing, fearful of what she was about to hear.

s.c: &bquo;I was aware needless to say that the prince had become infatuated with you.

s.w:
Both Sir Thomas and I assumed that distance and the fickleness of youth would take care of the
matter,&equo; continued Elizabeth Mowbray.

s.c: &bquo;Sir Thomas insisted on reading the prince's letters as a condition of his acting as go-between, and saw naught in them save the boyish fondness of a lad in his thirteenth year for a lass of similar age.

s.w: The prince, it seems, had not hitherto shown a particular interest in a damsel and Sir Thomas was therefore convinced that the attachment between yourself and the prince was simply a romantic interlude.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Yea, my lady,&equo; Joan said in a small voice, still fearful of what was to follow.
&bquo;I understand.&equo;
&bquo;I trust you do, Joan — I trust you do!&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Mowbray said with a sigh.

s.c: &bquo;For now, it seems, the prince has revealed to Sir Thomas the depth of his regard for you — even going so far as to say that if in due course he may not marry yourself, he will remain unwed.

s.w: Sir Thomas remonstrated with him, as was his duty, reminding him of his high calling and how he will be required, in accordance with royal custom, to make a match advantageous to the realm — that is to say with a foreign princess.&equo;
Joan felt a trifle faint and was grateful for the fact that she was sitting down.
But her hands were trembling uncontrollably, giving away to the duchess the measure of her anxiety.

s.c: &bquo;And how did the prince make answer, my lady?&equo; she asked.
&bquo;He refused to hearken to Sir Thomas's words of wisdom, disdaining to discuss the matter further.

s.w: As a result, Sir Thomas has resolved that he can no longer act as go-between in respect of the prince's letters to yourself.&equo;
Elizabeth Mowbray gave a deep sigh as if the words that were to follow were unpleasing to her.

s.c: &bquo;He further informed the prince that, should he find evidence of a continuing liaison between himself and yourself, he would consider it his duty to at once have recourse to the king his father.&equo;
&bquo;I understand, my lady,&equo; Joan said again, her heart feeling like lead.
&bquo;Joan, you are a lass of intelligence,&equo; said Elizabeth Mowbray.
&bquo;You must surely have realized therefore that there could be no future in this attachment.

s.w:
Lose not your
heart to the prince, child — he will wreak havoc with many a feminine heart, I doubt not, ere he reaches his majority.
He must marry when and where the king his father dictates…&equo;
She paused as if turning over in her mind her next words before giving them substance.

s.c: &bquo;…

s.w: One cannot overlook the fact that you yourself are not of the nobility — let alone of royal blood!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Nay, my lady, I am but the offspring of a carpenter and a washerwoman,&equo; Joan said bitterly, close to tears.
&bquo;I recognize that there can be no future for us together and yet I know a great fondness for the prince — a fondness that time, I suspect, will not lessen.&equo;
&bquo;Dear child!&equo; smiled Elizabeth Mowbray.
&bquo;There speaks the voice of youth!

s.w: I warrant you will in a twelve-month have forgotten about the prince, and be head-over-heels in love with another — one more suitable, please God!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;With a carpenter perchance?&equo;

s.w: Joan asked resentfully.

s.c: &bquo;Or an innkeeper maybe?&equo;
&bquo;Why say you an innkeeper?&equo; asked Elizabeth Mowbray curiously.
&bquo;For the same reason as I say a carpenter, I dare say!&equo; shrugged Joan.
&bquo;After all…&equo;
&bquo;You said a carpenter, one must suppose, because you believe yourself the daughter of a carpenter,&equo; interposed Elizabeth Mowbray firmly.
&bquo;And that brings me to a further reason for my summoning you here today.

s.w: The one, I trust, will help to ease your pain over the other.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;If by the other, my lady, you refer to the regard the prince and I have for each other, pray be assured it is not pain I feel — but joy, deep joy.

s.w: Our fondness each for the other is pure and innocent, a union of two happy souls — it could be that a way will be found for us.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Joan, hearken to me.&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Mowbray was baffled by the girl's refusal to see the matter in its true light and more than a little troubled by what she was beginning to see as something other than a passing infatuation.

s.c: &bquo;You are not, as you believe, the offspring of Will Halidon — but of my late husband John Mowbray, fourth Duke of Norfolk.&equo;

s.w:
Joan's face paled and she gazed wide-eyed at the
duchess, as if suspecting that lady had taken leave of her senses.

s.c: &bquo;Nay, it cannot be,&equo; she breathed.
&bquo;Bess Halidon, your mother, gave me proof of it when she came here on the day prior to her death and asked that you be found employment.&equo;

s.w: Then mama was not married to papa?

s.c: &bquo;She was wife to Will Halidon —&equo; said Elizabeth Mowbray succinctly &bquo;— not to your father.&equo;
&bquo;Then mama was a…&equo;
&bquo;Hearken to me,&equo; hastily interposed Elizabeth Mowbray.
&bquo;Your mother perchance felt for your father, much as you now feel for Prince Edward.

s.w: Think well on that, Joan de Warenne, ere you make harsh judgements!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Then you are not angry about — about the duke?&equo;
&bquo;Persons in my position customarily wed, not according to their own choosing — but in accordance with the wishes or indeed the ambitions of their elders.

s.w: Sometimes there is love— indeed I loved my lord dearly.
Such is rare.
Should I then, blessed with love in an arranged marriage, be angered by another's brief joy!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;You are sure about this, my lady — that I am daughter to the duke your husband?&equo;
&bquo;There can be no doubt.

s.w: I spoke of the matter to Sir Thomas Vaughan, he being of like age to my lord and a close friend from boyhood,&equo; Elizabeth Mowbray told her.

s.c: &bquo;Sir Thomas admitted — though with no small reluctance — that he had been aware of a liaison 'twixt my lord and Bess Halidon.

s.w: Your mother, he gave me to understand, came from a respectable if impecunious family.
Your grandfather, it seems, was a Yorkist partisan, like Sir Thomas himself — after he was slain in battle, the family fell on hard times.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Mama never spoke of her family, insisting that she had been born an orphan,&equo; Joan said, still unable to fully comprehend that she was not whom she had thought she was.
&equo; 'Tis hard to imagine that she and the duke…&equo;
&bquo;My lord's family is ambitious,&equo; put in Elizabeth Mowbray, seeing Joan's hesitation.
&bquo;I was considered a suitable bride and — well, that was that!

s.w:
My lord purchased
Briar Cottage for his lady-love and offered a generous allowance for your maintenance — but your mother refused the latter.
She wed Will Halidon soon after.
He was many years her senior, as you will be aware — I doubt not you know the rest.&equo;
There was silence in the library for several moments, whilst Joan digested the astonishing facts.
Elizabeth Mowbray watched her changing expressions, seeing the steadiness of her gaze as she gave thought to the revelation and its implications, the high smooth brow and long-fingered white hands.
By my faith, she thought with an inexplicable mixture of joy and resentment, she at this moment even more than the other closely resembles my dead lord!
Why then is she too not mine?
Were she so, perchance there would be a hope — faint but none the less reasonable — that she and the prince could in the fullness of time marry…

s.c: &bquo;Thank you for telling me, my lady,&equo; Joan said.
&bquo;I expect that was why you agreed to have me here when mama came to you.&equo;
&bquo;Not entirely.&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Mowbray smiled.

s.c: &bquo;The lady Anne needed a companion — and who better than her half-sister?

s.w: It would please me, Joan, when the time comes and my daughter's marriage to Prince Richard is completed, to find you a suitable husband.

With your permission, I shall let it be known that you are in fact my lord's bastard — bastardy, whilst it precludes a royal marriage, is no impediment to a good match, more especially when the bride possesses a sizeable dowry.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;A dowry, my lady?

s.w: But I have no dowry.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;That could easily be remedied,&equo; Elizabeth Mowbray assured her.
&bquo;In fact it shall be so very shortly— my lord would have wished it so!&equo;
&bquo;You are very good to me, my lady,&equo; Joan said with sincerity.
&bquo;I know not how I may repay you.&equo;
&bquo;I hold you in some affection, child,&equo; came the reply.
&bquo;That is why I ask you here and now to give serious thought to ending your innocent liaison with Prince Edward.

s.w: No lasting good could come of it and I fear to see you hurt.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;My lady, the prince and I share a great fondness…&equo;
&bquo;Think on it, Joan,&equo; firmly interposed Elizabeth Mowbray.
&bquo;Give thought to it, is all I ask.

s.w: Sir Thomas will no longer be acting as go-between in the matter of correspondence, but the prince might well contrive some other means of communicating with you.
Either way, he will be returning to Westminster at the end of May, I am told.
Avoid his advances, is my advice to you, child.
Keep him at a distance — for your own sake.&equo;

King Edward died unexpectedly at Westminster Palace on the ninth day of April.
In his forty-second year at the time of his death, his latter years had been passed in luxury and rich living.
Prior to his death, he had been planning a full-scale war with Scotland, calling upon his subjects to raise the revenues for the undertaking.

In the midst of these preparations — Richard Duke of Gloucester, his brother, having already taken Berwick and occupied the fortress — the king had been seized with a virulent fever to which he had quickly succumbed.

So sudden had been his demise that, very soon afterwards, prior to robing, in order to avert any suspicion as to its cause, his body, with face, arms and chest uncovered, was laid out on a board for nine hours.
All the nobility, together with the lord mayor and aldermen of the City of London, were sent for, that they might identify the body and declare that the king was truly dead.
Anne had learned of the change in the royal fortunes from her mother.

Occupying their own apartments at the palace and giving little heed to the prevailing rumour that the king was unwell, neither she nor Joan was prepared for the tidings they received on that April afternoon.
But that cannot be, mama, Anne protested as if the duchess had somehow been misinformed.
