s.c: &bquo;It just can not be.

s.w: Why, only yesterday the king was speaking with me, calling me his little daughter-in-law and patting my hand as was his wont.
He is neither ill nor old — not very old, that is.
You are surely mistaken.&equo;

s.c:
&bquo;Believe me, daughter, I am not mistaken — I would it
were so!&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Mowbray was very much on her mettle.

s.c: &bquo;Maybe 'tis a jest,&equo; persisted Anne, as if willing her mother to change her story.
&bquo;Yea, that is the answer — a jest in very poor taste.&equo;
&bquo;Do I look as if I am jesting?&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Mowbray's face was pale and tense, her sorrowful mien reflecting the newly sombre mood of the court.

s.c: &bquo;Would I jest about such a disaster!&equo;
&bquo;A disaster, you say?

s.w: Then it is true?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;May he rest in peace!&equo; said Joan piously, crossing herself and frowning at Anne to do likewise.
&bquo;His Grace will be sorely missed, alas!&equo;
&bquo;He will so —&equo; agreed Anne gloomily, adding since it was clearly expected of her &bquo;— God rest his soul.&equo;
&bquo;Anne, I suggest that…&equo;
&bquo;Mama, this means that Prince Edward will now be king — and Richard, my Richard, will be Prince of Wales!&equo;

s.w: The duchess registered the sudden brightening of her daughter's expression and the my Richard with some exasperation— but it was Joan's face that caught her attention.

s.c: &bquo;What is it, child?&equo; she asked with concern.
&bquo;What ails you?&equo;
&bquo;Edward is king now,&equo; Joan said in distress.
&bquo;Already.

s.w: Ere he has even returned from Ludlow.
Nay, it must not be…&equo;
And before anyone could reply, she had dissolved into tears and rushed from the chamber.

s.c: &bquo;Alas, poor Joan!&equo; sighed Anne.
&bquo;I expect she realizes now that Prince Edward is lost to her for ever!&equo;
&bquo;Poor Joan, you say?&equo; exclaimed Elizabeth Mowbray disapprovingly.

s.w: What of Queen Elizabeth and her daughters— and of Prince Edward most of all!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Most of all?

s.w: Because he will be king, do you mean, mama?&equo; asked Anne.

s.c: &bquo;Already he is king, my daughter.&equo;

s.w: Anne looked at her, trying to take in the fact.

s.c: &bquo;The king is dead — long live the king!&equo; she said.
&bquo;That surely means that Edward will have to be married right away to a foreign princess — someone old and ugly whom he hates, I doubt not, instead of the one he loves.&equo;
&bquo;To whom do you refer, child?&equo;
&bquo;Why, Joan — whom else?&equo; asked Anne — as of a child.
&bquo;She talks of little else and makes me quite vexed with her at times.

s.w: I wish I had shown more patience.
Alas, poor Joan!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;What of the prince himself?&equo; asked Elizabeth Mowbray, curious to know her daughter's views on the subject.
&bquo;Think you his regard for her is genuine?&equo;
&bquo;Oh, he positively adores her, mama — he is quite enchanted with her.

s.w: You see, I was with her when they met one day in the rose-garden and I watched their faces as they talked together.&equo;
Anne sighed.

s.c: &bquo;Oh, mama, 'twas so romantic their meeting like that— and now it must all come to naught!&equo;
&bquo;He being who he is, and she who she is, it was a foregone conclusion that it would come to naught,&equo; said the duchess practically.
&bquo;There was no future in the attachment — surely even you, my frivolous daughter, could see that!&equo;
&bquo;What will happen now, mama?&equo;
&bquo;The queen attended a meeting of the Privy Council soon after her lord's death was announced.

s.w: She proposed that the new king and his brother, who was on a brief visit to Ludlow, should be escorted to London by a substantial body of troops.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Why a substantial body of troops?&equo;
&bquo;Desolated by the sudden loss of her husband, the queen feels anxious and vulnerable, I doubt not,&equo; replied the duchess with feeling.
&bquo;She would naturally be concerned for the safe-keeping of her sons.&equo;
&bquo;But why a substantial body of troops,&equo; persisted Anne.
&bquo;Is there to be a war?&equo;
&bquo;I trust not,&equo; came the answer.
&bquo;As a mother, I am keenly aware of the queen's fears for her elder son at this time.

s.w: Alas that the Prince of Wales has not yet attained his majority!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Mama, I must go to Joan and cheer her up,&equo; Anne said at that.
&bquo;Perchance the outlook is not as bleak as she imagines.

s.w: As I shall say to her, it might all be for the best— now that he is king, I expect Edward will decide for himself whom to marry.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;You will say no such thing, my daughter,&equo; said Elizabeth Mowbray sternly.

&bquo;To encourage Joan's hopes now would
be cruel in the extreme.

s.w: I utterly forbid it.
Disobey me in this and I shall pack you off to Framlingham and send Joan elsewhere — more quickly than you could say wedding-bells!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Mama, you would not — surely you would not!&equo;
&bquo;Edward is king,&equo; the duchess told her uncompromisingly.

&bquo;To think of him in any other role, to plot and connive for his affections — even to think of his putting his own desires and inclinations before his duty to God and the realm, is treason of the highest order.

s.w: I require your assurance that you will not meddle.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;You have it, mama,&equo; Anne responded meekly.
&bquo;And mama?&equo;
&bquo;What is it, daughter?&equo; asked Elizabeth Mowbray warily.
&bquo;Now that Edward is king, I suppose I shall very soon be Princess of Wales — is that not so?&equo;
&bquo;The honour is customarily reserved for the wife of the king's eldest son,&equo; observed the dowager-duchess.
&bquo;I therefore suggest we wait and see as to that.&equo;
&bquo;But the king is not yet married, let alone having a son,&equo; objected Anne — but then her face brightened.
&bquo;My prince meanwhile is heir presumptive, is he not?

s.w: Should aught happen to Edward — as God forbid — I would be queen of England!&equo;
Again the my prince, thought Elizabeth Mowbray wearily.
So the marriage is no longer anathema to my daughter!
Ah me!
I would that Anne displayed the maturity of her half-sister — sometimes she is like a child of eight instead of a damsel of fourteen!
Joan is the younger by a year but, being of similar height and appearance, the girls are as twins.
Joan seems the more mature, perhaps due to her austere childhood.
Truth to tell, it is not difficult to see why Edward is enamoured of her…
Joan was lying on her bed, her face tear-stained, when Anne entered her chamber.
No longer weeping, she was in déshabillé and, Anne noticed, was wearing the prince's ring on the third finger of her left hand.

s.c: &bquo;Joan, it will all turn out for the best — I know it will,&equo; Anne assured her, seating herself on the edge of the bed.
&bquo;There are more fish in the sea than ever came out of it, as my nurse used to say!&equo;
&bquo;You understand not how I feel — how could you!&equo;

s.w: Joan said, without removing her gaze from the ring.

s.c: &bquo;You see, I was so looking forward to the prince's return from Ludlow.&equo;
&bquo;But as it is, he is returning sooner — not later,&equo; pointed out Anne.
&bquo;That is surely something for which to be thankful.&equo;
&bquo;Since I am not to see him or speak with him alone ever again, in truth it matters little where he is.&equo;
&bquo;Oh, he will think of something,&equo; Anne assured her, with a confidence of which her mother would not have approved.
&bquo;Edward will think of something.

s.w: Lovers always do.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;He is not my lover,&equo; protested Joan.
&bquo;And never will be, alas, alas!

s.w: I hoped that when he returned in May…&equo;
She fell silent, leaving the sentence uncompleted and Anne looked curiously at her.

s.c: &bquo;You would not have, would you?&equo; asked Anne.
&bquo;Why, that would be dreadfully wicked!&equo;
&bquo;Not when you love someone.&equo;
&bquo;Why would you, Joan?

s.w: Never would I wish to do whatever it is they do — nobody would!
One does it when one is married out of a sense of duty, as Father Powicke and my governess informed me.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;And what do they know about it?&equo;

s.w: Joan asked scathingly.

s.c: &bquo;He is a celibate priest and she is a spinster.&equo;
&bquo;Mama's neither a celibate priest nor a spinster — I shall ask her about it.&equo;
&bquo;I expect your mother wishes you to remain unenlightened, since you must wait another four years for your bedding!&equo;
&bquo;Joan, how is it that you know— about things like that?&equo;

s.w: Anne asked interestedly.

s.c: &equo; 'Tis hard to say,&equo; said Joan with truth.
&bquo;I suppose it is just that I have led a more open life than you.

s.w: Sometimes, of course, it is quite awful!&equo;
Anne heard her voice go heavy on the last word, as if it came from deep within her, influenced by some deep-felt experience.

s.c: &bquo;Why so?&equo; she asked.
&bquo;Why is it awful?&equo;
&bquo;If you hate someone.&equo;
&bquo;Surely none would marry someone they actually hated.

s.w: After all, I do not actually hate my Richard.
He has become more presentable of late — not quite the infant he was!
All the same, he is still the queen's &bquo;sweet babe&equo;!'

s.c: &bquo;She calls him her angel — so you should be all right!&equo;

s.w: Joan said gloomily.

s.c: &bquo;Why do you say that?&equo;
&bquo;You could not go far wrong being bedded by an angel!&equo;

s.w: Anne gave thought to it.
Then she smiled.

s.c: &bquo;Perchance Richard will be less of an angel by then — either way, I expect I shall manage,&equo; she said, determined to look on the bright side.
&bquo;After all, until Edward marries and has an heir — as he will now have to do forthwith — Richard will remain heir presumptive.

s.w: And if as heir presumptive, he happens to be an angel as well— why should his bride complain!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Oh, go away!&equo; cried Joan.
&bquo;Go away!

s.w: You understand not — how could you?
I dare say you never will.
Go and play with your dolls!&equo;
Twelve
Events moved swiftly following the death of King Edward.
So quickly that the commonalty experienced difficulty in keeping up with them and the nobility wondered where disaster would strike next in the realm.
At first it seemed that the Woodvilles, the members of the queen's ambitious and much-disliked family, held the vantage points.

Sir Edward Woodville, the queen's brother, was Admiral of the Fleet; and the Marquis of Dorset, the queen's elder son by her first marriage, was Constable of the Tower of London which housed the deceased king's treasure and the vast store of armaments held ready for an invasion of France.
It had long been believed that he who held the Tower, held London in the palm of his hand.
Richard Duke of Gloucester, the late king's soldierly youngest brother, was at his castle of Middleham in Yorkshire when he received news of Edward the Fourth's death.

Nominated by his dying brother as Lord High Protector of the realm during the boy king's minority, he had just returned from Scotland where, at the head of a powerful army, he had re-taken Berwick in his brother's name and thus nullified the Scottish King's threat of a full-scale invasion.
Richard of Gloucester acted swiftly.
He set forth at once for Northampton with a mere three hundred men, leaving Sir Richard Ratcliffe, his knight of the body, at York to raise more troops and follow him south with the reinforcements.

He next dismissed his nephew's two-thousand-strong Welsh escort and, having assured the bewildered youth of his affection and loyalty, set out with
him for London.
Edward the Fifth, as the prince was now, was as confused as his subjects by the rapid turn of events.
No sooner had he received the sorrowful news of his father's death, than he found himself surrounded by confusion, suspicion and intrigue.
Why, he asked himself, had his uncle, Earl Rivers, been placed under arrest?
And for what reason had Sir Thomas Vaughan, his chamberlain, a man he trusted and respected above most, been marched away and imprisoned like a common thief?
He was glad that Richard his brother was still with him — that he had not returned to the capital ere the calamitous news had arrived.
Richard, he could see, was as puzzled as himself.
They exchanged meaningful glances from time to time — and it was apparent that his brother was as troubled as he by the disturbing events.
Both princes drew strength from their uncle's quiet confidence.
Riding beside them, he explained that time was of the essence if their father's instructions in respect of the protectorship were to be carried out.
The commonalty, he told them, was on their side — any attempt to block the protectorship would but increase its already substantial resentment of the Woodvilles.

s.c: &bquo;But what of my chamberlain, sir?&equo; asked Edward.
&bquo;He presents no threat to the protectorship!&equo;

&bquo;Once the truth becomes apparent, nephew,&equo; explained Richard of Gloucester, and I judge there to be no further danger of a rising to place another on the throne or appoint another as Lord Protector, Vaughan and Rivers shall be released — and no harm done.&equo;

s.w: It sounded logical enough, yet Edward had an uncanny sense of foreboding.
He yearned to reach London, was no less anxious than his uncle and his brother to reach the capital — and yet he had the curious feeling that time was not on his side.
He longed to be reunited with his bereaved family.
His mother and her advisers would allay his fears, he told himself.

He and his family would retire for a while from public gaze, so that they could privately give vent to their grief at the loss of that larger-than-life figure who
had seemed immortal…
Latterly, as the miles between themselves and the capital had lessened, Prince Richard had fallen uncustomarily silent.
During the first part of the journey, he had chattered incessantly, excited by all that he saw, his spirits elated.
But such a journey taken at speed was arduous in the extreme, something of an endurance test for an eleven-year-old.

s.c: &bquo;Poor Uncle Rivers!&equo;

s.w: Edward had remarked to him at one stage.

s.c: &bquo;God grant he will soon regain his freedom — I know not which way to turn without him and Vaughan to advise me.&equo;

s.w: His brother made no reply, seeming half asleep in his saddle and lagging behind.
Edward drew rein and waited for him to catch up — their uncle having ridden back along the line to urge the stragglers to greater effort.

s.c: &bquo;I have heard much talk,&equo; Edward told his brother in a low tone.
&bquo;They speak ill of our parents&equo; marriage — how then should I answer them?&equo;
&bquo;My lord of Gloucester says we shall reach London by the morrow,&equo; Richard reminded him.
&bquo;Mama will know how to answer the lies and accusations — she will tell you what to say.

s.w: I doubt not she will command the release of Uncle Rivers and Sir Thomas Vaughan!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;You are right, my brother,&equo; Edward replied, more heartened than he would have admitted by the prince's words.
&bquo;Am not I King of England?

s.w: I must stand firm before my lord of Gloucester — on the morrow, I shall myself command the release of my most loyal advisers.&equo;

A few miles further on, the eleven-year-old fell asleep in his saddle and Gloucester, unwilling to call a halt at that stage and thus delay their entry into London, insisted that he be conveyed the rest of the way in a horse-drawn litter.
Thenceforth Edward rode with his uncle beside him.
Whilst he missed his brother's company, he welcomed the opportunity for being alone with his thoughts.

Gloucester, never one for words, spoke little for the remainder of the
journey, his mind and energies set on reaching London in time.
The royal cavalcade entered London in early May and received a tumultuous welcome from its citizens.
I told Joan de Warenne I would return in May, Edward thought — I little knew then that such calamity and change of fortune would summon me hither!
Joan de Warenne?
Nay, I must not dwell on that now— I must put her from my mind.
It is past before it has scarce begun.
I am older now — I most certainly feel older, weighed down methinks by sorrow and care.
I am King of England and henceforth must dedicate my life to my kingdom…
But it seemed that the longed-for reunion with his family was not to take place.
It soon became apparent to Edward that they were not en route for Westminster.

s.c: &bquo;Whither are we bound, my lord?&equo; he asked Richard of Gloucester.
&bquo;Ely Palace, nephew.&equo;
&bquo;Why Ely Palace rather than Westminster?&equo;
&bquo;Opposing factions are at work, alas, and I fear an uprising,&equo; came the daunting reply.
&bquo;You, my lord, could well be in grave danger.&equo;
&bquo;I desire first to go to the palace of Westminster, my lord, there to greet the queen my mother and tender my condolences — and to share the grief of my family.&equo;
&bquo;Alas that it cannot be, nephew!&equo;

s.w: Edward looked at his uncle in alarm.

s.c: &bquo;Has ill befallen other members of my family also?&equo; he asked.
&bquo;Also, you say?&equo;
&bquo;I but refer to Earl Rivers, my uncle — not forgetting Sir Thomas Vaughan, my chamberlain.

s.w: The latter has been my guardian and close confidant from infancy — he would not fail me now!&equo;
Richard of Gloucester sighed.

s.c: &bquo;Have patience, nephew, I pray you.

s.w: You are weary, I am weary and the horses are weary.
Let us leave such vexatious matters for the time being.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Should you be referring to Vaughan, good uncle, I assure you that he is no vexatious matter,&equo; Edward said hotly.
&bquo;Indeed, I would feel a deal more at ease, were that worthy gentleman by my side now.&equo;

s.w: Richard of Gloucester gave another sigh and set his gaze on the narrow road ahead.

s.c: &bquo;I had hoped to keep the information from you, at least till the morrow,&equo; he said.
&bquo;But it seems it is not to be, alas!

s.w: The queen-dowager, your mother, having learned of the protector's decision to place Rivers and Vaughan under arrest — news travels fast, it seems, when the Woodvilles are on the warpath — went into sanctuary at Westminster, together with her family.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;But surely, my lord, there must be some mistake.&equo;
&bquo;Since your family has fled the palace,&equo; Richard of Gloucester continued evenly, &bquo;I deemed it wise to install Your Grace elsewhere.

s.w: The prince your brother however, being yet of tender years, will join the queen-dowager and her daughters forthwith.&equo;
Edward made no reply.
His heart was beating agitatedly, as if sharing his sense of foreboding.
He had longed to be reunited with his family from the moment he had learned of his father's demise — but only now did he recognize the depth of his longing.
As it was, he must conceal his sorrow, his grief, his terrifying sense of aloneness…
Is it as my uncle says? he wondered.
Are mama and my sisters truly in sanctuary — or could it be that some grave misfortune has overtaken them also?
Nay, I must not think thus!
Richard of Gloucester has a difficult task — an unenviable task, some might say.
He has acted thus from the soundest of motives, being determined to ensure the safety of his sovereign and nephew— his brother's son.
Papa ever held Uncle Richard in high esteem — entrusting the protection of the realm to him, having him lead his armies in times of war.
That is why he appointed him Lord High Protector — he knew and trusted him implicitly.
Why then should I, who lack papa's experience of men and statecraft, question Uncle Richard's judgement now?

s.c: &bquo;When will the prince my brother be joining the others in sanctuary?&equo; he asked.
&bquo;Take a look behind, nephew,&equo; came the answer, &bquo;and you will see that already the litter carrying the prince has turned off for Westminster!&equo;

s.w: Edward looked round, and the sight of the empty space where the horse-drawn litter had been, all but unmanned him.
He felt deprived, desolate, doubly-bereaved…
I must not mind, he told himself sternly.
Richard is but a child of eleven — 'tis fitting and right that he should join mama and our sisters.
It is foolish of me to be concerned.
Maybe it is for myself I mind, rather than for him! 'Tis not so much that Richard is bound for sanctuary — as that I am denied such privilege.
Privilege?
How foolish of me!
I am King of England — or so they tell me!
How then could I so much as contemplate joining my family in sanctuary?
Uncle Richard is right.
He must be right…
It was then that the thought occurred to him.
If his mother and sisters had gone into sanctuary, what of the lady Anne?
She will have accompanied them, I doubt not, being bride to Richard my brother, he told himself.
And if she is there, will not Joan de Warenne be there also…?
He turned to speak to Richard of Gloucester, and the latter was surprised by his expression.
It was as if his downcast spirits had lifted— and he were, after all, elated by thoughts of kingship.

s.c: &bquo;My lord uncle,&equo; he said, &bquo;you are very good to me.

s.w: The king my father had complete confidence in your judgement and loyalty, I know.
Pray be assured that I have no less confidence in your qualities of governance.&equo;
Richard of Gloucester met his gaze.
There could be no doubt of the youth's sincerity.
Emotion clearly showing in his eyes, the protector nodded briefly and, before replying, turned his gaze to the highway ahead.
It was as if he were in two minds about something and must select his words with care.

s.c: &bquo;Our Lord have you in his keeping!&equo; he said quietly then.

s.w: The populace surged around them, noisy and enthusiastic at the sight of the young king.

As the cavalcade proceeded through the city, Edward smilingly acknowledged the acclamations and Richard of Gloucester — well aware that it was the very day, the fourth of May,
appointed by Elizabeth Woodville for her son's coronation — addressed the citizens as he rode by.

s.c: &bquo;Behold your prince and sovereign!&equo; he cried, indicating his nephew and receiving in response a tumultuous roar of approval.
&bquo;Good citizens, behold your prince and sovereign!&equo;

s.w: Thirteen
Elizabeth Woodville, informed of the arrest of her brother and of her son by a former marriage, as well as of the young king's faithful chamberlain, was beside herself with anger and anxiety.
Fearful of opposing Richard of Gloucester however until she had her sons in her charge, she resolved to take no precipitate action until she was reunited with them.
Word of the arrival in London of the new king was brought to her by Prince Richard.
She embraced her younger son warmly and with expressions of joy — whilst quite unable to restrain her tears.

s.c: &bquo;How good it is to see you, my son,&equo; she told him.
&bquo;But what of the king your brother?&equo;
&bquo;He will lodge tonight at Ely Palace, maman ,&equo; the prince told her.

s.w: On the morrow or soon after, as our uncle of Gloucester told me, he will take up residence in the Tower.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;The Tower, you say?&equo; asked Elizabeth Woodville in dismay, fear clutching at her throat.
&bquo;Wherefore the Tower?&equo;
&bquo;Why, for his safe-keeping!&equo;
&bquo;His safe-keeping, you say?&equo; asked Elizabeth Woodville.
&bquo;Would he be safer there than here with his own mother?

s.w: If only he were here with us, my son, how joyful would be this reunion!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;My brother is in good health, madam my mother — though he shed a tear or two, but secretly, when Sir Thomas Vaughan and Uncle Rivers were arrested!&equo;
&bquo;And so I should think!&equo; exclaimed Elizabeth Woodville approvingly, turning to address her daughters.

&bquo;God be
praised that we had the foresight this morning to leave the palace and take refuge here!&equo;
&bquo;Did none try to persuade you to stay till the king arrived?&equo; asked the prince.
&bquo;I gave no heed to them,&equo; came the answer.
&bquo;My mind was made up.

s.w: We departed by the garden staircase, bringing with us only such articles of apparel and personal effects as could be worn or carried.
Truth to tell, all is not yet completed — even at this moment my servants are working secretly to bring my plan to fruition.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;What of myself, maman ?&equo; asked the prince, since his mother's attention had apparently veered to the completion of her move.
&bquo;My lord of Gloucester wishes me to join Edward in the Tower — he made me promise.&equo;
&bquo;You, my pretty son, are staying with me!&equo; declared Elizabeth Woodville.
&bquo;I gave my word, maman .&equo;
&bquo;A promise given under duress is a misnomer, my son,&equo; came the answer.
&bquo;It is merely a password to freedom!&equo;
&bquo;But I can not leave Edward on his own,&equo; protested the eleven-year-old.
&bquo;He depends on me, you see.&equo;
&bquo;Depends on you?&equo;

s.w: The queen-dowager laughed softly, her anxieties relegated to the background as she gazed at her best-loved child.

s.c: &bquo;The conceit of the lad — and he only a second son!

s.w: I declare you are so much like your papa — whose soul God pardon — that it eases my sorrowing heart!
Edward is in his thirteenth year, two years your elder, and is King of England— why then would he depend on you?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;The king my brother is fearful — though none knows it save I,&equo; explained the prince.
&bquo;Kings must hide their fears, he says.&equo;
&bquo;Alas my poor son!&equo; wept Elizabeth Woodville.
&bquo;Whatever would his papa have said!&equo;
&bquo;You see, maman , I have to remind him to say &bquo;we&equo;,' Richard said importantly, pressing home what he saw as his advantage.

s.w: Although the journey from Ludlow, accomplished in record time, had been arduous in the extreme for one of his years, the yearned-for reunion with his family seemed now an anti-climax.

He was shut away in sanctuary with
the female members of his family, whilst the king his brother and, as he told himself, every other male of importance in the realm, would shortly be taking up residence in the Tower.

Wearying though the journey had been at the time — even humiliating in respect of his being drawn in a litter — in retrospect it seemed full of excitement, a time when one knew not what would happen next or what lay around the next corner.
Even the unease he had felt when from time to time he had registered his brother's anxiety, had somehow suggested an adventure.
To a lively eleven-year-old, albeit heir to the throne, danger was the spice of life.

s.c: &bquo;Explain your meaning, my son,&equo; his mother was saying in the disapproving tone generally reserved for others.
&bquo;The royal plural, my lord Rivers calls it,&equo; explained the prince.
&bquo;Edward is wont to forget, you understand, being such a new sovereign — and 'tis my duty to remind him.&equo;
&bquo;Alas that a child of barely eleven summers must stand at the king's elbow to remind him of his duty!&equo; lamented Elizabeth Woodville.
&bquo;Woe is me that Edward's kinsmen, plucked from his side during his first moments of kingship, lie now in the dungeons of Pontefract!&equo;
&bquo; Maman , what mean you?&equo;

s.w: Richard's eyes were wide with shock.

s.c: &bquo;Surely Uncle Rivers and Sir Thomas Vaughan are not held in a dungeon!&equo;
&bquo;They are indeed — and Richard Grey with them.

s.w: I was given the news last midnight and methought I would drown in the sorrow of my tears!&equo;
Elizabeth Woodville told him woefully.

s.c: &bquo;I fear greatly for their safety — God grant they will retain their lives if not their liberty!&equo;
&bquo;But Lord Richard Grey is your own son, maman —&equo; said Richard, as if such would ensure his safety &bquo;— and the king's half-brother.&equo;
&bquo;He is so,&equo; said the queen-dowager unhappily, &bquo; and Earl Rivers is my own brother.

s.w: So now you see, Richard, do you not, why your mama cannot let you out of her sight?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Edward needs me, maman ,&equo; persisted the prince.
&bquo;Really he does.&equo;
&bquo;Not another word, my son,&equo; said the queen-dowager firmly.
&bquo;You are very precious to me — indeed to us all.

s.w:
The
king your brother's life could well depend on your continuing safety.&equo;
At the words to us all , the boy's attention had wandered somewhat.
He looked from one to another of those gathered around them — the thought having suddenly occurred to him.

s.c: &bquo;What of the lady Anne?&equo; he enquired of his mother.
&bquo;I see her not here with my sisters.&equo;
&bquo;She is to join us forthwith,&equo; explained Elizabeth Woodville.
&bquo;The dowager-duchess, your lady's mother, is in frail health at present and was reluctant to be separated from her only child.&equo;
&bquo;Could not the dowager-duchess also have entered sanctuary?&equo;
&bquo;Such is unnecessary.&equo;

s.w: There was a cold note in the queen-dowager's voice.

s.c: &bquo;The Mowbrays are in no danger — of the old nobility, they are held in reverence throughout the land.&equo;
&bquo;But the lady Anne is my bride.&equo;
&bquo;She is indeed, my son, and that is why the dowager-duchess has agreed, if reluctantly, that her daughter too might be in danger.

s.w: Once the dowager-duchess is well enough to leave Westminster, she will make her abode at her residence in the Strand and Anne and her servant will join us here.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Her servant, you say?

s.w: Joan de Warenne, do you mean, maman ?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;My son, I take no note of my relatives&equo; servants,&equo; said Elizabeth Woodville impatiently.
&bquo;The person in question is methinks the lady Anne's companion.&equo;
&bquo;I am glad the lady Anne is coming here,&equo; the prince said, feeling it was expected of him.

s.w: Well aware of his brother's infatuation with Joan and seeing no reason to discourage it, he regarded Anne's arrival at the sanctuary as a step in the right direction.

s.c: &equo; 'Tis proper that she should be with yourself and my sisters.&equo;
&bquo;I am glad you are seeing sense, my son!&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Woodville turned round, her attention diverted towards servants who had just entered the hall with some more of her possessions.

s.c: &bquo;Now, let me see…&equo;
&bquo;Madam my mother, pray permit me to go to my brother,&equo; the prince pleaded, still at his mother's elbow as she moved away.
&bquo;It is out of the question,&equo; came the reply.
&bquo;Later we shall speak further of the matter — at present there is much to be done.&equo;
&bquo;The king my brother needs me.&equo;

s.w: The prince was close to tears.

s.c: &bquo;I know he does.&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Woodville turned and drew him to one side.

s.c: &bquo;Hearken to me, my son,&equo; she said in a low voice.
&bquo;This is for your ears only.

s.w: I suspect that the king's life could well be in danger.
Together, you would both be in danger — I doubt it not.
Separated, as long as you are alive and your brother's heir, there would be no point in our enemies destroying Edward.
Whilst you wait safely in the wings, your brother too is safe.
Think on that, my prince, ere you pester your mama further!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Madam my mother, I would much much rather remain here with you.&equo;

s.w: Convinced that in keeping him with her, she was merely indulging her maternal regard for him, Richard was playing his last card.
He wished for nothing more at that moment than to join his brother and be part of the scene during the heady days before and during the coronation.

s.c: &bquo;Am not I your own angel boy?

s.w: But you, dearest maman , have my sisters to console and comfort you — whilst poor Edward will be alone, quite alone, if I desert him.&equo;
But it seemed that only the one sentence had impinged on the queen-dowager's consciousness.

s.c: &bquo;You are indeed my angel boy!&equo; she said, kissing him fondly.
&bquo;Are not you heir to the House of York — maman's very own White Rose!&equo;

s.w: Fourteen
The Grand Sanctuary was a vast building and stood only a short distance from the palace of Westminster.

Built by Edward the Confessor, of sufficient strength to withstand a siege, it housed an almonry where the alms of the abbey were distributed and an abbey church built above it in the form of a cross.
Shortly after Elizabeth Woodville and her family entered sanctuary, she received a visit from the chancellor, Thomas Rotherham Bishop of Lincoln.
The evening was well advanced when the chancellor arrived and he found the queen-dowager lying on cushions on the rush-strewn floor.
Prince Richard was asleep beside her, his head on his mother's lap, her arm protectively encircling him.
The prince's young bride lay a short distance away beside her sisters-in-law, all of them huddled together for warmth and sleeping fast, exhausted by the trials and tribulations of a distressing day.

s.c: &bquo;Madam,&equo; said the servant who had conducted the chancellor to the queen-dowager, &bquo;the Bishop of Lincoln is here and begs audience of Your Grace.&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Woodville sat up and gently disengaged herself from her sleeping son.
She smoothed her hair and her gown, and indicated with a notable lack of enthusiasm that she would receive the visitor.

s.c: &bquo;Madam, it grieves me deeply to see the straits to which your bereavement has brought you,&equo; observed the chancellor after a formal obeisance.

&bquo;Being informed by Lord Hastings of your situation and assured by him that my lord of Gloucester intends no harm to the king your son — but, on the contrary, desires only to protect him
from those who would harm him — on learning of this an hour ago whilst in my bed at York House, I at once arose and came hither.&equo;
&bquo;I know you to be a compassionate man,&equo; the queen-dowager told him.
&bquo;I know moreover that you speak with sincerity.

s.w: Tell me then, sir, if you yourself believe that no harm is intended to the king.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Madam, I judge that my lord of Gloucester has the welfare of his nephews close to his heart,&equo; the chancellor told her.
&bquo;Did not he ever show himself a loyal supporter of the late king your husband?&equo;
&bquo;By my troth, I derive small consolation from Lord Hastings&equo; assurances!&equo; declared the queen-dowager.
&bquo;I confess myself bewildered by it all — since my lord's death, you see, it has been difficult to determine one's friends from one's enemies!&equo;
&bquo;I feel certain you may count Lord Hastings your friend, madam.&equo;
&bquo;Ah, woe worth him!&equo; came the reply.
&bquo;For it is he that goes about to destroy me and my blood.&equo;
&bquo;Madam, be of good comfort,&equo; the chancellor urged, disturbed by her outspokenness.
&bquo;Be assured that if they crown anyone king than your elder son whom they have with them, we will on the day following crown his brother whom you have here with you.&equo;
&bquo;I thank you for that assurance, my lord,&equo; said the queen-dowager tremulously, drawing closer the still-sleeping prince.
&bquo;This child is very precious to me — indeed to all who honour the House of York.

s.w: He is our hope for the future, a hostage for his brother's safety.
Fair and fragile though he be — they tell me his father looked so in his youth — yet he has great strength of will.
The joy of a sorrowing mother's heart he is — her one and only White Rose!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;May God protect him!&equo; said the chancellor piously, somewhat taken aback by so abundant a display of mother-love.
&bquo;The Holy Spirit have charge of him for all our sakes!&equo;

&bquo;My lord, I shall endeavour to take heart from your assurances in regard to Lord Hastings — I derive much
comfort from your undertaking in respect of this my younger son.&equo;

s.w: The chancellor who had long been an admirer of the queen, was affected not for the first time by her beauty and appeal — attributes which, it seemed to him, were in no way impaired by adversity.
He sought to convince her of — his good intentions.

s.c: &bquo;As to that, madam, I shall go further,&equo; he said gallantly, whereupon he unfastened his leather pouch and carefully removed from it the Great Seal of England.
&bquo;But surely, my lord…&equo;
&bquo;Madam, the Great Seal is as you know, on the sovereign's demise, temporarily entrusted to the lord chancellor,&equo; he said, beneficently placing it in her hands.
&bquo;As a pledge of my sincerity in the matter of the crowning of Prince Richard, I leave it for the time being with you.

s.w: You see it likewise as your noble lord gave it to me on his deathbed.&equo;
Edward had meanwhile left Ely Palace and was lodged instead in the royal apartments within the Tower.
The Tower served a number of purposes, not least as a public record office and a meeting place for the Council's chief administrators.
A council was called on the day following Edward's arrival at which, in accordance with the late King's wishes, Richard of Gloucester had been declared protector of the king and kingdom.
The protector had taken the Great Seal, returned by the queen-dowager that very morning, and given it again into the chancellor's care.
He next bestowed on his favourites all those offices that had hitherto been held by the Woodvilles, thus weakening their position and strengthening his own.
He then sent a deputation to the queen-dowager, requiring that Prince Richard be permitted to attend his brother and assist at his coronation.

Her concealment of the prince implied mistrust, he told the council, which
might invite jealousies and revive factions — to the great detriment of the realm.
Thomas Cardinal Bourchier, former Archbishop of Canterbury and chancellor, was appointed to head the deputation.
The cardinal himself demurred, this prompting a noisy debate between the temporal and ecclesiastical peers.
Impatient of this, Richard of Gloucester put forward a further suggestion — which made the first seem infinitely preferable!

s.c: &bquo;Whilst there may be sanctuary men and sanctuary women —&equo; he pointed out, producing as it were his trump card, &bquo;— since children can commit no crime for which asylum would be needed, the privilege of sanctuary cannot be extended to them.

s.w: I could therefore possess myself of my nephew by force if —&equo; he paused for full effect and looked from one to another of the councillors &bquo;— if, as Lord High Protector, I elected so to do.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;And do you elect so to do?&equo; pertinently enquired the cardinal, voicing the curiosity of them all.

s.w: The protector appeared to hesitate.

s.c: &bquo;Should the queen-dowager again refuse my petition — for the sake of the realm, it would be necessary to resolve the matter by having recourse to force,&equo; he replied then.
&bquo;Such action needless to say would be both regretted and regrettable.

s.w: That being so, my lord cardinal, it is up to you!&equo;

Cardinal Bourchier, venerable and well-respected, was a man of integrity and high moral standards — one who, throughout his seventy-nine years, had maintained his belief in the inherent goodness of Man.
Whilst the rest of the deputation waited uneasily, the cardinal, as spokesman, gently and courteously used every argument to persuade the queen-dowager to relinquish Prince Richard.
She was adamant.

s.c:
&bquo;My lord, by agreeing to the protector's demand, I would be placing the lives of both my sons in jeopardy,&equo; she
said.
&bquo;As long as Richard Duke of York remains here, he is guaranteeing the security of the king his brother.&equo;

s.w: The cardinal looked shocked.

s.c: &bquo;Be assured, madam, that either way the king is not in danger,&equo; he said firmly.

&bquo;Whilst one can needless to say appreciate your anxiety for one born to high estate and deprived over-soon of the protection of his sire, pray be assured that were King Edward of happy memory here with us now, he would urge you to relinquish your over-protectiveness of the prince.&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Woodville's eyes filled with tears.

s.c: &bquo;How cruel you are in speaking thus, my lord!&equo; she said reproachfully, having no defence against such an argument.
&bquo;We are both aware, I dare say, that were my royal lord with me now, I would not have been brought to such a pass.

s.w: My lord was a lion amongst men — but his sons are as yet mere cubs!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I beseech you to have trust, madam,&equo; persisted the cardinal.
&bquo;None wishes harm to the prince your son.

s.w: Deliver him into my hands now and I swear, as I hope for salvation, that you will never have cause to regret it.
The king is young and requires the company of his brother, being melancholy without a playfellow.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Sayeth the protector — and pray God he may be a protector! — that the king doth lack a playfellow?&equo;

s.w: The queen-dowager's voice was scornful in the extreme.

s.c: &bquo;Can none be found to play with the king but only his brother which hath no wish to play because of sickness?&equo;

s.w: She had reckoned without the prince.

s.c: &bquo;But I am not sick, madam my mother!&equo; he protested, being with his sisters and overhearing only her last seven words.
&bquo;Why say you I am sick?&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Woodville ignored the interruption.

s.c: &bquo;Fie, my lord!&equo; she continued.
&bquo;As though princes, so young as they be, could not play without their peers, or children without their kindred — with whom for the most part they agree worse than with strangers!&equo;
&bquo;But Edward does need me, madam my mother,&equo; again interposed the prince as she paused to collect her thoughts.
&bquo;You know he does.&equo;
&bquo;Be silent, my son!&equo;

s.w: The words were sharp but there was none the less warmth in the queen-dowager's voice.

s.c: &bquo;Join not your persuasions to those of our enemies.&equo;

s.w: The cardinal looked shocked — was shocked.
Never before in hisseventy-nine years had sovereign or consort accused him of enmity.

s.c: &bquo;Madam, I confess myself deeply grieved that you should judge one an enemy who has ever served you and yours faithfully and to the utmost of his ability,&equo; he said sorrowfully — and the prince, watching the scene with avid interest, expected to see tears well from his eyes.
&bquo;Believe me, madam…&equo;
&bquo;Yea, my lord, I believe you,&equo; interposed the queen-dowager hastily — sharing her son's expectations but with less enthusiasm.
&bquo;I believe you believe what you say.

s.w: I accept that what you say is well-meant but is not it possible that you yourself…&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Then since you accept what I say, madam —&equo; interposed the cardinal with a sense of timing that suggested the protector had not nominated him for the task solely on account of his venerability &bquo;— might I urge you to give the prince into my custody!&equo;
&bquo;Please, maman ,&equo; put in the prince in his most wheedling tone.
&bquo;Please let me join Edward.&equo;

s.w: Edward?
Elizabeth Woodville's voice was unusually stern — her defences were down and attack was the better part of defence.

s.c: &bquo;To whom do you refer?&equo;
&bquo;The king my brother,&equo; the prince replied cheerfully.
&bquo;Pray permit me to go to him, that I may be by his side at his coronation.

s.w: I could tell him when his crown's starting to fall off and remind him of the royal plural — and, well, lots of things!
Then after the coronation I could — should you still wish it — return to sanctuary.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;My precious White Rose!&equo; murmured the queen-dowager.
&bquo;You are so young, so tender — you know not the wickedness of the world, of devious and ambitious rascals.

s.w: How could you know!
Think you if I permitted you to join your brother now, that you would be permitted to return?
Alas my innocent lamb!&equo;

s.c:
&bquo; Maman , I have an idea,&equo; the prince said, having racked
his brains for further persuasions and clutching this time at straws.
&bquo;Since you are concerned for my safety, would not it be well for the lady Anne to accompany me — she being my duchess and bride?&equo;

s.w: Recognizing that in this instance her son would use any means to persuade her to change her mind, Elizabeth Woodville none the less gave thought to the suggestion.

The House of Mowbray was, after all, of the ancient nobility — unlike the Woodvilles themselves who, by virtue of her marriage and the late king's generosity, had only recently attained the highest appointments in the land.
Whatever Richard of Gloucester's intentions — and God knows I could be mistaken! — he would not provoke the enmity of the Mowbrays by causing harm to the lady Anne, she told herself.
She would be lodged in the royal palace within the Tower, with servants a-plenty to serve and chaperon her.
Indeed, her presence could well guarantee the safety of both princes.

s.c: &bquo;Madam, I fear you are distracted by indecision and grief,&equo; observed the cardinal, wearied by what he privately termed her procrastination.
&bquo;The matter is not as you imagine, God be thanked!

s.w: My lord of Gloucester displays the utmost affection for his nephews— his care is solely for their welfare and he judges that Prince Richard's place at this auspicious time is with the king his brother.
A boy needs male companionship and — pray forgive me, madam — one with a doting mother and five sisters is in my humble opinion in danger of becoming petticoat-ridden!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I shall give thought to the matter, my lord,&equo; Elizabeth Woodville said icily, more than a little on her mettle.
&bquo;Might I suggest that you wait with yonder deputation whilst I consider the matter further?

s.w: I shall acquaint you with my decision in due course!&equo;

As the deputation withdrew tactfully to the further end of the great chamber, the queen-dowager conferred with her family, listening to their conflicting views and in the process becoming more undecided than ever.

s.c: &bquo;What of yourself, lady Anne?&equo; she enquired.

&bquo;Were your young lord permitted to join the king his brother — he being now at the royal palace within the Tower — would
you wish to accompany him?&equo;

s.w: Anne and Joan had been sitting a little aside from the others and had till then taken no part in the discussion.
Gloom and despondency hung over the royal party and Anne was more than a little resentful of having been required to join them in sanctuary.
Given the choice, she would have returned with her mother to Suffolk, and Joan with her.
She hesitated.
None of this was her affair, she told herself not for the first time.
Apart from having to suffer, as she told herself, the royal family's woefully reduced circumstances, she missed her mother and was genuinely concerned for the latter's deteriorating health.

Elizabeth Mowbray, faced with the conflicts and uncertainties that had beleaguered the court during the weeks following Edward the Fourth's death, had made plans to return with Anne and Joan to Framlingham until the tumult had died down.
Like Anne, she saw the current situation as none of her business — and wished not to be seen as taking sides.
Partisanship at such a time could be unwise, she knew, and the sooner she and Anne were back at Framlingham, the better for them both.
Then in the event of a change of monarchy, Anne's marriage to Prince Richard could, since it was as yet incomplete, be annulled.
But even as Elizabeth Mowbray was finalising her plans for departure, Fate intervened.

A sudden and debilitating attack of the sweating sickness had rendered her unfit for travel, with the result that Anne had accompanied the royal family into sanctuary and her mother had been taken by litter to Norfolk House in London's Strand.
Anne had been dwelling on this, even as the queen-dowager, together with the prince, princesses and Joan, waited with a mixture of feelings — hope, doubt, impatience and irritation — for her reply.
Her reply seemed ananti-climax — even to herself.

s.c: &bquo;I know not,&equo; she said.
&bquo;I know not how to answer Your Grace.

s.w: And since there is much talk of danger and imprisonment, perchance I should remain here until mama has been consulted.&equo;

None too happy with what she privately termed her
daughter-in-law's faint-hearted response, the queen-dowager sat lost in thought for a minute.
She gave a start as the prince, at her elbow, spoke.

s.c: &bquo; Maman , please say I can go to the king, with or without the lady Anne,&equo; he said.
&bquo;Edward needs me.&equo;
&bquo;Alas, fair son, you play upon your mama's heartstrings!&equo;
&bquo;Then I may go?&equo;

s.w: Anne, having moved away from Elizabeth Woodville and her family, had meanwhile been conversing in low tones with Joan.
Joan, this is surely your opportunity!&equo; she said.

s.c: &bquo;Opportunity — what mean you?&equo;
&bquo;To see the prince.&equo;
&bquo;I can see the prince very well, thank you.

s.w: He is at present looking more angelic than ever, trying to charm his mother into letting him have his own way!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I was meaning the king his brother.&equo;
&bquo;Why did not you say so then!&equo;

s.w: Joan's seeming ill-humour was a ploy to conceal even from herself her true feelings — the quickening of her pulses at mention of the beloved, told a different story.

s.c: &bquo;Joan, hearken to me,&equo; Anne said urgently.
&bquo;The queen is naturally loath to part with her &bquo;sweet babe&equo; and uses every argument against his joining his brother.

s.w: As a means of persuading her, the prince suggested to my chagrin that I should accompany him.
The queen broached the matter to me and ostensibly I am now giving thought to my answer — what would you say to going in my place?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;To the Tower of London?&equo;

s.w: Joan asked without enthusiasm — but then her face brightened.

s.c: &bquo;You mean I might see the prince!&equo;
&bquo;Not the prince,&equo; Anne corrected, getting her own back.
&bquo;But there is a possibility — a faint possibility — that you might see the king.&equo;

s.w: Joan's eyes sparkled.

s.c: &bquo;You mean…?&equo;

s.w: Anne nodded.

s.c: &bquo;What do you say?&equo;
&bquo;I might actually see Edward?&equo;
&bquo;In truth, I think it is likely.&equo;
&bquo;How soon can I leave?&equo; asked Joan with a broad smile.
&bquo;Now — at this very moment?&equo;
&bquo;Then you agree?&equo;
&bquo;Naturally I agree — I would agree to anything for a sight of Edward, be he prince or king!&equo;
&bquo;That is settled then,&equo; smiled Anne.
&bquo;I shall inform the queen.&equo;
&bquo;But surely…&equo;
&bquo;Leave it to me.

s.w: Just leave it to Lady Anne.&equo;
Thus it was that Prince Richard's latest appeal went unanswered.
His mother's attention had been diverted — fortuitously from her point of view — by his young duchess.

s.c: &bquo; Maman —&equo; said Anne, using the mode of address favoured by the prince when in private and pleasing to the doting mother &bquo;— I would speak with you alone.&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Woodville drew her to one side.

s.c: &bquo;What is it, child?&equo; she asked, grateful for the interruption.
&bquo;Could not Joan de Warenne, my half-sister, go to the Tower in my stead?&equo; she asked.
&bquo;Much as I myself desire to accompany my lord, being a minor and not fully wed, I would first need my mother's permission — such would take time, alas!

s.w: Joan has ofttimes been taken for myself.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;She would go as yourself, do you mean?&equo; asked Elizabeth Woodville doubtfully.
&bquo;She would make pretence of being Anne Duchess of York?&equo;
&bquo;Only with Your Grace's permission, needless to say.

s.w: As my companion andhalf-sister, Joan is already acquainted with the king your son.
She would be a companion for both princes.
None would suspect if she and I changed places, as it were — she wearing my apparel and having her hair dressed in like manner.&equo;
Joan de Warenne being not of royal blood and not linked as you yourself are, Lady Anne, by a bond of marriage, I can see no virtue in such an arrangement.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Would not it give Your Grace a foot in both camps — in a manner of speaking?&equo; Anne suggested.
&bquo;Disguised as Anne Duchess of York, would not Joan de Warenne have free passage'twixt Tower and outside world — and thus be a carrier of messages and information?&equo;
&bquo;The plan has something to recommend it,&equo; agreed Elizabeth Woodville.
&bquo;Yea, such would give me, as you say, a foot in both camps.

s.w: What of the lass herself?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Joan is willing to go,&equo; came the answer.
&bquo;And since the royal apartments are well staffed, she would be adequately chaperoned.&equo;
&bquo;And presently, my lady?&equo; asked Elizabeth Woodville.
&bquo;The situation could continue thus for weeks.

s.w: Whilst a new date has been named, I understand, for the coronation — again it could be postponed.
Alas, naught is certain in this troublous world!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Having obtained mama's permission, I should forthwith change places with Joan — and none, I dare say, would notice the difference!&equo;

s.w: The queen-dowager hesitated only for a moment.
Joan de Warenne is willing to go, you say?&equo; she enquired then.

s.c: &bquo;For my sake, maman , she is willing to go,&equo; Anne replied — somehow implying that Joan herself had no great liking for the undertaking, but knew her place and her duty.
&bquo;For my sake.&equo;
&bquo;Then I agree,&equo; said Elizabeth Woodville graciously.
&bquo;To have a go-between, one who could move freely betwixt Tower and Westminster, betwixt my sons and myself, would greatly relieve my concern for their welfare.&equo;
&bquo;Then I may go, maman ?&equo; asked Prince Richard gleefully, having again overheard his mother's last words.
&bquo;That is what you are talking about, is it not?&equo;
&bquo;Yea, fair son, you may go…&equo;

s.w: The rest of the queen-dowager's words were drowned by the prince's whoops of joy— and the cardinal, kept waiting for over an hour, hearing the hullabaloo, exchanged relieved glances with his fellows.

s.c: &bquo;Hearken to me, my prince,&equo; said the queen-dowager in a low voice, frowning at her son.

s.w: Joan de Warenne, the lady Anne's half-sister, rather than that young lady herself, will go with you to the Tower — thus will there be a means of communication between us.&equo;
Joan de Warenne?&equo; asked the prince in surprise.
His mother nodded.

s.c:
&bquo;You will leave today with Cardinal
Bourchier.

s.w: Joan de Warenne will follow on, arriving on the morrow.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;By St. Crispin!

s.w: Edward will be overjoyed…&equo;
The prince paused and collected himself — and changed horses in mid-stream &bquo;… to see his baby brother!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;That it is Joan de Warenne rather than the lady Anne who accompanies you to the Tower, must be a close-kept secret,&equo; Elizabeth Woodville told him, her mind working rapidly.
&bquo;The knowledge will be shared by no more than six persons: Edward and yourself, the lady Anne and her mother, Joan de Warenne and myself — and another who shall as yet be nameless.&equo;
&bquo;My lord of Gloucester?&equo; enquired the prince mischievously.
&bquo;Surely, madam my mother, you will inform my uncle!&equo;

s.w: But Elizabeth Woodville, observing the cardinal advancing towards them, was turning to address him.

s.c: &bquo;You will not regret it,&equo; the cardinal told her, observing the prince's elation and guessing its cause.
&bquo;Your Grace has made the right decision, God be thanked!&equo;
&bquo;The prince will leave forthwith with yourself,&equo; the queen-dowager told him.

s.w: Her voice was cold — her heart even colder.

s.c: &bquo;I trust you will care for him, my lord, as if he were your own.&equo;
&bquo;He is my own, madam,&equo; came the smooth response.
&bquo;Are not we all one in Christ?&equo;

s.w: Elizabeth Woodville, the prince at her side, next addressed the deputation.

s.c: &bquo;My lord and all my lords here present, I will not be so suspicious as to mistrust your truths,&equo; she said, her voice charged with emotion.

s.w: Taking the prince by the hand, she continued, &bquo;Lo, here is this gentleman whom I doubt not would be safely kept by me, if I were permitted; and well as I know there be some deadly enemies to my blood, that if they knew where any lay in their own bodies, they would let it out if they could!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Madam, I protest!&equo;

s.w: Cardinal Bourchier was plainly shocked — but the queen-dowager, if she heard, paid no heed.

s.c:
&bquo;The desire of a kingdom knows no kindred,&equo; she told
the deputation.
&bquo;Brothers have been brothers&equo; bane— and may the nephew be sure of the uncle?

s.w: Each of these princes is safe whilst they be asunder.
Notwithstanding, my lords, I here deliver my son — and his brother's life with him — into your hands, and of you shall I require them before God and man.
Faithful be ye, I know well, and power ye have if ye list to keep them safe; but if ye think I fear too much, yet beware ye fear not too little!&equo;
A ripple of unease ran through the deputation at that, but the murmurings were indecipherable, as if even collectively its members were treading warily.
If any shared the queen-dowager's forebodings, none was prepared to admit it.
As she finished speaking, the queen-dowager called for the prince's cloak.
As this was fastened and he was made ready for departure, the prince for the first time seemed ill-at-ease — as if only then did he sense the poignancy of the moment and was after all loath to go.

s.c: &bquo;Farewell, mine own sweet son,&equo; his mother said in a voice laden with tears.
&bquo;God send you good keeping!&equo;
&bquo;Farewell, madam my mother,&equo; responded the prince sturdily, but then,&bquo;Nay, maman, pray do not weep…&equo;
&bquo;Let me kiss you once ere you go, my princeling — for God knoweth when we shall kiss together again!&equo;

s.w: She kissed and blessed him and hugged him close, and it seemed to the uneasy watchers that she would after all change her mind.

s.c: &bquo;God have pity!&equo; she said then.
&bquo;Reason tells me I do right to let you go, yet my heart urges me to hold on to you…&equo;
&bquo;You are hurting me, maman,&equo; the prince protested, a little frightened by his mother's anguish.
&bquo;Forgive me, my son —&equo; she said softly and then, with a brave attempt at a smile, &bquo;Go now, with the cardinal…&equo;

s.w: Weeping, she turned away as the prince, trying manfully to hold back his tears, was led away.
As he disappeared, the great chamber fell strangely silent.
It was as if, thought the queen-dowager fancifully, the world had stopped turning for a few moments, immobilised by the enormity of her action.

Quelling an urge to run from the sanctuary, to seize the prince and
bring him back before it was too late, she fell on her knees.

s.c: &bquo;O Mary, mother of sorrows who knows so well a mother's anguish, intercede I pray you for this sorrowing mother and her innocent son…&equo;

s.w: Fifteen
Joan had accepted without reservation her half-sister's suggestion that she go with Prince Richard and take up residence in the Tower.
Overjoyed at the prospect, she found it difficult to conceal her excitement from those around her.
Anne herself was well aware of Joan's motive in accepting the suggestion with such alacrity.
She realized that it stemmed, not from a noble desire to serve the royal family in general, but from a somewhat ignoble desire to see Edward in particular.
Joan, she had discovered, was single-minded in her approach to life.
To see Edward again, she would have dared the Devil himself!
Indeed, thought Anne wryly, to hear the queen-dowager talk, one would imagine Richard of Gloucester was the Devil incarnate — and he her deceased lord's brother!
She would miss Joan, of course.
But it would be only for a time and she had been thinking of asking the queen-dowager for permission to leave sanctuary and visit her mother.
Once at Norfolk House, she would consult her mother's wishes as to her future movements.
Perhaps her mother would agree to her returning for a while to Framlingham…
Yea, that is what I shall do, she thought.
One cannot in such circumstances as these, please everybody all of the time.

My plan will give joy to some and satisfaction to many: satisfaction to Prince Richard because he can now join the king his brother, to Cardinal Bourchier because his mission has been successfully accomplished, and to the protector because he will have his nephews where he wants them — wherever that may be!
Joy?

Joan's meeting with
her Edward will be, unless I am much mistaken, joy indeed!
I, Anne Mowbray, Duchess of York, can very shortly follow my own path with a clear conscience…
The Tower was, as it had always been, both fortress and residence.

Not greatly favoured by Edward the Fourth and his family, the royal palace was none the less fully maintained and adequately staffed — a number of privileged persons residing there permanently in grace-and-favour apartments.
On the morning after the prince's departure, carrying out a plan known as yet to only six persons, the queen-dowager bade farewell to the damsel everyone assumed to be the lady Anne.

The leave-taking this time was formal, bearing none of the displays of emotion that had marked Prince Richard's departure — the queen-dowager was but bidding farewell, it was thought, to her son's bride, a young lady who was going to the royal palace within the Tower to keep company for a time with her husband.
The arrangement seemed practical, unremarkable, to those around the queen-dowager who watched the young woman's departure.
As the queen-dowager had informed them, she was but paying a brief visit to the palace, out of respect for her young lord and would be returning to the sanctuary very shortly.
It was noted at the same time — though with rather less interest — that the lady Anne's companion was leaving sanctuary.

Joan de Warenne, it appeared, had not been required to go with her young mistress, since the latter was to be the guest of Lady Alianor Woodville, the queen-dowager's kinswoman — a lady who occupied apartments in the palace and kept an amplitude of servants.
Lady Alianor was the childless widow of one of the queen-dowager's Woodville cousins.

Highly regarded by Elizabeth Woodville, she had been lady of the bedchamber
until her retirement and was one of the queen-dowager's closest friends.
She was to have been among those entrusted with the secret of the girls' switched identities.
But before writing to her friend of the matter, the queen-dowager debated whether or not it was necessary to burden her with the knowledge.
Nay, she thought, I shall say nothing — at least for the time being…
Lady Alianor received her friend's letter on the evening of Prince Richard's departure.

Fearing her correspondence would otherwise be intercepted, the queen-dowager had entrusted it to the care of Cardinal Bourchier — sending it by a trusted servant to the cardinal's residence, requesting that it be forwarded to her cousin forthwith.

s.c: &bquo;I ask that you will accommodate Anne Duchess of York, my daughter-in-law in your household,&equo; Elizabeth Woodville had written— after enquiring as to her friend's health, reminiscing about former days and passing on to the matter of her daughter-in-law as if it were of little consequence.
&bquo;The damsel, now in her fourteenth summer, has understandably a great fondness for the prince her husband, and desires to be at his side during these troublous days.

s.w: I have given my consent, intending to gratify her wishes in this respect only for a short while.
The lady Anne, I doubt not, wishes to attend the king's coronation with her lord, as is to be commended.

s.c: &bquo;I ask then that you, my dear cousin, will be the lady Anne's chaperon and friend whilst she is at the Tower— any letters from you or the lady Anne to myself, may be sent via the cardinal who has agreed to serve me, and with the utmost discretion, in this matter.

s.w: Should you see your way to granting this request, the cardinal's servant shall on the morrow escort the lady Anne from the sanctuary to your abode.

s.c: &bquo;I pray that the commotion time will soon be past, that we may enjoy greater peace of mind and slumber of a night-time more soundly in our beds.

s.w: Our Lord have you in his keeping.
Thus it came about that Joan de Warenne, as closely resembling her young mistress as made no difference, was conducted to the Tower of London — and Alianor Woodville's apartments.
Lady Alianor received her graciously.

s.c: &bquo;I am well acquainted with your family —&equo; she told Joan &bquo;— and recall most vividly the duke your father, whose soul God pardon!&equo;
&bquo;I can scarce remember him,&equo; said Joan sadly — and with truth.
&bquo;Alas that the good are called so soon!&equo; sighed the lady Alianor.
&bquo;A lovely gentleman, a charming gentleman — and you, my lady, are the living image of him!&equo;
&bquo;Thank you, my lady.&equo;
&bquo;The duke will never be dead whilst you are alive, child,&equo; smiled Lady Alianor, as soon as her guest was seated.
&bquo;Methinks I am to be your chaperon — which means, I suppose, that I am to see that you conduct yourself properly and are accompanied suitably whenever you leave these apartments.

s.w: Well, I shall have no qualms as to that, it is certain!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Qualms, my lady?&equo; asked Joan, the word being new to her.
&bquo;I doubt you will get into bad company whilst in my care!&equo; said the lady Alianor with a smile — she being renowned for plain-speaking no less than loyalty.
&bquo;And I doubt the princes, poor lads, have freedom enough to carry out any mischievous forays!

s.w: Still, we must wait and see.
You, my lady, will be here with us but for a short time, I understand — so pray be at ease, and treat this as your own abode.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;The prince my husband is lodged here in the palace?&equo; enquired Joan.

s.w: Alianor nodded.

s.c:
&bquo;Here in the palace — though since
none herein has seen hide or hair of him, one suspects that the king and his brother are under some form of house arrest.&equo;
&bquo;House arrest?&equo; asked Joan in surprise.
&bquo;But I understood — that is to say the queen my mother-in-law understood — that the king moved here from Ely Palace in readiness for his coronation.

s.w: The sovereign, I understand, customarily resides at the Tower of London prior to his coronation.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;That is so — and yet…&equo;

s.w: Joan's new guardian hesitated — but then she smiled.
Lady Alianor Woodville was tall, nearly sixty years of age, and always wore flowing gowns of unrelieved black out of deference to her deceased lord.
Her patrician features were wont to relax into a smile upon the slightest provocation — giving her an ageless quality, a charm that won many hearts.

s.c: &bquo;My lady, I shall say not another word on the subject!&equo; she declared to Joan now.
&bquo;On the morrow, you will see for yourself, I doubt not.

s.w: You are welcome at any time, as far as I myself am concerned, to have the prince your husband attend you here — equally, provided you are suitably chaperoned by either myself or one appointed by myself, and provided no obstacles are put in the way, you may visit the prince.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Obstacles, you say, my lady?&equo;
&bquo;As to that, we must wait and see,&equo; sighed Alianor.
&bquo;You yourself shall be the judge.&equo;

s.w: Sixteen
Anne's hopes of returning to Framlingham had somehow gone awry.
Elizabeth Mowbray had herself already decided to return to Suffolk — her health, she told herself, would benefit from country air and rural seclusion.
On learning of her mother's decision, Anne pleaded to go with her.
It was necessary, she told her persuasively, that she leave sanctuary for the time being.
As Joan de Warenne, she had no place at court other than as a servant — should privileges such as befitted her true station be accorded her, unwelcome suspicion would be aroused.
One way or another, it was vital that she left sanctuary until after Joan's return…
Elizabeth Woodville, on learning of Anne's intentions, had other ideas on the subject.
She was adamant that her daughter-in-law must remain in the capital.
She had informed Elizabeth Mowbray of the girls' exchange of identities — information which the duchess had received thankfully, believing the exchange to have been necessary for Anne's safety.
The queen-dowager had her own reasons for wishing to keep her daughter-in-law close at hand — whilst accepting that her remaining in sanctuary in the circumstances was out of the question.
Should disaster overtake Edward her son, should he die or be declared unfit for rule, Prince Richard would likely take his place.

As the matter stood therefore, Anne Mowbray was in effect consort presumptive and, as such, if seized by one or other of the factions working against the Woodvilles, would herself become a pawn in the battle for the throne.

The Mowbray family was influential and ambitious, and would view the
queenship of one of their number with enthusiasm.
Should aught happen to Anne Mowbray, support for the Woodvilles would no longer be forthcoming.

Eventually it was agreed between Elizabeth Woodville and Anne's mother that Anne would remain in London, at least for the time being — but that for safety's sake, and lest her true identity be recognized, she should be sent secretly to the Abbey of the Minoresses which stood only a short distance from the Tower.
There she would remain in seclusion until the commotion had died down and she could live openly and in safety with her young lord.
Informed by the queen-dowager of their decision, resentful at being refused permission to return home, Anne made her displeasure plain.
She stamped her feet, wept and refused for two days to eat or — once her initial reaction had been volubly expressed — speak.

s.c: &bquo;Leave her alone,&equo; the queen-dowager ordered her daughters who had no idea what all the fuss was about.
&bquo;Leave the lass alone — she will come to her senses in time!&equo;
&bquo;But she is the lady Anne's half-sister!&equo; pointed out sixteen-year-old Cecily.
&bquo;She is the lady Anne's companion and, as such, has no place here with us now.

s.w: A position of a temporary nature has, I understand, been found for her elsewhere!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Mama, she is so like oursister-in-law — I do wish she could stay with us,&equo; said nine-year-old Anne who had a special affinity with her namesake.
&bquo;Looking at her just then, I truly believed she was the lady Anne!&equo;
&bquo;Mama, let me go and talk to her, console her…&equo;
&bquo;Leave her, Elizabeth — leave her, I say!&equo; sternly interposed thequeen-dowager.
&bquo;We all of us have something better to do than concern ourselves with the tantrums of servants!&equo;

s.w: Anne desired now above all else to leave sanctuary.
Whilst in going to the abbey, I should be exchanging one kind of prison for another, she told herself, I should no longer have to pass my days amongst the remnants of the court!
Queens and princesses, officials and servants, all lived together in the great sanctuary chamber.

Efforts had been
made to screen off the royal family from the rest by the strategic placing of hangings and drapes, but the overall effect was more suggestive of a market-place than a royal habitat — a fact which had caused Anne and Joan much secret merriment!
Living at such close quarters with them, Anne found herself at odds with the princesses.
Elizabeth of York — the eldest — was too prissy, she had decided, Cecily was a busybody, and Bridget, who was four, was prone to hiccups in the middle of the night!
Nay, all things considered, I shall welcome the move to the abbey, she thought — it could not be worse than here!
And if I should change my mind and find the abbey not to my liking, or if Joan returns and it becomes expedient to resume our true identities, then so be it.
Henceforth I shall take life as it comes, looking not to the future…
At the end of the two days, Anne found her appetite and her voice — and herself on the way to a nunnery.
Seventeen
Joan settled happily into her new and temporary abode.
Comfortably and expensively furnished, the apartments were staffed by servants many of whom had been with the lady Alianor from the time of her marriage.
Joan found the transition from sanctuary to Tower wholly satisfactory.
She had not before entered the Tower precincts, although its grim-visaged exterior as seen from the river, particularly during the dark days of winter, had frequently given her a sense of foreboding.
She had pictured its dungeons and torture-chambers, and recalled the tales of men racked and women held in chains, and of armies of plague-carrying rats.
Now she saw a different, more pleasing aspect of the fortress.
Within the Tower's walls stood its keep, the imposing White Tower which for the two hundred and fifty years since the reign of Henry the Third had been regularly whitewashed.

Rising through two floors of the White Tower, was the chapel of St. John where the lady Alianor and Joan attended Mass each morning: it was as they returned on the second morning that Joan voiced her enquiry.

s.c: &bquo;I expected to see the prince my husband at Mass this morning, my lady, she said.

s.w: Could it be that he and the king his brother hear Mass at St. Peter ad Vincula, the chapel outside the White Tower?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Both the king and his brother, I understand, hear Mass at a small private chapel close to their apartments,&equo; came the answer.
&bquo;The protector desires that, prior to his coronation, the king should not be seen too frequently in public.&equo;

s.w: More disappointed than she was prepared to admit, Joan could not entirely conceal her chagrin.

s.c: &bquo;Regular attendance at the chapel of St. John hardly constitutesover-exposure to the public,&equo; Joan demurred.
&bquo;Does not the king himself have a say in such matters?&equo;

s.w: Alas, thought the lady Alianor, the lass is pining for her young lord! 'T was rumoured that Anne Mowbray was not over-pleased with her bridegroom, due to the disparity in their ages.
Clearly though she is disappointed at not seeing him — and is concerned for his welfare.
And in that she is not alone.
There is much uneasiness and speculation — all of it, please God, unfounded!
The king and his brother are seen from time to time, if infrequently — and appear lively and in good health.
Nay, one must give Richard of Gloucester the benefit of the doubt — he is taking no chances this side of the coronation.
Various factions are at work, each seeking to promote its own interests — I'd not give a fig for the young king's life if he fell in with one of them!
One cannot blame the protector for being zealous in his guardianship of his nephews.
He but does his duty — an onerous duty, it seems to me.
Some though, and among them my dear lady Elizabeth ( always in her thoughts did Alianor refer thus to the queen-dowager) think differently.

s.c: &bquo;Very soon now, I am sure, you and your lord will be reunited,&equo; she told Joan reassuringly.
&bquo;Meanwhile, I shall enquire into the matter and see if aught can be done to hasten your reunion.&equo;
&bquo;Four days have passed since the prince left sanctuary,&equo; Joan said sadly — though it was in truth another for whom she pined.
&bquo;Perchance he desires not to receive me — and 't is by his wish I am denied a sight of him.&equo;
&bquo;Be at peace, child,&equo; said the lady Alianor consolingly.
&bquo;Strange are the ways of princes!&equo;
&bquo;What mean you, my lady?&equo;
&bquo;Richard of Gloucester has never been one to allow his heart to rule his head.

s.w: Such as he can not comprehend that which prompts others to give their heart free rein!
Have patience, lady Anne, I pray you — all will come right in the end.

Tomorrow or maybe the next day — I doubt you will
be kept waiting much longer.&equo;
The lady Alianor's prognostications proved correct.

The date of Edward's coronation had not been announced, partly because the protector wished first to ascertain the reaction of the commonalty to the news that the three prisoners at Pontefract had been executed.
In fact the populace, bewildered by rumour and uncertain as to the truth, knew not which way to turn.

Edward, elder son of the late king, was the rightful sovereign, they told themselves, but until he attained his majority, Richard of Gloucester, his uncle, was exercising his proper authority in keeping his nephews in a place of safety.
Propaganda against the Woodvilles had led the commonalty to believe that Rivers, Vaughan and Grey had plotted to gain control of the as yet uncrowned king.
The princes were seen from time to time when, with a strong guard, they rode through the streets of the City.
Edward rode always a little ahead of his brother, acknowledging the acclamations of his subjects, and Prince Richard waved and smiled — to be greeted always with an especial cheer.
The protector, on such occasions, smiling and genial, rode behind his nephews: such excursions did much to enhance his image as a benevolent and conscientious guardian.
His popularity had increased and his ambition had increased proportionately — the time had come, he told himself, to put his carefully laid plan into action.
Whether or not the meeting was part of that carefully laid plan, none could have said.
But on an afternoon following one of the City excursions, Joan was at last permitted to see Prince Richard.
One excuse after another had been made.
The young king was ill, it was claimed, was nursing an inflammation of the lungs.

The prince her husband was undesirous of
seeing the lady Anne.

The king, troubled by the prince's displays of temperament and his unwillingness to follow the advice of those who had charge of him, mindful also of his own unrobust health, considered it would be unwise for himself and his brother to receive visitors at the present time.
These prevarications had been conveyed to Joan by the lady Alianor.

s.c: &bquo;I can scarce believe it,&equo; Joan said, puzzled at the display of coldness.
&bquo;If the king my brother-in-law is ill, then it behoves me to see him, judge what may be done to assist him and inform the queen-dowager.&equo;
&bquo;Be assured that everything possible is being done,&equo; Alianor had told her — though in truth as mystified as Joan by the negative response to her requests.
&bquo;Be patient, child!

s.w: Perchance on the morrow we shall have better news.&equo;
But several morrows went by before she received word that the lady Anne might visit the prince her husband in the company of her guardian.
On entering the well-guarded but comfortable apartments occupied by the princes, Joan and Alianor were greeted by Prince Richard who looked, Joan noticed with relief, much as usual.
Having exchanged courtesies with the prince, Alianor tactfully withdrew and, for propriety's sake leaving the door just a little ajar, waited outside the chamber.

s.c: &bquo;How good it is to see you!&equo;

s.w: Richard of York said enthusiastically to Joan, as soon as they were alone.
He kissed her hand with courtly grace, displaying an air of bonhomie reminiscent of his father.
It was at once apparent to Joan that, whatever changes of circumstance had taken place, he had changed not a jot.
But his uncustomary pallor puzzled her.
