s.c: &bquo;I trust you are in good health, my lord,&equo; she said.
&bquo;In rude health,&equo; he assured her with a smile.
&bquo;If I look pale as a lily, 'tis because fresh air is too rarely on the menu.
&bquo;And the king your brother?&equo; she asked, trying to sound nonchalant.
&bquo;I trust he is well.

s.w: There are rumours abroad…&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I have a message for you from Edward,&equo; the prince interposed — and lowered his voice.
&bquo;I know 'tis my brother you really wish to see— just as I know I must call you my lady Anne!&equo;
&bquo;I would I might see you both,&equo; Joan admitted.
&equo; 'Tis bruited about that the king is unwell and that you are given to displays of temperament!

s.w: The queen your mother would learn the truth.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Displays of temperament?&equo;

s.w: The prince's eyes sparkled with merriment.

s.c: &bquo;In musical terms, as my tutor explained more than once, temperament is a system of adjusting tones of an instrument to adapt the scale for all keys!

s.w: Why, yea, I suppose then one might rightly say that this prince is given to displays of temperament!&equo;
Joan smiled, catching his mood — but then her thoughts turned to Edward.

s.c: &bquo;And has the king too adapted to circumstance?&equo; she asked soberly.
&bquo;Has he also adapted the scale for all keys?&equo;
&bquo;The only key which would interest Edward methinks is that which would open the gate to freedom!&equo;
&bquo;Freedom?&equo; frowned Joan.
&bquo;But you and the king are not prisoners, my lord!&equo;
&bquo;Edward has become apprehensive of late,&equo; came the answer.
&bquo;He sleeps little and is plagued by nightmares.

s.w: The Privy Council, it seems to us, consists solely of the protector's minions.
Only this morning we heard a rumour that an attempt is to be made to gain the approval of the commonalty to the protector being crowned king instead of Edward!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;But that cannot be!&equo; exclaimed Joan, white-faced.
&bquo;One must be ever on guard against rumour — as the lady Alianor tells me!&equo;
&bquo;Joan, hearken to me…&equo;
&bquo;I am the lady Anne, my lord!

s.w: Fie, that you should imagine otherwise!&equo; she said lightly, adding on a more serious note, &bquo; During the past months, I learned to speak and act like the duchess your wife — but in these last days I have learned to think like her also; to believe that I am indeed the lady Anne!

Thus only will suspicion be averted — and I myself enabled to gather information about
yourself and the king and convey it to the queen your mother.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;How is maman ?&equo; the prince asked — and Joan registered the small catch in his voice.
&bquo;Is she in good health?

s.w: We receive no news.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;In rude health —&equo; Joan said smilingly, echoing his own words &bquo;— though anxious needless to say for the welfare of her sons!&equo;
&bquo;Comfortable as are our surroundings, they ofttimes seem to us like a prison.&equo;
&bquo;After the coronation, all will be well,&equo; Joan assured him, ignoring her own misgivings.
&bquo;You must have patience, my lord.&equo;
&bquo;But the coronation of whom, my lady?&equo; enquired the prince, as if he too had accepted that she was indeed the lady Anne.
&bquo;Edward my brother or Richard of Gloucester?&equo;
&bquo;Surely you, my lord, reared to court life, have learned to disregard rumour and speculation!&equo;
&bquo;Edward seems more like a prisoner than a king awaiting his coronation,&equo; the prince told her.

&bquo;We no longer ride in procession through the City — and of late, our servants, some of whom have served us since infancy, have all but one been replaced with surly rascals of another's choosing.&equo;
&bquo;Once Edward becomes truly king, he can change all that, my lord.&equo;
&bquo;If he becomes truly king,&equo; corrected the prince.
&bquo;But…&equo;
&bquo;I recall how I refused to hearken to the queen my mother's fears for my brother's safety — yet now I myself fear greatly for him!&equo;
&bquo;Why so, my lord?&equo;
&bquo;I can not explain fully, for this meeting must be brief — I suspect that even the walls have ears!

s.w: But this much I must tell you —&equo; He looked around the chamber, as if expecting to see a silent listener at every corner.

s.c: &bquo;— A council meeting is called for the morrow, not in the council chamber within the Tower as is customary — but at the Guildhall.

s.w: Edward sees great significance in this.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I fail to see…&equo;
&bquo;I know.

s.w: I have sought to reassure him but…&equo;
Richard's gallic shrug was expressive and again reminiscent of his father.

s.c: &bquo;Anyway, Joan, the protector will be elsewhere tomorrow night and Edward has therefore contrived a plan whereby you could meet.

s.w: I should be there — for appearance's sake, as Edward says — but out of earshot if 'tis any concern to you!&equo;
Joan, you say?&equo; she asked with raised eyebrows.
In truth, she needed time to recover her composure — her sudden breathlessness at the realization that the long-yearned-for reunion was within her grasp.

s.c: &bquo;Alas, my lord, that you should confuse your bride with another.

s.w: Fie, I say!&equo;
The prince nodded.

s.c: &bquo;You are right of course, my lady.

s.w: It is a mite confusing for some, I doubt not, since you so closely resemble the lady Anne — though you are more agreeable and much prettier!&equo;
Joan blushed at the unexpected compliment and told herself that, despite first impressions, Richard of York had changed.
He seemed to have grown older, more mature — as if his brother's burden of kingship had fallen on his shoulders also.

s.c: &bquo;Pray tell me of the king your brother's plan, my lord,&equo; she said softly.
&bquo;Come you hence tomorrow evening,&equo; the prince told her.
&bquo;The outer door will be unlocked and a servant, our remaining trusted servant, will await your arrival.

s.w: He will escort you to Edward.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;But I am close chaperoned, my lord,&equo; Joan pointed out unhappily.
&bquo;I am not permitted to leave the lady Alianor's apartments unaccompanied.&equo;
&bquo;Then you must find a way, Joan de Warenne!&equo;

s.w: The prince smiled as he spoke her true name — as if tempting fate, cocking a snook at danger.
His next words aided the impression.

s.c: &bquo;A clandestine meeting, remember — a secret rendezvous.

s.w: Why, Edward and I have been planning it for days — it has done much to keep up his spirits!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I shall be here,&equo; Joan said quietly — telling herself that wild horses, let alone Richard of Gloucester, would not keep her from Edward.
&bquo;I shall be here, I promise you!&equo;

s.w: Eighteen
Joan returned with the lady Alianor to the latter's apartments in uncustomary silence.
Alianor registered her preoccupation and wondered at it.
She appears spellbound, she thought — like one enchanted by love and romance…
But nay, it cannot be so.
Her lord is, after all, a lad of but eleven summers.
Joan retired early to her bedchamber that evening, wishing to be alone to give thought to how, without her chaperon's knowledge, she would reach the rendezvous on the following evening.
It at once became apparent that, much as she trusted and respected Alianor, she must on this one occasion slip the leash.

Should the plan be discovered and Alianor be seen as party to the clandestine meeting, she could well find herself in danger, accused of shelving her responsibility for the lady Anne's protection and honour…
On the following evening, her plan laid, Joan again found an excuse to retire early and put the first part of the scheme into action.
With the assistance of Martha, her maid, she removed her day-gown and donned déshabillé .
Then she dismissed Martha, telling her she would have no further need of her services that evening.
Once alone, she went to her closet and selected a gown of dark-blue brocade, its hem and wide neckline trimmed with white fur.
She put this on, emphasising the gown's high waist-line with a modish four-inch wide red girdle that fitted tightly just below the breasts.
The fashionable and becoming gown and girdle were her only concessions to style and conformity.

She brushed
her long hair into a shining mane and arranged it carefully around her shoulders.
Wearing neither head-dress, veil nor jewellery — save the two rings — she stepped into soft shoes of blue leather embroidered with gold.

She glanced in the long mirror and, apparently satisfied, opened an oak chest and took out a drab fustian cloak of the type customarily worn by maidservants of the lower order, the which she had borrowed earlier from the servants' quarters on a pretext.
She fastened the rough cords with practised hands which remembered that which their owner had all but forgotten — thus concealing the blue brocade gown — and pulled the hood over her head.
Critically surveying her reflection, she told herself she would pass muster.
She looked drab, ordinary, anonymous — a woman garbed like a host of others.
But then her face caught her attention — that was not ordinary.
Her cheeks were flushed with excitement, her blue eyes were sparkling — and her dream-like expression was suggestive of a bride going to meet her bridegroom…
She drew the hood more closely about her face, held somewhat by the radiance of her own expression.
You have changed, Joan de Warenne, she thought.
Like it or not, you are in truth of the commonalty — the orphaned daughter of a poor washerwoman.
You are wearing a cloak such as was worn every day by the likes of your mama, your grandmama and yourself.
From childhood to grave, come rain or shine, joy or sorrow, but for a miracle, you yourself would have worn such garb to keep out the cold, the heat and the rain.

s.c: &bquo;Yet still you smile like a bride going to meet her bridegroom!&equo; she murmured.
&bquo;But you are not a bride — oh dear me nay! 'Tis the other who is the bride, the one called Anne.

s.w: You are called Joan — Joan de Warenne — and you are not going to meet a bridegroom.
There will be no bedding for you…&equo;
But even as the whispered words crossed her lips, her pulses were racing and her eyes were shining the more.
She recognized then that she desired it so — that she would, if she could, make it so.

Her life hitherto had been a preparation — she
recognized that now.

Her humble beginnings, the magical means by which she had come to share her half-sister's privileged life and had later by thequeen-dowager's design taken her place, had been part of some pre-ordained plan.
Jack O'Dandy, the innkeeper, and that brutal encounter — even they of a sudden held meaning.
Her ravishment too had been part of the scheme of things.
She gave thought to it now, dwelling for the first time, without fear, without flinching, on what had taken place.
She vividly recalled every detail.
Yes, even that had prepared her.
It had been an enlightenment, given her a sense of her own power, her own worth…
Not that she had seen it so at the time.
Far from it.
Only now, curiously, did she view it thus.
It had prepared her for the coming meeting when she would be alone at last with the youth who was King of England; the youth she loved…
She, Joan de Warenne, was arags-to-riches princess — the heroine of a myriad fairytales.
She loved the handsome prince who was soon to be crowned, and he loved her — or so she believed.
For tonight at least, she was Anne Mowbray, sister-in-law to the handsome prince who was soon to be crowned.
Anne Mowbray was bride, duchess, virgin, the richest heiress in the land.
Anne Mowbray was everything, had everything.
For the time being, she was Anne Mowbray— she was everything, had everything.
None could gainsay her.
None could prove otherwise…
She wanted to forget, had forgotten already, would go on forgetting, that she was the other one — the other one who, as some believed, was presently whiling away her days in a nunnery…
was Anne Mowbray, she who was everything, had everything.
But this Anne Mowbray would stop at nothing — she would chance all to be alone with him she loved best in the world; on one throw of the dice…
Nineteen
Joan was ushered into the king's private chamber by a manservant who had been with him since infancy.
A serving-maid to all intents and purposes, she had presented herself at the door which gave access to the rear stairs, the garden stairs, which led to the royal apartments.
The manservant had appeared as if from nowhere and, on being shown Joan's ring, the agreed signal, had nodded and led the way to the king's chamber.
Following the soft-footed manservant, Joan was struck quite forcibly by the silence — only their footsteps, echoing in the otherwise empty corridor, broke the stillness.
Accustomed by then to the hustle and bustle of court life, she was puzzled.
She had expected the royal apartments to be brimming with activity.
She shivered involuntarily, a reaction prompted by something other than cold…
As the man withdrew as silently as he had arrived, Joan was surprised to find herself alone with the young king.
She had known not what to expect but she was certainly unprepared to find them alone together so soon.

s.c: &bquo;Edward…&equo; she started to say.

s.w: She knew it was not the correct mode of address but she felt a little odd, outside reality, and was afraid she was about to dissolve into tears.

s.c: &bquo;Edward…&equo;

s.w: He came forward at once, his hands held out in greeting.

s.c: &bquo;What joy to receive you thus!&equo; he told her warmly, taking and kissing her hand.
&bquo;I feared even at the eleventh hour that it would not be possible — and I knew not when we could meet else.&equo;

&bquo;My lord, it is good to see you,&equo; she told him, and this
time there were tears in her eyes.
&bquo;Being here with you like this seems like a dream, a dream realized!&equo;

s.w: She unfastened her cloak and he took it from her, noticing as he did so the brocade gown that so exactly matched the colour of her eyes.
And he saw the ring, his ring, that she was wearing openly for the occasion, beside Anne Mowbray's wedding-ring on the third finger of her left hand.

s.c: &bquo;Pray be seated, my lady,&equo; he said, using the courtesy title whilst not for an instant confusing her with her half-sister.
&bquo;There is much to say and I know not where to begin.

s.w: But tell me first of yourself, I pray you.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Of myself?&equo; she asked, as if there were nothing to say.
&bquo;What should I tell you of myself?&equo;
&bquo;Of how it is to be Anne Duchess of York perchance?&equo;
&bquo;With you, my lord, me thinks being Joan de Warenne is more to my liking.&equo;
&bquo;And to mine,&equo; he agreed whole-heartedly.
&bquo;I would you could remain with me for ever!&equo;
&bquo;Within the Tower?&equo;

s.w: Joan shook her head.

s.c: &bquo;Nay, my lord.

s.w: I like not your being in the Tower — it troubles me more than I could say!&equo;
He watched her for a moment in silence.
Then, seating himself beside her, he spoke quietly but with a curious sense of urgency.

s.c: &bquo;Today's events suggest that my future movements could be uncertain,&equo; he told her.
&bquo;Even that the very future is uncertain for some!&equo;
&bquo;Then the journey to the Guildhall was to some purpose, my lord?&equo;
&bquo;One could say that,&equo; Edward agreed grimly.
&bquo;But first let us speak of ourselves.

s.w: I have long yearned for this meeting — even before the king my father's passing.
I planned and connived whilst at Ludlow but never, even in my wildest dreams, did I envisage that, when we did meet, it would be in such dire circumstances!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Then the news is not good, my lord,&equo; Joan said, watching his expression.

s.w: He looked older, she thought — more mature, as if the events and uncertainties of recent weeks had given him a maturity beyond his years.

s.c:
&bquo;The
prince your brother spoke yesterday of the situation, expressing some concern.

s.w: Pray tell me what has transpired?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Presently.

s.w: Presently,&equo; Edward said vaguely, as if to himself.
It seemed to Joan that he was torn betwixt unburdening himself and trying to ignore the issue.

s.c: &bquo;For now, I would rather look at you, take in your beauty and your warmth, hear your voice and bask in your smile — see you in reality just as hitherto I have seen you only in my dreams!&equo;
&bquo;None knows I am here save your manservant — and, of course, my bridegroom!&equo;

s.w: Joan smiled.

s.c: &bquo;I have a key, borrowed from the lady Alianor's apartment, but I must return ere midnight, lest my absence be discovered.&equo;
&bquo;Denby, my manservant, is completely trustworthy — too much so for the likes of those who now have charge of me!&equo;

s.w: Edward said ruefully.
By the protector's command, Denby must leave upon the morrow — he is the last of my own loyal retainers.
Uncouth, unmannerly fellows have taken their place — men who are accustomed not to service, I fear, but to rather more dubious pursuits!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;But surely, my lord…&equo;
&bquo;None knows you are here save my manservant — and your bridegroom, as you said,&equo; interposed Edward, as if he must reveal what was in his mind whilst there was yet time.
&bquo;My brother alone is aware of your true identity.

s.w: He is also aware that I have a deep regard for Joan de Warenne — and in that I fear he is not alone!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Others know also?&equo; asked Joan in alarm.
&bquo;But how could that be, my lord?&equo;
&bquo;The king my father learned of my regard for yourself from Sir Thomas Vaughan who saw it as his duty to inform him,&equo; Edward told her with notable reluctance.
&bquo;Vaughan himself, a gentleman of highest principles, warned me of his intentions, saying it was up to the king to decide what, if any, action should be taken.

s.w: It was after that I was forbidden to write to you.
'Tis unlikely that the king spoke of the matter to my mother or any other — save one!&equo;
Joan hesitated, but only for a moment.

s.c: &bquo;Richard of Gloucester?&equo; she asked, her face paling.
&bquo;The same.

s.w: He and my father were very close, you see — he controlled my lord's armies, and supported him verbally and by arms in all things.
He had my lord's entire confidence — indeed it is hard to credit that anyone could change so radically as has my uncle.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;And what of today, my lord? 'Tis what took place at the Guildhall that causes you distress, is not it?&equo;

s.w: Joan asked, watching him closely.

s.c: &bquo;Later, we will talk of us, if that be your will — but I see that you have much on your mind.

s.w: Unburden yourself, tell me all that has passed — and later we will speak with a clear mind of matters close to our hearts.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;There were the customary acclamations from the populace as I rode in procession to the Guildhall this morning — indeed it seemed to me that my subjects had never before greeted me with such enthusiasm,&equo; Edward told her, gazing into the fire as if reliving the morning's events.
&bquo;I was greatly heartened and told myself I must previously have misjudged the situation — that my subjects were after all behind me and would see that right was done.&equo;
&bquo;As it will be, my lord, I am certain!&equo;
&bquo;I was courteously received at the Guildhall, but found, to my chagrin, my lord of Gloucester already ensconced in the chair of state.

s.w: Having little option, I took my seat beside him.&equo;
Joan looked troubled.
Such discourtesy could surely mean only the one thing, she thought to herself — but she said nothing, waiting for him to continue.

s.c: &bquo;The Duke of Buckingham then stood to deliver an harangue,&equo; Edward went on.
&bquo;First he extolled the virtues of the protector and then proceeded to read a petition which virtually declared myself illegitimate.&equo;
&bquo;Mother of Mercy!&equo; exclaimed Joan in dismay.
&bquo;How could he speak thus?

s.w: Such was surely treasonable.&equo;
Edward shrugged and still avoided meeting her gaze.

s.c: &bquo;Buckingham, I doubt not, has his own axe to grind!&equo; he said sombrely.

&bquo;The petition read, &bquo;It is incumbent upon the council to prevent the crown falling to issue of the pretended
wedlock between his late Majesty and the lady Elizabeth Woodville, made without the consent of the lords of the land, and by the sorcery of the said Elizabeth and her mother Jacquetta — as the voice is throughout the land — privily and secretly in a chamber, without proclamation by banns according to the laudable custom of the English church; the said King Edward being married and troth-plight a long time before to one, Eleanor Butler, daughter to the old Earl of Shrewsbury&equo;.&equo;
&bquo;God have pity!&equo;

s.w: Joan exclaimed with feeling.

s.c: &bquo;How could Buckingham make such treasonable utterances — without being hounded out of the chamber!&equo;
&bquo;Worse was yet to come!&equo;

s.w: Edward said grimly.

s.c: &bquo;Is it your will, gentlemen,&equo; asked Buckingham then, &bquo;to have this prince, Richard Duke of Gloucester, at present protector of the realm, for your king?&equo;

s.w: Surprised murmurs ran through the assembly at that, and then there was silence.
The question having then been repeated to the same lack of response, the Lord Mayor rose to speak.

s.c: &bquo;My lord, your question must be asked of the citizens of this realm,&equo; he told Buckingham, indicating the noisy crowd which had gathered outside the Guildhall.
&bquo;I propose therefore that the Recorder be asked to address the people, he being considered as the mouth of the City&equo;.'
&bquo;And how did the council answer, my lord?&equo; asked Joan.
&bquo;Did not many raise their voices against the proposal and for Your Grace?&equo;
&bquo;Gloucester and Buckingham methinks had done their work well,&equo; Edward said quietly.
&bquo;If any were against the proposal, either they were too lily-livered to protest — or else they were impeded by the rush for the exits!&equo;
&bquo;And once outside — what then, my lord?&equo;
&bquo;Gloucester positioned himself on the Guildhall steps — in the forefront of the assembly.&equo;
&bquo;You are saying that you were again relegated to second place, my lord?&equo;

s.w: Joan asked aghast.
She recalled with a sense of shock thequeen-dowager's words, her uneasy reference to Richard of Gloucester, when commanded to relinquish her younger son.

hi.w: Pray God he may prove a protector

s.c: ! she had said.
&bquo;To second place, you say?&equo;

s.w: Edward shook his head.

s.c:
&bquo;To
the background would be nearer the truth.&equo;
&bquo;Alas that my lord of Gloucester had so far forgotten his duty!&equo;
&bquo;Indeed so great was the press of people around us, that I gripped my brother's arm lest he be trampled underfoot.

s.w: My right hand went instinctively to my sword, thus to force a way through the crowd and take my rightful place.
But caution prevailed.
Such action, I believed — and still believe — would have played into the hands of my enemies.
My being hemmed in by well-armed stalwarts, was part of the plan.
Well-bribed assassins — my uncle's creatures I doubt not — were marking my every move, ready to meet any show of force with greater force.
In the event, it would have been stated that, unrecognized in the confusion, the young king had met with an accident!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;God have pity!&equo;

s.w: Joan was close to tears.

s.c: &bquo;That you, your father's heir and rightful sovereign of the realm, should be treated thus!&equo;
&bquo;Everything happened so rapidly that it afterwards seemed part of an evil dream,&equo; Edward said slowly.
&bquo;Indeed, but for my brother's tears, his reproaches that I had not drawn my sword, I would have dismissed the whole affair as a nightmare.&equo;
&bquo;Pray tell me the rest, my lord — I would hear all.&equo;

&equo; &bquo;Citizens of London,&equo; the Recorder cried, &bquo;is it your will to have Richard Duke of Gloucester, brother of our late king Edward and present protector of this realm, as your king?&equo;

s.w: A hubbub of noise greeted this.
Clearly the populace was taken by surprise and many voices were raised in dissent.
Some called for myself, demanding to know why I was not present.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;So I should hope!&equo; declared Joan roundly.
&bquo;After further confusion, Buckingham conferred with Gloucester and the former took the stage.&equo;
&bquo;The stage, you say?

s.w: Was it then a play, my lord— a charade?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;It seemed so at the time to myself,&equo; admitted Edward ruefully.
&bquo;A play well-rehearsed, in which the leading players carried the lesser players along with them!
&bquo;Hearken to me, good people,&equo; Buckingham said.

pb.c: &bquo;Declare your sentiments one way or another.

s.w: I demand now in plain terms whether you will or not have the protector for your sovereign.&equo;
At that, some apprentices, whom I judged to have been well-primed and well-paid for their services, set up a feeble shout.

s.c: &bquo;Long live King Richard!&equo; they cried.

s.w: This was judged as a declaration of the sentiments of the nation!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Alack-a-day!&equo; breathed Joan.
&bquo;I can scarce believe it — why, none has spoken of it today in my hearing!

s.w: The lady Alianor makes it her business to discover all that goes on, and has many influential friends — yet she has made no mention of it.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;By the morrow, I dare say, the news will have reached all parts of the City — and within a week or two, the entire realm.

s.w: Buckingham will make sure of that.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Buckingham is the protector's chief confederate?&equo;
&bquo;One gained the impression that he had master-minded the whole affair,&equo; Edward said bitterly.
&bquo;If so, that is because it suited my uncle's purpose — he will use Buckingham just as long as it suits him and not a moment longer.&equo;
&bquo;And was it Buckingham who made the final announcement — at the Guildhall?&equo;

s.w: Edward nodded.

s.c: &bquo;Naturally.
&bquo;My lord protector,&equo; he said, &bquo;you are called upon to assume the reins of government by the loyal citizens of London.

s.w: Indeed, my lord, it is plain that the people are as much determined to reject the posterity of our late king that, if Your Grace will not accept the crown, they must turn their eyes on some other person&equo;.'

s.c: &bquo;And my lord of Gloucester accepted?&equo;
&bquo;Not immediately.&equo;

s.w: Edward's tone was ironic.

s.c: &bquo;He appeared to hesitate, as if loath to take on so onerous a burden.

s.w: Then he said, &bquo;My lord, you do me great honour.
However, I cannot accept…&equo;

s.c: &equo;&equo; Your Majesty ,&equo; Buckingham interposed with emphasis, &bquo;onerous as such a duty may be, it is the unanimously expressed will of your subjects&equo;.'
&bquo;And with that, Gloucester accepted?&equo; asked Joan.
&bquo;Not quite,&equo; replied Edward, tight-lipped.
&bquo;He demurred.

&bquo;Nay, my lord, I am unworthy of so high a
calling,&equo; was what he said.&equo;
&bquo;Never was a truer word spoken!&equo; observed Joan.
&bquo;My lord of Gloucester had the right of it there.&equo;
&bquo;Ah, but Buckingham had not finished — he had more to say!
&bquo;There is none more worthy, sir,&equo; he said.

s.w: This was greeted by rowdy applause from the afore-mentioned apprentices — and someone in the crowd responded with, &bquo;I thank you both!&equo; to the general merriment!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;And then, my lord?&equo;
&equo; &bquo;I beg you to reconsider, sir,&equo; Buckingham urged the protector.

s.w: A touching little scene ensued.&equo;
Edward's tone was highly satirical.

s.c: &bquo;The protector closed his eyes and bowed his head, as if seeking Divine guidance.

s.w: Then, straightening up as if already the burden of sovereignty weighed heavily on his shoulders, he made his reply.&equo;
Edward paused, thought Joan, as if the memory of what had followed were too painful to be put into words.
In truth, he was recalling how, in a matter of seconds, his uncle had severed all ties of kinship, loyalty and affection.
His father's brother, Gloucester had hitherto been loyal to a fault.
Reserved, enigmatic, a soldier rather than a statesman — it appeared withal that ambition was the protector's guiding star.

s.c: &bquo;And his reply?&equo; prompted Joan, recognizing his distress but needing to know.
&bquo;His reply?&equo;

s.w: Edward spoke vaguely, as if lost in thought.

s.c: &bquo;Ah, yea— the protector's reply!
&bquo;Alas, gentlemen, you leave me no choice,&equo; he said.
&bquo;I must yield to your earnest persuasions, knowing the matter to be the will of the English people.

s.w: I comply with your plea and will accept the crown&equo;.'
For a full half minute there was silence in the chamber.
Edward seemed of a sudden bereft of further speech and Joan was at a loss for the right words.

s.c: &bquo;My lord —&equo; she said at length &bquo;— I cannot believe that my lord of Gloucester, being your uncle and the acknowledged protector of the realm, intends aught else than to rule in your name until you are of age.

s.w: Perchance, as he sees it, such will make for a stronger monarchy.&equo;

s.c:
&bquo;Your charity does you credit, my lady!&equo; observed
Edward.
&bquo;If only the protector's stealing the crown were all…&equo;

s.w: All? thought Joan.
Why does he say all , as if the crown were a toy, a plaything, a mere nothing — when both of us know it means everything to him!

s.c: &bquo;…

s.w: Sir Robert Brackenbury, constable of the Tower, informed me this morning that my brother and I are to be moved.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Moved whence, my lord?

s.w: To another royal palace — Eltham or Greenwich perchance?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Gloucester intends, as Brackenbury informed me, himself to take possession of the royal apartments here in the Tower.

s.w: Richard and I will be moved to the Garden Tower and there lodged on the upper floor.&equo;
There is surely some mistake, my lord!
Joan sounded perplexed— not for the first time that evening.

s.c: &bquo;The Garden Tower is not part of the royal palace.&equo;
&bquo;The only mistake, as far as I can see, is in Brackenbury giving me intelligence of their plan today instead of tomorrow.

s.w: In so doing, he has enabled me to tell you of the matter — in the fervent hope that you will discover a means of informing the queen my mother of our case.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;As to that, my lord, be assured I shall send word to Her Grace as soon as I leave here.

s.w: please God she will find a way of coming to your aid!
Once I receive word from her, I shall contrive to visit you again.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I suspect that may not be possible,&equo; Edward told her.
&bquo;We are virtually prisoners here, my brother and I.

s.w: Once we are confined in the Garden Tower and Denby is banished from our service, I fear we shall be denied all contact with the outside world.
What the end of it will be, Lord only knows!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;But I am not in the outside world, my lord,&equo; smiled Joan.
&bquo;Am not I Anne Duchess of York, guest within the Tower to the lady Alianor Woodville, cousin by marriage to the queen-dowager?

s.w: That being so, my prince, it should not be too difficult to contrive a further meeting — if such be Your Grace's will.

s.c:
&bquo;Joan, when I departed for Ludlow, it was with a heavy heart — for it seemed to me we had only just found each
other,&equo; Edward told her.
&bquo;But such heaviness of heart is bitter-sweet, in that it pines for the absence of the beloved whilst looking to the joy of reunion.

s.w: Now, all that has changed, alas!&equo;
Seated together on a bench seat by a warm hearth, it seemed to Joan that they were isolated from the intrigue and controversy that were presently raging around the royal family.
They were together — happily and companionably together, separated for a time from the outside world and its evil influences.

s.c: &bquo;Changed?&equo; she asked in pretended alarm.
&bquo;The joys of reunion are no longer of consequence — is that your meaning, my lord?&equo;

s.w: He shook his head.

s.c: &bquo;Nay, such was not my meaning — as you know full well!

s.w: I fell in love with you several moons ago.
Before that, I was heart-free, a somewhat studious fellow, I suppose, who lacked the merry nature of his younger brother.
You are aware of my continuing regard for you — tell me, I pray you, that you yet return my regard.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;You need not the telling, my lord,&equo; she dimpled.
&bquo;We both recognize methinks that, young though we be in years, we are all in all to each other.&equo;
&bquo;In truth, Joan, you are as far removed from myself as ever.

s.w: First my father's plans for my marrying a French princess, precluded my offering you anything more than a clandestine attachment — and now, with the future so uncertain, I fear that clandestine attachment and French princess are each as remote as the other.
Indeed, I strongly suspect that for Richard and myself there is no future!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Surely the prince is not in danger,&equo; Joan protested.
&bquo;He is but heir presumptive.&equo;
&bquo;He is heir to the rightful king of this land,&equo; Edward reminded her — a mite haughtily, Joan thought.
&bquo;Should I die, Richard would under normal circumstances accede to the throne with the lady Anne as his consort.&equo;
&bquo;Myself.&equo;

s.w: He smiled, reflecting her smile.

s.c: &bquo;Yourself indeed, my lady.

s.w:
In truth, 't is Joan de Warenne concerns myself — she
who is closer to me in years and closer still to my heart.
Were it not for her, I dare say Edward Plantagenet would long since have succumbed to ennui and despair.
The future…&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Dwell not on the future,&equo; Joan interposed lightly.
&bquo;Who can tell what lies ahead?

s.w: Let us banish the future for a space— giving place only to here and now, to ourselves and our regard for each other.&equo;
He put an arm around her then and drew her close.
He kissed her on the cheek and then, as she turned her mouth to his, on the lips.

s.c: &bquo;I have ofttimes given thought to doing that —&equo; he told her wonderingly &bquo;— to that and other things.&equo;
&bquo;Giving thought is not for lovers, my lord,&equo; she said softly.
&bquo;Giving thought is only for kings and princes, for innkeepers and washerwomen.&equo;
&bquo;Innkeepers?&equo; he frowned, not understanding.
&bquo;Washerwomen?&equo;
&bquo;Lovers give not thought to actions and words, joy and sorrow, past and future.

s.w: Lovers seek all, take all, letting words, sorrow and the future — like the Devil — take the hindmost!&equo;
She took one of his hands and pressed it to the bodice of her gown.
He ran his fingers lightly over the soft fabric, exploring the contours of her breasts…

She was reminded again of that other time — of hands, cruel and insistent, travelling over her body; of a man four times her age who in one brutal movement had stolen, as if by right, both her maidenhead and her innocence.

Shocking as the assault had been, it had prepared her for another encounter — an encounter with a youth of her own age, bewildered and uneasy, one called to high estate who found himself of a sudden alone on the edge of an abyss…

s.c: &bquo;I have naught to offer you,&equo; the youth was saying and there was sorrow in his voice.
&bquo;Love is all I ask,&equo; she said softly.
&bquo;Yourself and love.&equo;
&bquo;But…&equo;
&bquo;You fear we shall be disturbed, my lord?&equo;
&bquo;Nay.

s.w: Denby has his orders.
He will not unfasten the outer door ere he has cried warning!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;And the prince?&equo;
&bquo;My brother has an understanding of the situation&equo; came the enigmatic reply.
&bquo;Then let us think only of ourselves — and love.&equo;
&bquo;I have not before…&equo;
&bquo;I know.

s.w: I know you have not.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;And what of yourself?

s.w: Have you…?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I love you — naught else matters,&equo; she said, moving away and seating herself demurely on the furskin rug in front of the fire.
&bquo;Come, be seated here beside me!&equo;

s.w: He needed no second bidding.
No longer was he a diffident youth.
Gazing up at him then, meeting those shining blue Plantagenet eyes, she knew there was no turning back.
He was, after all, his parents' child — the offspring of a joyous and passionate union.
His doubts were gone, banished.
She had kindled a flame within him…

s.c: &bquo;Nay,&equo; she cried, seeing his expression — and remembering.
&bquo;Nay…&equo;
&bquo;But I love you,&equo; he said ingenuously.
&bquo;I love you.&equo;

s.w: Again she met his gaze.
She held out her arms to him…
Twenty
The protector was crowned Richard the Third, King of England, at Westminster Abbey one week later, a document having been drawn up bastardizing Edward.

The offspring of Edward the Fourth and Elizabeth Woodville were declared bastards on the grounds that, before his marriage, Edward was affianced to Lady Eleanor Butler, since widowed daughter to the Earl of Shrewsbury — and sister to the Dowager Duchess of Norfolk, Anne Mowbray's mother.

Edward, installed by then with his brother in the Garden Tower, was informed of the turn of events by Brackenbury, the protector not having visited his nephews since the day he had accepted the crown at the Guildhall.
The change of abode and servants was not the princes' only misfortune.
Their days and nights were spent together in a large but gloomy chamber, reached by a winding staircase; and their requests to take the air in the gardens were for the most part ignored.
Edward, whose joyful encounter with Joan de Warenne had given him a further reason for wishing to gain his freedom, sought for some means of contacting his mother.
He mistrusted their new attendants, Dighton and Slaughter, believing them to be the tools of his enemies.
Will Slaughter had been employed formerly as a headsman.
A large man of ferocious appearance with thick black hair and beard, illiterate and unprepossessing, he went by the name of Black Will.

Despite his appearance, the erstwhile executioner treated the princes
with a rough kindliness that set him apart from the other attendants — taking it upon himself to ensure that the food was to their liking and the fire well-tended.
He showed a particular liking for Richard who took full advantage of the situation, though it caused Edward some uneasiness.
Brackenbury one morning, to their great joy, brought the princes a letter from the queen-dowager.

s.c: &bquo;Be pleased to read it, my lord, and then destroy it,&equo; he urged Edward.
&bquo;I am disobeying orders in conveying it to you — but there are some who regard Your Grace as their lawful monarch, though it would cost them their lives to declare as much openly!&equo;
&bquo;I am grateful, sir,&equo; Edward replied with a smile.
&bquo;I had not till now received word from the queen my mother.&equo;
&bquo;Her Grace has ofttimes written to yourself and your brother,&equo; Brackenbury told him.
&bquo;The letters somehow — er — miscarried, alas!&equo;
&bquo;Would it be possible, sir, to have a reply conveyed to Her Grace?&equo; asked Edward earnestly.
&bquo;I dare say she is anxious for news of us.&equo;
&bquo;Let me have it on the morrow, my lord, and I shall see what can be done — needless to say I shall do my best.

s.w: I shall be off-duty on Thursday and intend then to seek audience with Her Grace at the sanctuary.
That will give me an opportunity of passing on any messages — of a verbal nature only, I regret to say!
I myself have information for the queen-dowager.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Indeed, sir?&equo;
&bquo;I have knowledge of certain matters, my lord — God help us all!&equo;
&bquo;Certain matters?&equo; frowned Edward.
&bquo;What mean you, sir?&equo;

&bquo;I mean to tell Her Grace what I know and pray to God that she will discover a means of remedying the situation,&equo; Brackenbury said obscurely — but then he paused, hesitated and, seeming to make up his mind, spoke boldly.
&bquo;King Richard cannot keep you here for ever, my lord.

s.w: In truth, as I mean to tell Her Grace, he means very soon to put an end to your captivity .&equo;

Despite his brother's joyous reception of this
confidence, Edward knew a sense of foreboding.
Was it a warning? he asked himself later.
If not, why should Brackenbury, that most circumspect of gentlemen, have placed emphasis on those last eleven words, giving them a sinister ring?
The letter from their mother was a joy and an inspiration to both princes.
But so graphically did her words convey her love and concern for them that, reading it aloud, both were reduced to tears.

s.c: &bquo;Have faith in the future, my princes,&equo; she had concluded, &bquo; and be of good cheer— you are your father's sons, and he who laughed always at adversity would have been proud of you.
&bquo;God send you good keeping.
&bquo;Written this day at Westminster by the hand of your loving mother &bquo;ELIZABETHWOODVILLE'

s.w: Brackenbury failed to put in an appearance on the following day.
Disappointed at the constable's absence, since he and Richard had prepared a verbal message for their mother, Edward remarked on it to the servant, a stranger, who brought their supper.

s.c: &bquo;He's gone,&equo; came the disquieting response.
&bquo;Gone?&equo; frowned Edward.
&bquo;Aye, gone — g-a-w-n!&equo;
&bquo;He has died, do you mean?&equo;

s.w: Nay, not 'im— not old Blackberry!
He's hopped it — done a bunk, as they says!&equo;
Edward concealed his dismay.

s.c: &bquo;Your name, sirrah?&equo; he enquired evenly, by way of changing the subject.
&bquo;Forest.&equo;
&bquo;Forest?&equo;
&bquo;Aye, that's it — Forest.

s.w: And no laughing, mind!
I don't care for being laughed at.
Them others, Dighton and the big fellow, they laughed fit to bust when I told 'em me name.

s.c: &bquo;Forest?&equo; grinned Dighton, slapping 'is thigh.
&bquo;Aptly named, me friend — plenty of undergrowth but a bit dim in the upper reaches!&equo;

s.w: I landed 'im one for that and bowled him clean over — now he's grinning on t'other side of 'is face!
So watch it, me lord — no laughing!&equo;
In fact Edward had never felt less like laughing.

s.c: &bquo;Am I to understand, Forest, that a new constable has been appointed?&equo; he asked, hoping against hope that the answer would be in the negative — that Brackenbury's absence was only temporary.
&bquo;Understand what ye please, me lord — it makes no odds to me!&equo;

s.w: Gritting his teeth against this insolence, needing to know more, Edward decided to try a more direct approach.

s.c: &bquo;And the new constable's name?&equo; he asked coldly.
&bquo;Tyrell — Sir James Tyrell,&equo; came the gruff reply.
&bquo;Tyrell, you say?&equo;

s.w: Only Edward's eyes gave away the measure of his dismay — and Forest was avoiding his gaze.

s.c: &bquo;Master o' the horse to King Richard —&equo; Forest grinned unpleasantly &bquo;— among other things!&equo;

s.w: Richard, who had so far remained silent, was bitterly disappointed at being unable to send the message to their mother.
But registering the menace in Forest's voice, he too joined in.

s.c: &bquo;Why has Brackenbury resigned his office?&equo; he asked curiously.
&bquo;I dun no, me lord,&equo; shrugged Forest.
&bquo;Didn't 'e tell ye he was off?.&equo;
&bquo;Nay.&equo;

s.w: Richard was no less concerned than his brother by the constable's inexplicable disappearance.
Brackenbury was kindly, and had always shown them the courtesy due to their rank — and himself as their ally.
The need for his mother's support and guidance was still uppermost in Richard's mind.
Now, he thought, there is none to whom we may entrust a message.

s.c: &bquo;He must have left suddenly or else he would have…&equo;

s.w: Catching his brother's warning frown and on the point of saying&bquo;remembered,&equo; Richard smoothly changed course.

s.c: &bquo;… forgotten.&equo;
&bquo;Forgotten?&equo;

s.w: Forest scratched his head.

s.c: &bquo;He would 'ave forgotten, you say?

s.w: Forgotten what?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;He must have forgotten to tell us,&equo; Richard said slowly, as to a simpleton, and deliberately confusing the issue.
&bquo;It goes without saying, sirrah!&equo;
&bquo;Forgot a lot o' things, did old Blackberry!&equo; observed Forest, addressing Richard as if he were of a sudden a force to be reckoned with.
&bquo;Forgot 'oo paid the piper, I dare say!

s.w: Even forgot 'oo was King of England at times — would ye credit that, me lord?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Be assured, sirrah, that the constable was never guilty of that mistake in my hearing,&equo; Edward said quietly — before Richard could muster a retort.
&bquo;Indeed I always considered him a loyal servant of the crown.&equo;
&equo; 'Tis glad I am to 'ear it, me lord,&equo; came the mocking response.
&bquo;Now eat your supper, both o' ye, afore it takes cold.

s.w: The new constable has sent each of ye a mug o' wine — reckoned it'd make a change from ale.
You can thank 'im yourselves when 'e calls on ye later!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I hardly think…&equo;

s.w: Forest's last words had been accompanied by a guffaw, and Edward's half-formed comment was drowned by the slamming of the door as the grinning man left.
The princes ate their supper in silence, neither of them having much appetite.
Both were beset by a growing uneasiness, a feeling that all was not as it should be — that somewhere out there in the darkness, sinister forces were gathering against them…
Why, Edward wondered, did Brackenbury speak yesterday of being off-duty on Thursday when he must already have been on the point of resigning his post?
With Thursday only a day or so hence, why did not he inform us there and then that he would be unable to convey our message to the queen our mother?

hi.w: Let me have the message on the morrow

s.c: , was what he said…

s.w:
It was at that point that Edward recalled the constable's
other words and how they had troubled him even then — seeming to carry a sinister note, a warning.

hi.w: King Richard can not keep you here for ever

s.c: , Brackenbury had said.

hi.w: In truth, as I mean to tell Her Grace, he means very soon to put an end to your captivity

s.w: What was his meaning?
Edward asked himself.
I recall his emphasis on the last eleven words — and how they struck chill into me at the time.
Will Brackenbury in fact still visit our mother — or has something happened to prevent that also?
During the days that followed Brackenbury's hasty departure, Edward's despondency increased.
He developed a tiresome cough which disturbed his brother's rest, and became listless and depressed.
It was as if, the weeks of turmoil and uncertainty that followed his father's death having turned into months, the tumultuous turn of events had proved too much for a youth of his years.
He had suffered the destruction of his most trusted relatives and advisers, the declaration of bastardy with all it implied, the loss of his birthright and sovereignty — and latterly his freedom.

s.c: &bquo;I would mine uncle would let me have my life, though he takes my crown,&equo; he had been heard to say on one occasion.

s.w: He and Richard, very different in temperament, inevitably quarrelled a good deal.
Richard had not lost his sense of fun — his ability to push aside the vexations of the moment and look to better things ahead.
It was he who after a particularly violent disagreement, suggested that Joan should be invited to pay them another visit — though he referred to her as the lady Anne, as had been agreed.
He was, it seemed, fully aware of his brother's attachment to Joan.

s.c: &bquo;My lady Anne is as yet lodged with the lady Alianor within the Tower,&equo; he said.
&bquo;Methinks I should contrive to send her a message, suggesting that she pays me another visit.&equo;
&bquo;Pays you another visit?&equo; asked Edward coldly.
&bquo;I am, after all, her lord and husband.&equo;

s.w: Edward was unjustifiably irritated.

Well aware that it was a game to Richard — a pretence with which to pass the empty hours — and that it was to Anne, rather than Joan, he was in this instance referring, such comments never failed to annoy Edward — as Richard was well aware.

s.c: &bquo;I have no wish to see her,&equo; Edward said flatly.
&bquo;She must not come here.&equo;

s.w: Richard looked at him in surprise, not taking him seriously.

s.c: &bquo;Why so?&equo; he asked.
&bquo;Look at us, Dickon.&equo;

s.w: Edward indicated their unkempt appearance.

s.c: &bquo;Are we in a fit state to receive a visitor?&equo;,

s.w: Richard looked at them.
Their clothes were dirty and their hair unwashed.
After Forest had taken over, all their fine apparel had been removed and replaced with ill-fitting second-hand garments.
They had no change of clothing and those they wore were never washed.
But Richard, who had always delighted in dressing for court functions, seemed unperturbed.

s.c: &bquo;None sees us,&equo; he shrugged.
&bquo;So what does it matter if we look like beggars?&equo;
&bquo; I see you — and you see myself,&equo; retorted Edward.
&bquo;And they see us — and seeing us garbed thus, they grow ever more surly, refusing now to carry out all but the most basic tasks.

s.w: I suspect that were I to appear of a sudden in royal regalia, crown, sceptre and all, it would be a different story!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I see not what that has to do with Joan,&equo; Richard said airily.
&bquo;I expect she would laugh her socks off if she found you here in royal regalia!&equo;
&bquo;Foolish fellow!

s.w: Damsels wear not socks.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Anyway, Joan would not be coming here to admire your regalia!&equo;

s.w: Joan, you say?
Do not you mean the lady Anne, little brother?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;To admire your regalia,&equo; repeated Richard with emphasis.
&bquo;She'd be coming to see how abysmally we are served, that she could inform the queen our mother of our situation.&equo;

&bquo;All the same, I have no wish to be seen like this,&equo; Edward
said as if that were the end of the matter— but Richard heard the catch in his voice.
&bquo;Let us speak no more of it.&equo;
&bquo;I care not who sees me,&equo; said Richard on a note of defiance.
&bquo;I am myself, after all — no matter what I am wearing.

s.w: If you like, Ned, I'll wash your clothes ere she arrives — there's still one jar of soap.
I would quite enjoy it, you know.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I doubt not you would — but whence would we get sufficient water?

s.w: Use what we have on washing clothes and we ourselves would likely go unwashed for a week!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;But 't would not show — not like our clothes!&equo;
&bquo;Besides, they would be certain to shrink — and then what would we do when our visitor arrived, little brother?&equo;
&bquo;Go to bed?&equo; suggested Richard helpfully — and with a mischievous gleam in his eye that prompted Edward to throw a pillow at him.
&bquo;Anyway, she is my duchess — and I shall invite her if I wish to!

s.w: If you like it not, big brother, you have no need to speak with her.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I could scarcely not speak with her, since we have but this one chamber.&equo;
&bquo;You could black your face and pretend to be a boot-boy,&equo; suggested Richard.
&bquo;After all, 'tis myself, her lord and husband, she'd be coming to see.&equo;
&bquo;You believe that?&equo;
&bquo;Nay,&equo; smiled Richard.
&bquo;Neither of us believes it.&equo;
&bquo;Anyway, how would you get a message to her?&equo; asked Edward curiously.
&bquo;I should ask Black Will,&equo; Richard told him.
&bquo;Black Will has taken a fancy to your little brother — what think you of that!

s.w: If I ask him nicely, he will take a message for me, I am sure.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Nay, 'tis too risky,&equo; said Edward, making it clear none the less that he had set aside his former objections.
&bquo;Risky?

s.w: For Black Will, you mean?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Nay, for you and me.

s.w: What if Black Will should tell the others?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;He would not,&equo; Richard said confidently.
&bquo;He speaks to the others as little as possible.

s.w: Methinks they are a trifle in awe of him — him being a headsman and all that!
He likes me though, as I said, and when I smile at him and beg for tales of executions, he laughs and laughs!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Since when has Richard Duke of York taken to begging?&equo; asked Edward haughtily.
&bquo;I confess the fellow's tales appal me — I would you would not encourage him!&equo;
&bquo;They are a mite blood-thirsty — but I expect he exaggerates.&equo;
&bquo;One has the impression of one truly dedicated to his calling,&equo; observed Edward.
&bquo;Calling, you say?

s.w: I'd not dignify it thus,&equo; laughed Richard.

s.c: &bquo;It makes Black Will sound like a monk!

s.w: Anyway, brother, I shall send word to my lady Anne and you shall do as you like.&equo;
Twenty-One

s.c: &bquo;I have received a letter from Prince Richard,&equo; Joan told the lady Alianor.
&bquo;Addressed to myself, it was delivered at the back door this morning by a manservant.

s.w: The letter is brief and unsigned, saying only that my lord wishes me to call on him at the Garden Tower at my earliest convenience.
He asks that I go secretly and after dark — near the eleventh hour, he says — thus to evade the guards who are wont to fall asleep at that time!&equo;
Alianor looked uneasy.

s.c: &bquo;Can you be certain that the letter is indeed from the prince your husband?&equo; she asked doubtfully.
&bquo;I am familiar with my lord's handwriting,&equo; Joan told her.
&bquo;Viewing myself as a future messenger, the queen-dowager ensured that I was so, ere I left sanctuary.&equo;
&bquo;There could be danger,&equo; observed Alianor, looking troubled.

s.w: The letter, delivered covertly, was brief and unsigned.
Rumour and speculation about the princes was on everyone's tongue, it seemed, and in truth she knew not what to believe.
The lady Anne is duchess to the prince, she thought, but one cannot be too careful.

s.c: &bquo;The princes are no longer seen in the gardens, child — none as far as I know has had sight or sound of them for several weeks.

s.w: As you know, I made every effort to gain permission for you to see your lord again — to no avail, alas!
Indeed, it has been lately feared…&equo;
She paused, loath to voice the dreadful rumour.
Joan too had heard the current gossip and had lain awake for much of the previous night, persuading herself it was a fabrication and that she must give no heed to wagging tongues.

But then had come Richard's letter and
with it the realization that no ill had as yet befallen the princes.

s.c: &bquo;As Richard of York's bride, my lady, I can not ignore his wishes,&equo; she said now.
&bquo;I can think of no good reason why I should shy from going openly and without having recourse to others.&equo;
&bquo;Danger,&equo; Alianor told her.
&bquo;By so doing, you could place yourself in danger, my lady — that should be good reason enough.&equo;
&bquo;Since when does a lady place herself in danger by openly visiting her lord?&equo;

s.w: Joan asked — a mite haughtily, the other thought.
Alianor hesitated.

s.c: &bquo;Since the day this lady's lord was removed to the Garden Tower methinks,&equo; she responded plainly.
&bquo;Is not it my duty then to obey my lord's wishes?&equo;

s.w: Alianor evaded the question.
The lass is right, she thought — in her place, I would have given much the same answer.
Good for her!

s.c: &bquo;If you are determined to go, my lady —&equo; she said &bquo;— and in your place, I dare say I should do likewise — I shall first seek permission on your behalf of Sir James Tyrell, the new constable.&equo;
&bquo;Nay, my lady, I fear that might be unwise.

s.w: Were permission refused…&equo;
Joan paused, not wishing to put her thoughts into words.

s.c: &bquo;You would go just the same?&equo; suggested Alianor.
&bquo;Yea, I realize what you have in mind — it would be better to go without permission than to flout a refusal!&equo;

s.w: Joan nodded.

s.c: &bquo;The queen-dowager urges me in her letters to do my utmost to discover news of her sons.

s.w: She too has heard rumours and fears greatly for their safety.
Who has a better right to enquire as to the welfare of Richard of York than the lady Anne his wife?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;The queen-dowager fears greatly, you say?

s.w: She fears a mischief has been done, do you mean?&equo;
Alianor wished the words unspoken as soon as uttered.

s.c: &bquo;Nay, nay, there is always talk — one learns to disregard it!

s.w: One must not give way to despair.
The queen-dowager is naturally anxious for her sons — but we must have patience.

All is well, I am
sure — Richard of Gloucester is simply being overprotective of his nephews.
Richard of Gloucester?
The lady Alianor refers always to the new king thus, thought Joan.
It is not difficult to see whose side she is on!
But she recognizes the need to tread warily and I doubt not she is right.

s.c: &bquo;Since there is speculation and King Richard must surely be aware of it, why does not he let the princes be seen?&equo; she asked uneasily.
&bquo;No longer do they ride in procession through the streets of London.&equo;
&bquo;I know not the answer to your question, my lady,&equo; admitted Alianor.
&bquo;Then I must discover the answer for myself,&equo; Joan told her.
&bquo;Duty demands it.

s.w: Quietly, choosing my time, I shall make my way to the Garden Tower and try to gain access to the upper chamber.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;You believe the princes are held in the upper chamber, my lady?&equo;

s.w: Joan nodded.

s.c: &bquo;My lord's letter to me was headed simply: Upper Chamber, The Garden Tower .

s.w: I shall go garbed as a maidservant and, if seen and questioned, shall concoct a tale about having a message for one of the guards.
Assuming I am unrecognized, I shall bide my time until I can gain entrance to the tower and the winding stairs to the upper floor.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I like it not,&equo; Alianor told her.
&bquo;I like it not at all, lass.

s.w: But since I agree that it is your duty to enquire as to the welfare of your wedded lord, and as…&equo;
She paused, seeming to hesitate.

s.c: &bquo;And, my lady?&equo; prompted Joan.

&bquo;As the queen-dowager, my cousin and dear friend, gave you into my keeping for the time of your sojourn here — then, dear child, if you promise to have a care for your own safety, to give no offence and behave discreetly, you shall have my permission.&equo;
&bquo;And your blessing?&equo;

s.w: Joan asked with a winsome smile.

s.c: &bquo;I would have your blessing also.&equo;

s.w:
Joan had taken a great liking to Alianor Woodville who, during the past restless weeks, had regaled her with colourful tales of the court in earlier days when Henry the
Sixth and Edward the Fourth had played turn-and-turnabout for the English crown.

The tales were lively, not without a strong hint of bawdiness, but they had brought vividly to life the glittering courts of former days — so different, as Alianor was wont to say with a sigh, from the subdued, uneasy court of the present king.
And my blessing child,&equo; smiled Alianor now.

s.c: &bquo;Naturally my blessing — are not we all King Edward's men at heart!&equo;

s.w: Twenty-Two
From Alianor's point of view, this was to be Anne Mowbray's second meeting with her young lord since their arrival at the Tower.

She noticed the girl's apparent excitement, her shining eyes and lightness of step as she made ready for the adventure; and again she wondered, surprised that her charge should give the appearance of a damsel in love, one shortly to be reunited with her bridegroom.
That she is fond of him is natural enough, she thought.
That she is concerned for him and wishes to assure herself as to his welfare is understandable, but that look of shining radiance is a trifle puzzling.
Could it be that 'tis not the younger prince who has stolen her heart?
Could it be that…?
Nay, I am surely thinking foolishly.
Mother of mercy, I must put such suspicions from my mind!
For Joan this would be no ordinary meeting with him to whom ostensibly she was affianced, an enterprise attempted solely to reassure the royal family as to the princes&equo; welfare.
It would be a reunion with her lover; with him she loved better than anyone else in the world.
Thoughts of Edward dominated her young life: it was for him that she yearned, breathed, existed.
Without him, life would mean nothing to her.
Should disaster overtake him and the dreadful rumours become reality, she Joan, alias Anne Mowbray, would not wish for longer life…

Again wearing a voluminous dark cloak and having wooden pattens on her feet, her charge looked, Alianor
decided, every inch a serving-maid.
She nodded approvingly.

s.c: &bquo;You'll do, lass, though you had better keep that hood well down over your head.

s.w: You are pretty as a picture and we would not want you drawing attention to yourself, would we!&equo;
Joan meekly obeyed.

What Alianor had failed to realize was that, under the sombre cloak, she was wearing a new and quite beautiful pale-pink gown trimmed with dark fur — a gown such as few maidservants would set eyes on in a lifetime, much less wear.
Her waist defined by a gold chain girdle, she was wearing Edward's ring on a gold chain around her neck.
Outwardly, as Alianor saw her, she gave the appearance of a servant — but inwardly, to Joan herself, she was a damsel going to meet her lover.
Letting herself out inconspicuously by way of the backstairs, Joan set out after dark for the Garden Tower, taking a circuitous route to avoid arousing suspicion.

Few people were about, owing to the lateness of the hour, and the guards around the entrance of each tower she passed, glanced briefly at her and turned away, seeing only a woman of indeterminate age, muffled in a hooded cloak such as was worn by serving-women everywhere.
She skirted the great hall of the palace and, passing the Wakefield Tower, approached the Garden Tower itself.
She then concealed herself in the shadows between the two towers, thus to survey the scene and decide on her best approach.
She had hoped and expected to find the Garden Tower all but deserted at such a late hour, with the two guards half asleep in the guardchamber on the ground floor.
She could hear a faint murmur of voices but they seemed to issue, not from the guardchamber, but from the middle chamber — that below the one occupied by the princes.
Uncertain what her next move should be, she waited and watched in the eerie light cast by the flambeaus, the flaming torches set in brackets at intervals along the walls.
She shivered of a sudden, and recalled Alianor's parting words.

s.c: &bquo;Not exactly a time to go visiting, lass!&equo; that lady had said with a sigh.

s.w: Joan wrapped the sturdy cloak more closely around herself, concealing all but the lower part of her face.
She waited thus for what she judged to be half an hour, moving a few steps to and fro to keep warm whenever the coast was clear.
Still, there was a good deal of stealthy coming and going within the building — this being ignored apparently by the men on duty in the guardchamber.
She decided she could hear three different voices now, one of them cultured and the other two sounding a trifle over-awed, obsequious.
She judged the first to be that of some official and wondered what such a one would be doing there at an hour now close to midnight.

s.c: &bquo;You have your orders,&equo; she heard the cultured voice say.
&bquo;Obey them to the letter and you will be well rewarded — any bungling or playing the fool and I doubt you'll live to tell the tale!&equo;
&equo; 'Twill be as ye says, constable,&equo; said the obsequious voice.
&bquo;All neat and tidy-like!&equo;
&bquo;Let's get to it then.&equo;

s.w: That was the third voice.

s.c: &bquo;We ain't got all night, Forest!&equo;
&bquo;Slaughter too has his instructions,&equo; Again the voice Joan had identified as that of the constable.
&bquo;You'll have no trouble with him.&equo;

s.w: Joan had met Sir James Tyrell — the constable who had replaced Brackenbury — and she had found him pleasant enough when Alianor had presented him to her.
Now he seemed rather less than pleasant…

s.c: &bquo;So Black Will's waiting 'is turn, is 'e!&equo; chortled the second voice.
&bquo;A task after 'is own heart I'll warrant!

s.w: He's to come up after we goes down — so's there'll be no bumping into each other on them there stairs.
That's it, sir, ain't it?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;That is indeed it,&equo; agreed the constable in a droll voice.
&bquo;So I'll leave you rascals to it.

s.w: No need to trouble yourselves about the guards.
Their liquor has been nicely doctored — gave them an extra ration of ale to celebrate my arrival!
So you'll hear no more from them till morning.
I shall meanwhile betake myself to my lodgings.
Bring word to me there when your task is accomplished.
You are aware of the venue, are you not?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;The venue?

s.w: Oh, I sees what you mean, sir…

Under the stairs as leads up inside the White Tower, Black Will told
us.
Been got ready, 'e said — a wooden chest and all that!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I shall be on my way then.&equo;

s.w: Again the constable's voice.

s.c: &bquo;Mind what I said.

s.w: Any bungling and I'll disclaim knowledge of the whole miserable business.
You're on your own from this moment till you bring word the job is done.
Is that clear?&equo;
The constable apparently left the chamber at that, for half a minute later a cloaked figure came quickly out of the Garden Tower's entrance and disappeared into the darkness.
Joan took her opportunity…

She removed her wooden pattens and, concealing them in her cloak, slipped noiselessly into the tower, past the guardchamber and up the winding stairs to the middle floor where she concealed herself in an alcove outside the chamber door.
She knew not what to expect, or what would happen next.
The overheard conversation had conveyed nothing useful to her.
The princes had not been mentioned and she assumed it to have been instructions for some special task commissioned privately by the new constable.
Whatever it was, she told herself, had nothing to do with her.
Her one concern was to reach the upper chamber without being seen.
She would wait therefore.
Once the other two men came downstairs and disappeared, like the constable, into the darkness, she would make her ascent.
The return journey?
She had given not a thought to that.
But if she could elude constable, guards and attendants one way, she supposed she could likewise elude them the other.
The important thing, the only thing that really mattered to her in those tense and anxious moments, was to reach and be united with Edward…
The nearby door opened and two men came out on to the landing.
With bated breath and trying to make herself invisible, Joan waited for them to pass the alcove and make their way downstairs.
But instead, they turned and mounted the stairs, the one Joan decided was Forest carrying what looked like a large piece of sacking.

They paused halfway up and, straining her ears, she heard them conferring in low tones but was quite unable
to hear what was said.
But then all was silent.
She waited expectantly, willing both men to return and go their way into the night.
Where were they?
Where else, she asked herself, than in the upper chamber which houses the princes!
Even at night, she supposed, they had tasks to perform — making up the fire, taking up water ready for the morning ablutions…
But neither had been carrying coal or water jug — only sacking, an unlikely receptacle for either commodity…
She registered of a sudden that she was bitterly cold.
Her teeth were chattering and her unshod feet felt like blocks of ice.
But 'tis only October, she thought, and the weather as yet is mild.
It was then she recognized it was fear that had set her limbs a-tremble and turned her blood to ice.
She was assailed by apprehension; by a sense of foreboding, of doom, of indescribable evil…
She crossed herself.

s.c: &bquo;Holy Michael, Archangel, defend us in the day of battle.

s.w: Be our safeguard against the wickedness and snares of the Devil…&equo; she said under her breath, reciting the age-old invocation.
She quelled an urge to race up the winding stairs and find out for herself what was going on.
Nothing, she told herself, could be worse than this uncertainty, this sense of impending disaster.
I desire only to know that all is well; that it is but my own foolishness, aided by my being here at so unholy an hour, which causes me such anguish…
She heard footsteps descending the stairs above, two sets of heavy-booted footsteps.
She waited breathlessly, pressed closely into a recess in the outer wall, straining her eyes to catch a glimpse of the men as they came within the orbit of the flambeau.
She must see what was going on; must find out who the men were and what it was they were carrying…
That they were carrying something she did not doubt, for they moved slowly, carefully, as if bearing some precious burden…
As the men came into view, she could see their shapes clearly enough, though their faces were blurred in the flickering light.
One walked ahead with the lantern, since the stairs were too narrow to give passage to two at once.

pb.w: But it was the second man who riveted Joan's attention.

s.w: He, the one she had assumed to be Forest, was descending carefully, stealthily, carrying some heavy object…
As they reached the middle landing where Joan stood in the shadows, as if by tacit consent the men paused for a brief rest, placing lantern and sack-shrouded burden on the floor.
As they did so, part of the sacking fell away, exposing its contents to view…
A shrill scream rent the air then — and one of the men leapt forward whence the sound had come.

s.c: &bquo;Nay, nay!&equo; cried the agonised voice.
&bquo;Nay, it cannot be.

s.w: God have pity!
Christ have pity!
Not Edward, my beloved Edward…&equo;
The dreadful cries ceased as a hand was clapped roughly over the young woman's mouth.
She struggled for a few moments until, overcome apparently by shock, she lost consciousness.

s.c: &equo; 'Tis a wench,&equo; muttered the first man uneasily.
&bquo;A serving-wench— fallen into a swoon, she 'as.

s.w: What'll we do?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Well, we ain't letting 'er go, that's for sure,&equo; Forest told him, releasing his hold so that she crumpled to the floor.
&bquo;The constable would 'ave our heads.

s.w: Nay, we'll take no chances — she saw 'oo it was, you know!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;See to it then, Forest.

s.w: I'll throw 'is Lordship over me shoulder and go on down— 'tis not much farther.
You'd best finish the job and follow on after.
Make it look like she's fallen and struck 'er head — no tell-tale marks, mind!
There's not space for more 'an two of 'em in that there chest.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;What about Black Will?&equo;
&bquo;Waiting down below for us, I shouldn't wonder — wanting us to get a move on so's 'e can keep 'is hand in at 'is old trade!

s.w: Funny is old Will — know what I mean?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Funny?

s.w: Queer, d'yer mean?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Hm.&equo;
&bquo;Never knows what to make of 'im…&equo;
&bquo;For gawd's sake get on with it, mate!

s.w: Look, she's coming round…&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Not if I knows aught about it, she ain't!&equo;

s.w: Twenty-Three

s.c: &bquo;Had you no idea who she was?&equo; demanded Tyrell, the constable, of Forest on the following day.
&bquo;No idea at all?&equo;
&bquo;Not when we found 'er, sir,&equo; Forest told him.
&bquo;Gave us a start, I can tell ye, coming on'er like that lurking in the shadows.

s.w: And that scream of 'ers — fair froze me blood, it did!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Thought she was a spectre, did you?&equo; asked Tyrell facetiously.
&bquo;An earlier victim come back to haunt you?&equo;

s.w: Forest hesitated, loath to admit such a flight of fancy.

s.c: &bquo;Not exactly, sir — though I'd wager Dighton did, for 'e turned pale as ashes.&equo;
&bquo;I'm surprised you had time to observe his reaction — you seem to have acted pretty quick-sharp!&equo;
&bquo;Methought 'twas a serving-wench on 'er way to a secret how-do-you-do!&equo;
&bquo;Are you in the habit then of despatching pleasurebound wenches?&equo;

s.w: Forest's eyes narrowed.

s.c: &bquo;Nay, not them — only prisoners and inconvenient princes!&equo; he said incisively.
&bquo;Watch your tongue, Forest — I've sufficient information against you and the other rogue to hang you both twenty times over.

s.w: I'd not have given you the task otherwise!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Beg pardon, sir, I'm sure,&equo; Forest said insolently.
&bquo;When Slaughter told me what had transpired, I had the lass brought here to my lodgings, and had a physician take a look at her.&equo;
&bquo;Oh, the maid was dead right enough — dead as mutton.

s.w: I'd bet me boots on that!&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Dead she appeared to be —&equo; Tyrell agreed grimly &bquo;— a maid, in more ways than one, she was not!

s.w:
That
maidservant you murdered so readily was none other than Anne Duchess of York — bride to the younger prince.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;How was I s'posed to know that — she didn't look like a duchess.

s.w: She looked like a maid, I tell ye.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;As it happens, she was a duchess but not a maid,&equo; Tyrell said sardonically.
&bquo;What is more to the point, she was, as the physician informed me, not dead — not quite!&equo;
&bquo;God's eyeballs!

s.w: Then…?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;When the physician examined her, he found she was not a virgin!

s.w: Indeed, your latest victim seems to have been a veritable bundle of surprises — not a maidservant but a duchess, not dead but alive — and, to top all, affianced to an eleven-year-old and not a virgin!&equo;
Tyrell sighed as if the magnitude of human folly never failed to appal him.

s.c: &bquo;He judged, did our physician, that the duchess had likely lost her maidenhead some two years earlier — and had not had carnal relations since.

s.w: What think you of that!&equo;
Were I to tell ye what I thinks o' that, mate, like as not you'd 'ave me guts for garters! thought Forest.
What's the old goat on about anyway?
Carnal relations indeed!
might 'ave 'ad carnal relations and 'im too I shouldn't wonder — but I'll thank 'im to leave my relations out of it!

s.c: &bquo;We could not take chances,&equo; continued Tyrell, whose question had apparently been rhetorical.
&bquo;Whilst it was the physician's opinion that she had not had carnal relations for some two years, he could not say for certain.

s.w: And if he were mistaken, it was just possible that the lass was with child.
You understand my meaning, do you not?&equo;

s.c: &bquo;I dun no,&equo; said Forest, scratching his head.

s.w: It was all a bit beyond him — and what concern was it of his!
Why all the fuss? he thought.
As to whether the duchess was in pod — if she was a duchess as I 'ave me doubts — who cares a tinker's cuss anyway!
Certainly not 'er!
The wench is dead — or is she?

s.c: &bquo;I dun no, sir.&equo;
&bquo;A discussion took place thereafter betwixt certain interested parties,&equo; Tyrell told him.
&bquo;Me lord Buckingham?&equo; enquired Forest — but the constable seemed not to have heard the question.
&bquo;Certain interested parties,&equo; he repeated sombrely.

&bquo;It was decided, with reluctance needless to say, that steps must
be taken — of such a nature as would avoid suspicion — to complete your handiwork!&equo;

s.w: Ah, thought Forest, I've got it at last!
I see now what 'tis all about— what the old josser is after!
He wants me to tell the same traveller's tales as 'im and 'is mates — the artful hound!
To complete your 'andiwork, he says — as if suggestin' as me and Dighton left the job half done.

s.c: &bquo;I see,&equo; he said with an emphasis that prompted the constable to glance suspiciously at him.
&bquo;I see.&equo;
&bquo;The duchess's body was afterwards placed head-on against the rear wall of the royal apartments,&equo; continued Tyrell, in the manner of one detailing the arrangements for a state function.
&bquo;It was discovered there this morning.&equo;
&bquo;And none suspects?&equo; asked Forest with a carelessness that in no measure deceived the constable.
&bquo;So it would seem.&equo;
&bquo;None knew if she was in the family way?&equo;
&bquo;Personally, I doubt she was,&equo; admitted Tyrell.
&bquo;Early days maybe, as the physician said — he could not rule out the possibility.

s.w: Anyway as I indicated, we could not take the chance.
Had she been so, then last night's work would have been for naught.
The duchess being bride to the heir presumptive, with the princes gone, any issue of hers would have been regarded by many as rightful sovereign of the realm.
As it is…&equo;

s.c: &bquo;As it is —&equo; put in Forest gleefully &bquo;— yours truly 'as not done such a bad job after all!&equo;
&bquo;As it happens,&equo; said Tyrell pointedly.
&bquo;As it happens.

s.w: But had your bungling been discovered earlier and by someone else, all hell would have broken loose.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;Then you'll pay the piper?&equo;
&bquo;With certain provisos.&equo;
&bquo;Meaning?&equo;
&bquo;Utter so much as a word about last night's work and you will be clapped in irons,&equo; declared Tyrell.
&bquo;I am not one for shilly-shallying, as well you know, Forest — in the event, I should make sure you were Will Slaughter's next victim.&equo;
&bquo;Slaughter, you say?

s.w: Now I comes to think on it, I've not set eyes on Black Will since afore we went to the Garden Tower last evening.&equo;

s.c: &bquo;No more has anyone else,&equo; came the rejoinder.
&bquo;Oh, he is around — we may be sure of that!

s.w: It seems the fellow carried out his task well enough — there are two corpses in the burial chest this morning.
But who could say for certain?
Will Slaughter has gone and one might suppose another has gone with him.
However, there is no point in looking for trouble.
Let sleeping dogs — together with sleeping princes and duchesses — lie, say I!&equo;
